Document_Content: urn:contentItem:4585-DYM0-0197-F2YF-00000-00<published>1997-01-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 119</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tread lightly, for our kids' sake</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>EARLE G</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PARK wherever you damn well please. Don't give way. Go places where there are no people, no noise, no rules.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Hold it! No rules? Wherever you please? We know what the advertisements for Jeep's new Wrangler are trying to say, but they might have put it better.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Fortunately, most 4WD owners do not park where they damn well please, except maybe in the city. And most know that wherever they go, there are rules.</p><p>True, a lot of 4WD drivers ignore the rules but they are doing so with less abandon than, say, five years ago. The message is spreading that the impact we have on our favourite spots could eventually ruin those places for our kids and their kids.</p><p>Rummaging through some old motoring column photographs recently I came across one of a 1980 Patrol at Fraser Island, with yours truly standing beside it admiring the fantastic view. The Patrol was parked on a dune, on top of new growth. Guilty. I tore the photo up.</p><p>Four-wheel-drive clubs today are usually environment conscious and subscribe to the Tread Lightly! program.</p><p>Tread Lightly! is an international campaign supported by vehicle manufacturers, some large companies, government departments, clubs and individuals with a common purpose: to protect outdoor recreation areas.</p><p>The basic idea is to help people develop the skills to enjoy themselves in the outdoors without having any lasting impact.</p><p>Tread Lightly! in Australia is spearheaded by Mrs Jan Scudamore, of Brisbane, who recently returned from the USA Tread Lightly! annual conference in Colorado.</p><p>Interestingly, at an advertising function the editor in chief of Popular Mechanics put advertising agencies and vehicle manufacturers on notice that "they had better change their ways".</p><p>"The current trend of advertising is very destructive, like a forest fire out of control," he said, warning that the loss of access to land was accelerating so rapidly in the US that in two years motorised vehicles could be restricted to paved roads.</p><p>Mrs Scudamore sees similar trends here.</p><p>Over the past 10 years drivers, riders and other users have caused so much damage to public and private land that access to large recreational areas has been progressively restricted.</p><p>Unfortunately, this has led to more and more people being forced on to remaining areas, which then deteriorate more rapidly.</p><p>One such area is the Canning Stock route, which stretches 1872km from Wiluna to Halls Creek in Western Australia.</p><p>It is one of the few truly isolated tracks left in the world. But the famous route is in danger of being loved to death, according to Mrs Scudamore. She doesn't mince words. A big part of the problem is human excrement.</p><p>"In the early days of the stock route, the cattle had an excuse, they didn't have to wipe their behinds," she said.</p><p>"Today's modern traveller on the Canning has no excuse and plenty of options when it comes to disposal of the unmentionable and all the other rubbish.</p><p>"Increasing numbers of thoughtless and unskilled travellers are discarding rubbish at bush campsites, chopping down living trees for fuel and doing their business in holes dug too shallow to escape the notice of dingoes, leaving a landscape of toilet paper flapping in the breeze."</p><p>Tread Lightly! has formed a working party to develop an education program aimed at all future travellers of the route.</p><p>The working party includes people from two WA government departments, the WA Association of 4WD Clubs, the Keep Australia Beautiful Council, the Heritage Council of WA, a 4WD magazine and a Canning route tour operator.</p><p>"Due to the remote location, sparse population and limited resources of the area, any proposals for a management plan would need to place strong emphasis on self reliance, a code of conduct, minimal supervision and responsible self-management by visitors," Mrs Scudamore said.</p><p>The first priority will be to replace old rubbish signs with more appropriate signage.</p><p>Tread Lightly! also hopes that in the meantime, people will dig deep _ not only for the unmentionable, but into their pockets to help fund the long-term education and planning program.</p><p>Membership forms for Tread Lightly! can be found at most 4WD and accessories outlets or by contacting Mrs Scudamore at PO Box 123, Coorparoo 4151.</p><p>Tread Lightly! also has a toll-free information number: 1800 650 881 and its e-mail address is: huttenme</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:468K-K110-015G-S55N-00000-00<published>2002-07-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES-TYPE- FEATURE-COLUMN- TRAVEL; Pg. T08</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A vintage capital</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JEFF COLLERSON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Canberra's turn-of-the-century temperance society members must be spinning in their graves. Their former meeting room, the Toual Public Schoolhouse built in 1888, has become a wine-tasting facility.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The schoolhouse is the focal point of Ken Helm's idiosyncratic winery, 6km out of the village of Murrumbateman on the Barton Highway, and 45km from Canberra.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mention Canberra and most of us think politics, foreign embassies and the National Gallery, Parliament House and the Australian War Memorial.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Tasting wine would be at the bottom of the scale in most national capital tourists' must-visit lists.</p><p> Yet John Richard Hardy (no relation to the Hardy winemaking clan) planted grapevines in Yass, on the edge of Canberra, in 1853.</p><p> That was 23 years before James Busby lit what became a "vinous forest fire" by establishing a vineyard in the Hunter Valley.</p><p> While the Hunter wine industry never stopped growing, Canberra's had a short life until resurrected as a cottage industry in 1971 by the Lake George and Clonakilla wineries.</p><p>Canberra wine's shot-in-the-arm came when Ken Helm quit his job as a CSIRO scientist two years later and established the district's first commercial vineyard and winery.</p><p> Every successful wine region has a champion -- a local winemaker who takes it upon himself to garner publicity extolling the virtues of his area's produce.</p><p> Helm has been so successful that his face appears regularly on Canberra Tourism promotional material and in 2000 was given the title of "Canberra's honorary ambassador".</p><p> Inside Helm's quaint cellar door, besides thumbing your nose at those temperance wowsers with a schoolhouse tasting, you can inspect a working 1920s Bordeaux wine press that goes like the clappers during vintage.</p><p> Best way to visit Canberra is to enter the region along the Barton Highway and leave via the Federal Highway. This way you can choose from six Murrumbateman area wineries, grab an excellent yet inexpensive lunch at Barrique, built in 1879 as the Traveller's Rest Inn, then head to Canberra.</p><p> Latest, and for mine the best, attraction is the free entry National Museum of Australia, which opened on the Acton Peninsula in March last year and welcomed a million visitors in its first 12 months.</p><p> I'm no "culture vulture" and until my wife dragged me into the National my perception of museums was stodgy and usually boring. Put those notions aside here.</p><p> The museum houses 172,000 historical and indigenous objects, including 95,000 Aboriginal stone tools and the world's largest collection of bark paintings.</p><p> Five permanent exhibitions comprise Nation (symbols of Australia), Horizons (peopling of Australia since 1788), Eternity (stories from the nation's emotional heart), Tangled Destinies (Australia's land and people) and First Australians (a gallery of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders).</p><p> Nation, tracing Australia's development from the kangaroo to the Hills Hoist, has 700 props which help convey stories like the Bean car which Francis Birtles drove from London to Melbourne in 1927-28.</p><p> Horizons chronicles tales of early settlers like Richard Johnson, Sydney's first Anglican priest who established Christianity in a remote convict settlement; and Mary Lee, a 19th century Irish migrant who championed women's rights in South Australia.</p><p> Highlight of Eternity is an inter-active exhibit that lets visitors record their own story. So far 8000 yarns have been composed, and all will become part of the display.</p><p> Tangled Destinies explores early Europeans' reactions to Australian nature, impact of introduced species and technological innovations born of grim requirements. Here you can watch the skeleton of a diprotodon -- the largest marsupial that ever lived -- come to life, and view memorials to extinct native animals such as the Tasmanian tiger.</p><p> First Australians profiles 40,000 years of indigenous heritage, outlining five different Aboriginal communities and their living cultures.</p><p> At the hands-on, inter-active kSpace children can design vehicles and buildings in a futuristic Australia, while Our Place features a tankstand hideaway (shared with a crocodile), treehouse (complete with snake) and backyard and magic wardrobe cubby-houses.</p><p> When leaving Canberra take the Federal Highway and inspect the showpiece Kamberra Wine Tourism Complex, opened in September 2000.</p><p> Joshua Moore, who received the area's first land grant in 1824, named his property Canberra after hearing local Aborigines calling the area Kamberra.</p><p> Set on 8.5ha and surrounded by vineyards, the complex has a showcase display of Canberra's 24 wineries, a restaurant and tasting room, glassware exhibits from a local workshop and 11am daily tours.</p><p> For $10 visitors get a souvenir glass, taste a dozen new release wines and a 45-minute inspection of the workings of the winery.</p><p> It's the perfect end to a varied and never boring trip.</p><p>Fact file</p><p>Where to try wines:  Kamberra Wine Tourism Complex and its Meeting Place restaurant, 10am-5pm daily (except Christmas Day and Good Friday). (02) 6262 2144.</p><p> Helm Wines, Butts Rd, Murrumbateman, (02)62275953 10am-5pm except Tues and Wed.</p><p> Where to eat: Barrique cafe & restaurant, Barton Hwy, Murrumbateman -- brunch Saturday and Sunday; lunch Thurs-Mon, dinner Saturday night, closed Tuesday and Wednesday, (02) 6227 5600.</p><p> What else to see:  National Museum of Australia, Acton Peninsula, Canberra. Open 9am-5pm daily, except Christmas (02) 6208 5000.</p><p> Canberra Tourism & Events Corporation (02) 6205 0002.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4MXC-NYH0-TX52-R27P-00000-00Junk (F) Email Does it HRT when you laugh?2007-01-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 22Junk (F) Email Does it HRT when you laugh?Andy Toulson

Looking for a laugh but don t have time to open up the spam cluttering your e-mail? Let us do it for you. Spam

junkie Andy Toulson is a serial e-mailer and we decided to put her talents for recognising the ridiculous to good use.

Each week she will filter out the rubbish and present the best of spam

PONDERISMS

* I USED to eat a lot of natural foods until I learned that most people die of natural causes.

* Gardening rule: when weeding, the best way to make sure you are removing a weed and not a valuable plant is to pull on it. If it comes out o f the ground easily, it is a valuable plant.

* The easiest way to find something lost around the house is to buy a replacement.

* Never take life seriously. Nobody gets out alive anyway.

* There are two kinds of pedestrians: the quick and the dead.

* Life is sexually transmitted.

* Health is merely the slowest possible rate at which one can die.

* The only difference between a rut and a grave is the depth.

* Health nuts are going to feel stupid someday, lying in hospitals dying of nothing.

* Have you noticed since everyone has a camcorder these days no one talks about seeing UFOs like they used to?

* Whenever I feel blue, I start breathing again.

* All of us could take a lesson from the weather. It pays no attention to criticism.

* In the 60s, people took acid to make the world weird. Now the world is weird and people take Prozac to make it normal.

* How is it one careless match can start a forest fire, but it takes a whole box to start a campfire?

* Why is there a light in the fridge and not in the freezer?

* If quizzes are quizzical, what are tests?

* Do illiterate people get the full effect of Alphabet Soup?

* Did you ever notice that when you blow in a dog's face, he gets mad at you, but when you take him on a car ride, he sticks his head out the window?

* Why doesn't glue stick to the inside of the bottle?

TYPICAL. . .

ONE day, a man came home and was greeted by his wife dressed in a very sexy nightie.

''Tie me up,'' she purred, ''and you can do anything you want.''

So he tied her up and went golfing.

NICE WORK

A WOMAN came home, screeching her car into the driveway, and ran into the house. She slammed the door and shouted at the top of her lungs: ''Honey, pack your bags. I won the lottery!''

The husband said: ''Oh my God! What should I pack, beach stuff or mountain stuff?''

''Doesn't matter,'' she said. ''Just get out.''

VERY TRUE

MARRIAGE is a relationship in which one person is always right, and the other is a husband.

TWENTY DOLLARS

ON their wedding night, the young bride approached her new husband and asked for $20 for their first lovemaking encounter.

In his highly aroused state, her husband readily agreed.

This scenario was repeated each time they made love, for more than 30 years, with him thinking that it was a cute way for her to afford new clothes and other incidentals.

Arriving home around noon one day, she was surprised to find her husband in a very drunken state.

During the next few minutes, he explained that his employer was going through a process of corporate downsizing, and he had been let go.

It was unlikely that, at the age of 59, he'd be able to find another position that paid anywhere near what he'd been earning, and therefore, they were financially ruined.

Calmly, his wife handed him a bank book which showed more than 30 years of steady deposits and interest totalling nearly $1 million.

Then she showed him certificates of deposits issued by the bank which were worth more than $2 million, and informed him that they were one of the largest depositors in the bank.

She explained that for the more than three decades she had 'charged' him for sex, these holdings had multiplied and these were the results of her savings and investments.

Faced with evidence of cash and investments worth more than $3 million, her husband was so astounded he could barely speak, but finally he found his voice and blurted out: ''If I'd had any idea what you were doing, I would have given you all my business!''

That's when she shot him.

You know, sometimes men just don't know when to keep their mouths shut.

THINGS YOU DON'T WANT TO HEAR DURING SURGERY

1. Better save that. We'll need it for the autopsy.

2. Accept this sacrifice, O Great Lord of Darkness.

3. Bobo! Come back with that. Bad dog!

4. Wait a minute, if this is his spleen, then what's that?

5. Hand me that. uh. that uh. . . that thingy there.

5. Oh no! Where's my Rolex?

7. Oops! Hey, has anyone ever survived after 500ml of this stuff before?

8. There go the lights again!

9. Ya know, there's big money in kidneys and this guy's got two of 'em.

10. Everybody stand back! I lost my contact lens!

11. Could you stop that thing from beating -- it's throwing off my concentration.

12. What's this doing here?

13. I hate it when they're missing stuff in here.

14. That's cool! Now can you make his leg twitch by pressing that one?

15. Well folks, this will be an experiment for all of us.

16. Sterile schmerile. The floor's clean, right?

17. What do you mean he wasn't in for a sex change?!

18. OK, now take a picture from this angle. This is truly a freak of nature.

19. This patient has already had some kids, am I correct?

20. Nurse, did this patient sign an organ donation card?

21. Don't worry. I think it's sharp enough.

22. What do you mean 'You want a divorce?!'

23. FIRE! FIRE! Everyone get out!

24. Darn! Page 47 of the manual is missing.

urn:contentItem:4MGF-9X80-TX52-R1YX-00000-00JUNK (F) EMAIL Something worth pondering2006-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 34JUNK (F) EMAIL Something worth ponderingAndy Toulson

Looking for a laugh but don t have time to open up the spam cluttering your e-mail?

Let us do it for you. Spam junkie Andy Toulson is a serial e-mailer and we decided to put her talents for recognising the ridiculous to good use.

Each week she will filter out the rubbish and present the best of spam.

PONDERISMS

* I USED to eat a lot of natural foods until I learned that most people die of natural causes.

* Gardening rule: when weeding, the best way to make sure you are removing a weed and not a valuable plant is to pull on it. If it comes out of the ground easily, it is a valuable plant.

* The easiest way to find something lost around the house is to buy a replacement.

* Never take life seriously. Nobody gets out alive anyway.

* There are two kinds of pedestrians: the quick and the dead.

* Life is sexually transmitted.

* Health is merely the slowest possible rate at which one can die.

* The only difference between a rut and a grave is the depth.

* Health nuts are going to feel stupid someday, lying in hospitals dying of nothing.

* Have you noticed since everyone has a camcorder these days no one talks about seeing UFOs like they used to?

* Whenever I feel blue, I start breathing again.

* All of us could take a lesson from the weather. It pays no attention to criticism.

* In the 60s, people took acid to make the world weird. Now the world is weird and people take Prozac to make it normal.

* How is it one careless match can start a forest fire, but it takes a whole box to start a campfire?

* Why is there a light in the fridge and not in the freezer?

* If quizzes are quizzical, what are tests?

* Do illiterate people get the full effect of Alphabet Soup?

* Did you ever notice that when you blow in a dog's face, he gets mad at you, but when you take him on a car ride, he sticks his head out the window?

* Why doesn't glue stick to the inside of the bottle?

WARNING FOR ALL WOMEN!

THIS is a heads-up to those friends who haven't experienced it yet, and an explanation to those friends and family who have. Most of you have read the scare-mail about the person whose kidneys were stolen while he was passed out.

Well, read on.

While the kidney story was an urban myth, this one is not.

It's happening every day.

My thighs were stolen from me during the night a few years ago. It was just that quick.

I went to sleep in my body and woke up with someone else's thighs.

The new ones had the texture of cooked oatmeal.

Who would have done such a cruel thing to legs that had been mine for years? Whose thighs were these and what happened to mine?

I spent the entire summer looking for my thighs. Finally, hurt and angry, I resigned myself to living out my life in jeans and Sheer Energy pantyhose.

Then, just when my guard was down, the thieves struck again.

My butt was next. I know it was the same gang, because they took pains to match my new rear end (although badly attached at least 8cm lower than my original) to the thighs they stuck me with earlier.

Now, my rear end complemented my legs, lump for lump.

Frantic, I prayed that long skirts would stay in fashion.

It was two years ago when I realised my arms had been switched. One morning I was fixing my hair and I watched horrified but fascinated as the flesh of my upper arms swung to and fro with the motion of the hairbrush.

This was really getting scary. My body was being replaced one section at a time.

How clever and fiendish.

Age? Age had nothing to do with it. Age is supposed to creep up, unnoticed, something like maturity.

NO, I was being attacked repeatedly and without warning. In despair I gave up my T-shirts. What could they do to me next?

My poor neck disappeared more quickly than the Thanksgiving turkey it now resembled.

That's why I decided to tell my story. I can't take on the medical profession by myself.

Women of the world, wake up and smell the coffee.

That really isn't plastic that those surgeons are using. You KNOW where they are getting those replacement parts, don't you?

The next time you suspect someone has had a face 'lifted', look again. Was it lifted from you?

I think I finally found my thighs . . . and I hope Cindy Crawford paid a really good price for them!

This is not a hoax.

This is happening to women in every town every night.

WARN YOUR FRIENDS.

P.S. I must say that last year I thought someone had stolen my breasts. I was lying in bed and they were gone!

As I jumped out of bed I was relieved to see that they had just been hiding in my armpits as I slept. Now I keep them hidden in my waistband.

DUTIES OF WIVES

THREE men were sitting together bragging about how they had given their new wives duties.

Terry had married a woman from England, and bragged that he had told his wife she needed to do all the dishes and housework.

He said that it took a couple of days but on the third day he came home to a clean house and the dishes were all washed and put away.

Jimmie had married a woman from Canada.

He bragged that he had given his wife orders that she was to do all the cleaning, dishes and the cooking.

He told them that the first day he didn't see any results, but the next day it was better. By the third day, his house was clean, the dishes were done, and he had a huge dinner on the table.

The third man had married an Australian girl.

He boasted that he told her that her duties were to keep the house cleaned, dishes washed, laundry and ironing twice a week, lawns mowed, windows cleaned and hot meals on the table for every meal.

He said the first day he didn't see anything, the second day he didn't see anything, but by the third day, most of the swelling had gone down and he could see a little out of his left eye.

Enough to fix himself a bite to eat, load the dishwasher and call a handyman.

Pg. 24</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>VICTORIA'S MOST WANTED</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Bag snatched at bookshop</p><p nitf:lede="true">THEFT</p><p nitf:lede="true">A WOMAN lost $3000 from her personal bank account after her handbag was stolen from the Victoria University bookshop in Footscray last year.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The bag containing cash, credit</p><p nitf:lede="true">cards and personal belongings was taken from the bookshop in Ballarat Rd on Monday, June 4.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Police believe stolen identification was later used to withdraw $3000 from a personal bank account at an Oakleigh branch on September 19.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Investigations reveal the stolen credit cards have been used in attempts to set up mobile phone and store accounts but have been declined.</p><p>Police hunt man over forest fire</p><p>CRIME OF THE WEEK</p><p>POLICE found a bottle of kerosene and several rags soaked in the highly flammable liquid at the scene of an arson attack at The Basin this year.</p><p> Detectives are seeking public help in identifying a man they wish to speak to in relation to the suspicious fire at the Doongalla State Forest on January 29.</p><p> The fire was discovered about 6.30pm by three women horse riding along Edgar Track in the forest.</p><p> A man hiding in bushes took the women by surprise.</p><p> Soon after, they smelled smoke and turned back to find a small fire at the base of a tree near where the man had been.</p><p> They put out the fire as they saw the man walking away along the track. Police later found the kerosene and rags near the scene.</p><p> The man is described as Caucasian, aged in his mid 40s, about 173cm to 178cm tall, and of medium build.</p><p> He was balding around the top of his head and spoke slowly.</p><p> He was wearing a light blue short-sleeved shirt, dark blue shorts and work boots.</p><p> Police have released a computer image of a man they wish to speak to in relation to the incident.</p><p>Woman bashed in Prahran lane</p><p>VIOLENT ROBBERY</p><p>A WOMAN was bashed with a piece of wood in a violent assault in Prahran.</p><p> Police believe a man lured the woman into a lane off High St about 5pm on Saturday, June 23 last year.</p><p> He then armed himself with a piece of wood and hit her head and face before making off with her backpack containing cash and personal belongings.</p><p> The victim was treated in hospital for head injuries.</p><p> Police want to speak to a tall, skinny man with long dark hair tied in a ponytail.</p><p> They believe he calls himself Zelko and has links to the North Melbourne and Fitzroy areas.</p><p>Tailgater towed away boat</p><p>STOLEN</p><p>A MITSUBISHI Magna with false number plates may lead police to a stolen 5m boat from St Kilda marina last year.</p><p> The runabout and its trailer were stolen from a restricted area at the marina on Marine Pde at 6pm on Tuesday, July 31.</p><p> Police believe the light-coloured, late '80s model Magna gained access to the compound by closely following another vehicle inside, before hitching up the boat trailer and driving away.</p><p> The missing craft is a white Haines Hunter runabout with green stripes along the side, registration number AO-605.</p><p> It was fitted with a Johnson 115 horsepower outboard engine and was on a boat trailer with registration C-66130.</p><p> Detectives have released a picture of the stolen boat and are appealing for anyone who recognises it to come forward.</p><p> WANTED</p><p>MICHAEL James Bellingham, 33, is wanted by police for burglary.</p><p> Mr Bellingham allegedly broke into a house in Kirkham Rd, Dandenong, in August 1994.</p><p> He was arrested and charged with burglary, but warrants for his arrest were issued when he failed to appear in court.</p><p> Mr Bellingham is 180cm tall, with a ruddy complexion, solid build, hazel eyes and brown hair.</p><p>UPDATE CALLS to Crime Stoppers have resulted in the following:</p><p>ARRESTS</p><p>MADE</p><p>Last week15</p><p>Since 1/7/01327</p><p>Total 5561</p><p>RECOVERED</p><p>STOLEN PROPERTY</p><p>Last week$11,250</p><p>Since 1/7/01$419,616</p><p>Total$13,385,920</p><p>DRUGS</p><p>SEIZED</p><p>Last week$39,000</p><p>Since 1/7/01$6,280,847</p><p>Total$61,108,435</p><p>Totals date from Crime Stoppers' inception in 1987.</p><p>ARRESTS</p><p>OF THE WEEK</p><p>SEXUAL crimes squad detectives have charged a man, 23, over an attack on a woman at Sorrento on March 1.</p><p> A passerby found a 36-year-old Rosebud woman naked in bushes at the base of a five-metre embankment at Sorrento beach.</p><p> The injured woman was flown to hospital suffering exposure, facial injuries and bruising.</p><p> Detectives arrested and charged the man with a range of assault offences on March 4.</p><p>TWO men in their 30s face burglary and theft charges following a police pursuit at Airport West on March 2.</p><p> Police responding to a report of a burglary at an electrical goods warehouse early in the morning disturbed two men driving from the scene.</p><p> After a pursuit lasting several minutes the vehicle crashed into a pole. Two men were arrested nearby.</p><p> Officers recovered stolen goods from the crashed car, which was stolen from Footscray on February 11.</p><p> PREVENTION HINT</p><p>IT is generally safe to use a credit card on the Internet but ensure you know with whom you're dealing. Credit card statements should be checked regularly to identify transactions. Should you discover that your credit card number has been used to make an unauthorised transaction, you should immediately contact your bank or credit provider and request a transaction reversal.</p><p>CRIME STOPPERS: 1800 333 000</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4M9J-2F10-TX52-F339-00000-00Green jihad a disastrous idea2006-11-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisFEATURESOpinion / Op EdPg. 16

MATP

Green jihad a disastrous ideaDENNIS SHANAHAN, POLITICAL EDITOR

To safeguard jobs, it is essential for us to keep carrying coals from Newcastle

IT used to be that carrying coals to Newcastle was considered the height of idiocy, a wasted effort without the hope of a financial return. The new height of idiocy is to stop coal going from Newcastle.

The backbone of NSW's second-largest city -- a Labor town built on the steel of the BHP mills and the coal from the Hunter Valley -- is still coal, despite all the changes the valley has been through.

It is also the undeniable backbone of Australia's domestic energy needs for decades to come and will continue to supply the bulk of the world's energy until 2050.

And this is not the pipedream of a fossil industry but the conclusion of the British Stern report, which urges economic changes to fight greenhouse gas emissions. We can't do without coal; we have to learn to live with it.

To try to kill off the $9billion coal industry in NSW and the exports shipped from Newcastle is to condemn the city and thousands of workers and businesses.

Yet this week, in the grip of greenhouse hysteria, the Newcastle City Council, at the behest of Greens councillors and supported by Labor councillors, determined that Newcastle's coal shipments should be limited.

The motion said the council recommended ''the NSW Government establishes a cap on coal exports from Newcastle at existing levels'' and ''initiates a moratorium on new coalmines at Anvil Hill and elsewhere in the Hunter Valley and Gunnedah Basin''.

It went one further by backing calls from conservation groups to shut down the coal industry, and called for the industry ''to fund the just transition to sustainability in the Hunter beyond coal''. That is, levy the coal industry to fund its own closure and find jobs for the displaced workers. ''Just transition'' is greenhouse-friendly code for sack workers.

Not surprisingly, local federal MP Joel Fitzgibbon, a Labor frontbencher and former resources spokesman, went ballistic: ''Extreme environmentalists are launching a jihad against the industry in an attempt to close it down, and the community must be told the other side of the story,'' he said.

''We must strive to increase the share of electricity produced by renewable technologies, burn our coal more cleanly and efficiently and tighten environmental safeguards. But killing King Coal would be a disaster for the valley.''

The heresy committed in Fitzgibbon's electorate allowed him to publicly vent feelings about anti-coal campaigns being conducted by conservationists in the name of fighting greenhouse gas emissions. There is trepidation in the ranks of Kim Beazley's supporters about the ALP being swept along in the emotional surge of anti-coal feeling.

Endorsed federal Labor candidate and potential ALP leader Bill Shorten and Victorian state Labor candidate Evan Thornley both suffered collateral damage this week because of their links with the GetUp campaign. As the national secretary of the Australian Workers Union, Shorten was defending the pay and conditions of the unsung heroes of the Melbourne Cup, the jockeys, but at the same time GetUp, of which he and Thornley are board members, was calling for an end to the coal industry and a ''just transition''. Both rapidly distanced themselves from any suggestion they supported the closure of the coal industry.

Beazley also made it clear yesterday that the future of Australia's baseload electricity power would come from coal and that he was backing the coal industry: a clean coal industry.

The Opposition Leader was emphatic about the Newcastle council's ban: ''That's not the right answer. The right answer is to go down the road of active measures for clean coal technology. We've got to become the world experts at clean coal technology and, as we export coal, we need to export those technologies with it, make sure we can survive economically and also survive environmentally.''

Beazley is right: it's a mixture of surviving economically and environmentally. But there has been too much emphasis from Labor on the potential effects of greenhouse gas emissions from coal-fired power stations.

Certainly there is a clear political differentiation between the Howard Government and Labor over the ratification of the Kyoto Protocol and entering a carbon emissions trading scheme that makes coal more expensive. But Labor has to be careful not to be seen as embracing unreal emotional claptrap that threatens the livelihoods of tens of thousands of Australian workers.

Labor's industrial relations campaign and its position on Iraq have rebuilt the ALP base and secured it a steady spot above the crucial 40per cent of the primary vote in opinion polls, but it cannot afford to alienate that base in pursuit of a new campaign to pick up concerned green Liberals in leafy suburbs and keep faith with the progressive Labor Left.

Howard's response on climate change and greenhouse gas emissions has been ad hoc and sloppy. Some sort of an emissions trading scheme is inevitable, yet the Coalition is poorly placed to deal with the politics.

However, don't dismiss the prospect of Howard preparing an important statement on greenhouse emissions and climate change before Christmas in which he sets out a more coherent agenda that is unapologetically worker friendly.

Howard learned in 2004 that playing cat and mouse with Mark Latham over the Tasmanian forest issue worked in his favour in two ways: first, Latham went too green too early, and second, the reverberations of defending jobs went far beyond Tasmania. Putting forward practical steps to address greenhouse emissions and protecting jobs is a political winner.

The anti-coal brigade is already damaging Labor by association and creating internal tensions, and the next frontier of forests is yet to be reached. Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation Minister Eric Abetz started the forest fire in the Senate this week when he pointed out that plantation forests cut carbon emissions and offset greenhouse gas emissions from industry. Conservation groups have also pointed to a forgotten aspect of the Stern report, which urges a halt to deforestation and highlights the positive aspects of planting trees and using wood instead of other materials in building.

Howard was surprised last week in the face of Senate committee evidence that in 2002-03 electricity generation emitted 160 megatonnes of greenhouse gases while in just three weeks bushfires released 130 megatonnes.

Old-growth forest management, logging state forests, plantation timber and pulping are the next frontiers in the greenhouse war.

Howard has been slow to enter the fray but Labor has more to lose if the realisation dawns before the election that there are drastic and unjustified changes being proposed in the name of greenhouse panic.

urn:contentItem:4GVV-9P80-00VK-21MS-00000-00<published>2005-08-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>International News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Highlights of the AAP world wire at 19:00 Aug 12</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Highlights of the AAP world file since 12:00<br/><br/>HK: 3 Aussies to face HK heroin trial after pleading not guilty</p><p nitf:lede="true">HONG KONG, Aug 11 AAP - Three young Australians are to stand trial in Hong Kong after pleading not guilty today to trying to smuggle $A1 million worth of heroin packed in condoms back home. (HK DRUGS Nightlead sent at 16:00, 587 words.)</p><p nitf:lede="true">With:<br/>ASIA: Father watches as daughter sent to trial with two others</p><p nitf:lede="true">HONG KONG, Aug 12 AAP - Ferdinand Diaz looked weary as he walked out a drab Hong Kong courthouse and pushed his way through crowds of commuters to catch a packed subway train. (HK DRUGS SCENE (With HK Drugs N/L) sent at 18:05, 373 words.)</p><p>And:<br/>ASIA: Corby lawyers write to PM to slam Ellison<br/>JAKARTA, Aug 11 AAP - Schapelle Corby's Indonesia lawyer has demanded Prime Minister John Howard sack Chris Ellison, accusing the justice minister of failing to help her client and to use her legal travails to boost his political ambitions. (INDON CORBY sent at 17:08, 302 words.)<br/><br/>PAC: PNG govt expects visit by Downer over police program</p><p>PORT MORESBY, Aug 12 AAP - The Papua New Guinea government expects Foreign Minister Alexander Downer to visit Port Moresby soon to resolve an impasse over Australia's stalled policing program. (PNG POLICE sent at 18:17, 408 words.)</p><p><br/>UK: British government defends plans to deport foreigners</p><p>LONDON, Aug 12 AP - Britain's top legal official today defended plans to deport a radical Muslim cleric and nine other foreigners suspected of posing a threat to national security, despite claims by rights groups that they could face torture in the countries they are sent to. (UK BLASTS Second Nightlead sent at 18:13, 563 words.)<br/><br/>MID: "No regrets" about impending Gaza pullout says Sharon</p><p>JERUSALEM, Aug 12 Reuters - With days to go until the start of Israel's Gaza pullout, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today he had no regrets about his plan to evacuate settlers from the territory despite deep divisions in the Jewish state. (MIDEAST SHARON sent at 17:22, 311 words.)</p><p>With:<br/>MID: More than 5,000 anti-pullout infiltrators in Gaza</p><p>JERUSALEM, Aug 12 AFP - More than 5,000 anti-pullout demonstrators have managed to slip into Gaza Strip settlements to oppose the evacuations due to kick off on August 17, Israeli military sources said today. (MIDEAST PULLOUT sent at 18:00, 306 words.)<br/><br/>MID: Sunni Arab leaders reject Shi'ite proposal for a federal Iraq</p><p>BAGHDAD, Aug 12 AP - Sunni Arab leaders today rejected Shi'ite calls for a federal Iraq enshrined the constitution, saying the proposal would fracture the country along religious and ethnic lines. (IRAQ Nightlead sent at 18:31, 385 words.)<br/><br/>PAC: Aust immigration considers visa for Muslim speaker</p><p>AUCKLAND, Aug 12 AAP - Australia's immigration department today was considering a visa application by a British Muslim convert accused of extremism. (NZ GREEN sent at 18:11, 313 words.)<br/><br/>NZ: Former NZ PM joins nuclear debate</p><p>WELLINGTON, Aug 12 NZPA - New Zealand's former prime minister and one-time ambassador to Washington Jim Bolger entered the nuclear debate today, calling for open dialogue with the United States over Wellington's ship visit ban. (NZ NUCLEAR sent at 16:34, 403 words.)</p><p>With:<br/>PAC: Deserting Kiwis give NZ Labour a taxing time before poll</p><p>AUCKLAND, Aug 12 AAP - About 600 Kiwis jump the Tasman every week to live and work in Australia. Their desertion has now become a central campaign issue ahead of what promises to be one of New Zealand's closest elections.(NZ VOTE AAP Backgrounder sent at 13:29, 701 words.)<br/><br/>EUR: Polish president calls on Putin to stop attacks on Poles</p><p>WARSAW, Aug 12 AFP - Polish President Aleksander Kwasniewski called today on Russia to take decisive steps to find and punish the perpetrators of a series of attacks on Poles in Moscow, including two embassy staff members. (RUSSIAPOLAND Nightlead sent at 17:50, 394 words.)<br/><br/>US: Deadly inmate escape leads to surrender 36 hours later</p><p>KINGSTON, Tennessee, Aug 12 AP - George Hyatte must have been thinking about freedom as he was led away in shackles, handcuffs and chains from the old red-brick courthouse in the little Southern town of Kingston, Tennessee. (US ESCAPE sent at 16:37, 803 words.)<br/><br/>JPN: Another 23 Japanese schools to use nationalist textbook</p><p>TOKYO, Aug 12 AFP - A district of Tokyo today adopted a nationalist history textbook for its 23 schools, the third school board to opt for the book that has outraged China and South Korea. (JAPAN TEXTBOOK sent at 16:13, 291 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Malaysians pray for rain to end haze crisis</p><p>PORT KLANG, Malaysia Aug 12 Reuters - Malaysians prayed for rain and a quick end to the country's worst pollution crisis in eight years as residents today choked on acrid forest-fire smoke blowing in from Indonesia. (MALAYSIA HAZE Nightlead sent at 15:28, 459 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Arroyo to call for impeachment case to be thrown out</p><p>MANILA, Aug 12 AFP - President Gloria Arroyo is to ask Congress to throw out an impeachment case against her for alleged vote-rigging on the grounds that the main evidence had been digitally altered, a senior aide said today. (PHIL ARROYO sent at 15:13, 411 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Taiwan begins deployment of cruise missiles: report</p><p>TAIPEI, Aug 12 AFP - Taiwan has begun deploying home-made cruise missiles on mobile launchers capable of hitting major military targets in southeast China, a newspaper reported today in Taipei. (TAIWAN CHINA sent at 14:46, 301 words.)<br/><br/>AFR: Sth African gold miners return to work after crippling strike</p><p>JOHANNESBURG, Aug 12 AFP - South African gold miners trickled back to work today, ending the biggest strike to hit the world's top producer in 18 years and as the industry counted the losses from the crippling five-day protest. (SAFRICA STRIKE Nightlead sent at 18:46, 351 words.)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4GVV-9P80-00VK-21MS-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-29</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="973"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1901 Australian Associated Press Pty. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Cleaning up the e-graffiti</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Vandals like to leave their mark on the web, as Karen Dearne reports</p><p nitf:lede="true">SCRIPT kiddies are trashing the internet with tags -- signature viruses and worms created simply to leave a mark but which cost billions of dollars to eradicate.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The problem is so out of hand that public education campaigns are needed to raise awareness and promote safe cyber-security practices, Symantec chief executive officer John Thompson says.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "More than 95 per cent of network security breaches are driven by individuals, or a group of individuals, who do not have a political or financial motivation," he says.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "They are young adults, mostly men aged 14 to 24, who just want to put a mark on the wall and say, 'I did it'.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>"Just like in the old days, when people wrote their gang signatures, or their personal signatures, on the side of a building -- it's graffiti."</p><p> But the costs of repairing network and system damage far exceed the costs of scrubbing paint off walls -- the Nimda worm alone caused an estimated $US3 billion ($5.8 billion) in economic loss worldwide when it hit last year.</p><p> While most security breaches occur within an organisation, it should not be assumed that these are politically or financially motivated either.</p><p> "Disgruntled employees, or careless employees, create a lot of the problems within company networks," Thompson says.</p><p> "The pragmatic reality is that there are simple precautions that every individual and every organisation can take to deal with cyber-security."</p><p> Home users are beginning to get the message, with Symantec's Norton range of consumer internet security products growing by more than 30 per cent last year.</p><p> But Thompson says more needs to be done. He favours a "Smokey the Bear"-style campaign, mirrored on an earlier scheme that raised awareness of forest fire risks.</p><p> "Personally, I believe any home user should not be on the web without basic firewall functionality, some intrusion detection capabilities and some ability to control the content that flows in and out of the home -- particularly if you're on a broadband connection."</p><p> Within organisations, most security breaches are due to lapses in policy or practices rather than failure to deploy technology.</p><p> "People buy a lot of technologies, but they forget to update virus definitions, they forget to police passwords, they forget to remove access for people who have left the company," he says.</p><p> "We know there is a significant deficit in skills, so we have developed services to help our customers deploy and use our technologies in the most effective way."</p><p> Security is a hotspot in the IT sector, with the US Computer Emergency Response Team reporting twice as many serious network events in 2001 than in 2000.</p><p> "But you will also see that the complexity of those threats has grown exponentially, with Code Red and Nimda having devastating effects," Thompson says.</p><p> "In fact, if the trend continues, we're going to have to employ just about everybody in the world to deal with cyber-security!"</p><p> This may not faze Symantec too much -- the company has built on its anti-virus heritage to become the dominant global brand in internet security.</p><p> IDC estimates the market for security software and services will exceed $US25 billion by 2004.</p><p> In the past 15 months Symantec has expanded its portfolio to offer an array of technologies and services to protect the "critical infrastructures" of everyone from home users to corporate systems.</p><p> "Over the last 12 months our enterprise security revenues have grown by more than 30 per cent every quarter," he says.</p><p> "We have won a sizeable contract in the US for the Navy and the Marine Corps, which is the largest internet infrastructure project undertaken in our country for government.</p><p> "In the private sector, we do business with 98 of the Fortune 100 companies, and globally more than 400 of the top 500 do business with us."</p><p> Many of these customers were principally focused on anti-virus products, but "now they want to talk to us about other security technologies".</p><p> Interest has finally reached corporate board level, he says. "While they all rushed to web-enable parts of their business, they now recognise they can't accelerate their move to the web without appropriate security as part of that plan," he says. "Success for e-commerce initiatives, and e-government initiatives, is critically dependant on how thoughtful the advocates of those approaches are in their deployment of security."</p><p> The release in the US last week of the SymantecGateway Security Appliance, the first to feature five applications -- firewall, anti-virus, content filtering, intrusion detection and virtual private networking -- heralds the new "all points covered" approach.</p><p> Thompson says his company is focusing on customer "pain-points" -- reducing complexity, making security applications easier to manage, driving down costs -- and ensuring its products and services are uniformly available in every region.</p><p> "Quite frankly, our future depends now on how we grow our business base globally," he says.</p><p> "Our business in Australia is exceedingly strong. We've got some exciting products to launch as the year unfolds, and we look forward to serving a broader set of needs for people in that market."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7X8K-SHK0-Y9B7-50JD-00000-00HighLights of the AAP National Wire at 14:30, Dec 92009-12-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSHighLights of the AAP National Wire at 14:30, Dec 9

  HIGHLIGHTS NATIONAL
   COPENHAGEN - A draft deal has been hatched at the Copenhagen climate conference which would see Australia green up its actions on global warming. (Summit Deal Aust. With factbox)
   BRISBANE - Australians could be hit with a tax bill of up to $400 billion under a draft deal leaked from the Copenhagen summit, Opposition Leader Tony Abbott says. (Summit Deal Abbott)


   SEE ALSO: Summit Plimer, Climate Abbott, Climate AMA
   TO COME: Climate Wrap, Summit Wrap late on Wednesday from Copenhagen
  
   MELBOURNE - The science may be old and the extreme weather more recent, but one thing's official: the climate is getting hotter. (Summit Weather Aust Wrap. With submitted graphics)
  
   CANBERRA - The federal opposition leader hopes his new frontbench will help him reinvigorate Howard's battlers and shape them into an election-winning "Abbott's army". (Liberals Wrap to come)
  
   SYDNEY - The syndicate planning to buy the remaining 705 ABC Learning childcare centres said the final sale price won't be settled until March next year, but it's expected to be more than $15 million. (ABC Learning Price)
   ABC Learning Wrap to come
  
   CANBERRA - Consumer confidence weakened further in December after the Reserve Bank took the unprecedented decision to lift its cash rate for a third time in as many months. (Consumers)
   Economy Wrap to come
  
   SYDNEY - Australian kidnap victim Nigel Brennan has admitted he shouldn't have risked being in Somalia but says his motives were honourable. (Brennan Wrap. Pix available)
  
   SYDNEY - One person is dead and another has suffered critical chest injuries after a fire-fighting helicopter crashed at Dorrigo, on the mid-north coast of NSW. (Helicopter 3rd update)
   BRISBANE - The Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) has forecast severe grassland and forest fire danger for the Darling Downs and Granite Belt district. (Bushfires Qld)
   TO COME: Bushfires NSW Wrap (taking in keHelicopter), Bushfires Qld Wrap
  
   MELBOURNE - The last person who saw seven-year-old Linda Stilwell alive said she felt a great fear for the little girl who was playing by herself on the St Kilda foreshore the day she disappeared in 1968. (Stilwell)
   Stilwell Wrap to come
  
   ADELAIDE - Bikie and former boxing champion Edward Yost subjected his partner to a series of sadistic and vicious beatings, before leaving her body to rot in his basement. (Yost )
  
   MELBOURNE - A judge has halted the corporate regulator's bid to bring a second proceeding against former AWB boss Andrew Lindberg over kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's Iraqi regime. (Lindberg)
   Lindberg Wrap to come
  
   HOBART - An antiques roadshow through Tasmania has unearthed a painting by Australian great Arthur Streeton, an auction house says. (Streeton)
  
   SYDNEY - Macquarie Radio Network Ltd, the owner of Sydney radio stations 2GB and 2CH, looks set to enter the Melbourne market after signing a heads of agreement with Pacific Star Network Ltd. (Macquarie Radio)
   SYDNEY - Morning radio broadcaster Steve Price has quit 2UE after eight years. (Price)
  
   MELBOURNE - AFL chief Andrew Demetriou has called on Australian soccer bosses to respect the needs of the other football codes, claiming Etihad Stadium cannot be part of any bid for the 2018 or 2022 World Cup finals. (WC18 AFL)
   WC18 Aust Wrap to come

   JAKARTA - Indonesia has told Australia it will finally move to outlaw people smuggling next year. (Indon Smuggling to come)
  
   LOS ANGELES - British actor Jude Law will help keep the legacy of his late, great friend Heath Ledger alive. (US Ledger)
  
   BROOME - Aussie songstress Missy Higgins says she's been inspired by experimental musicians like Brian Eno and film composer Philip Glass while writing for her third studio album. (Higgins)
  
   GOLD COAST - A team of medical researchers, led by a Gold Coast academic, has queried the use of Tamiflu and criticised the secrecy of the pharmaceutical company making billions of dollars a year from the weapon of choice against influenza. (Tamiflu. Outseeking more)
  
   MELBOURNE - The most popular cars favoured by young drivers are also the least safe, a new study has found. (Cars)
  
   CANBERRA - Good news ladies - reaching middle age could take longer than it used to, with new data showing a rise in the nation's median age. (Age)
  
   ADELAIDE - You'll be pleased to know that there's no problem with the Christmas turkeys this year. But the same cannot be said for puddings, cakes, boxed chocolates, confectionary and even seafood. (Turkeys)
  
   ADELAIDE - Two key communication tools of the 21st century, the mobile phone and Facebook, will be closer linked under a new service from Telstra. (Facebook )
  
   CANBERRA - The explosive detection dog that was lost, and then found, in Afghanistan is still stuck in Oruzgan province waiting for a veterinary clearance to return home to Australia. (Afghan Sabi)
  
   TOWNSVILLE - Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has chastised Westpac for sending an email to customers justifying its recent interest rate hike by comparing the bank to a business selling banana smoothies. (Westpac Rudd)
  
   CANBERRA - Australians of German heritage can now access the service records of a large part of Germany's World War I army. (Heritage )
  
   SYDNEY - A woman has denied threatening to kill her son a year before she murdered him and dumped his body in a suitcase in a Sydney duck pond, a judge has been told. (Pfitzner. Wrap to come)
  
   SYDNEY - NSW's budget deficit is set to blow out to over $1 billion this financial year but will return to the black 12 months earlier than forecast, the state government says. (Budget NSW. Wrap to come)
  
   SYDNEY - Strict new rules are needed on state government advertising amid concerns recent campaigns could be seen as serving party political interests, the NSW auditor-general says. (Advertising NSW. Wrap to come)
  
   SYDNEY - NSW's corruption watchdog has called for an overhaul of the state's security industry licensing system, after an inquiry into one dodgy training firm recommended prosecution of its boss and some staff. (ICAC Security Update)
  
   SYDNEY - A 22-year-old man bashed with a hammer, a bottle and a chair during a violent northwest Sydney home invasion is lucky to be alive, police said. (Hammer Update)
  
   SYDNEY - A Sydney GP who misdiagnosed a patient suffering serious heart disease has been ordered to pay him $776,000 in damages. (George)
  
   MELBOURNE - An Melbourne taxi driver who was stabbed in the chest may have been a victim of road rage attack, police say. (Taxi Update. Pix Available. Outseeking more)
  
   MELBOURNE - A 29-year-old man is on the run from police after a bloody fight that left a man dead in a Melbourne lane. (Park  Update. Pix available. Wrap to come)
  
   MELBOURNE - A retired Supreme Court judge will consider whether Victoria needs specific hate crime laws to deal with offences like attacks on Indian students. (Justice)
  
   MELBOURNE - The Dalai Lama has addressed Victorian politicians at a reception at parliament house, but the premier was noticeably absent. (Dalai. Wrap to come)
  
   MELBOURNE - A colony of rare legless lizards has been found in central Victoria, one of only five known populations in the state. (Lizard)
  
   BRISBANE - Striking Queensland Rail (QR) workers will be better off in the long run after the state government's decision to publicly list the company, Treasurer Andrew Fraser says. (Rail Qld Wrap)
  
   BRISBANE - Queen Victoria's declaration that established Queensland as a colony separate from NSW will be re-read on Thursday, exactly 150 years after the event. (Q150)
   CAIRNS - Prime Minister Kevin Rudd has dismissed calls for the establishment of a new state in northern Queensland, saying Australia had enough governments. (State Rudd)
  
   BRISBANE - A man accused of killing another man with a golf club may have been acting in self-defence, a court has been told. (Thatcher)
  
   BRISBANE - The winner of Tuesday night's $40 million Lotto draw has come forward, saying he can't believe his luck. (Casket Wrap)
  
   ADELAIDE - South Australian police have moved to have a second bikie club branded a declared group under the state's tough anti-gang laws. (Rebels )
  
   PERTH - The local community is "cautious" about BHP Billiton's sale of its Ravensthorpe nickel operation to a Canadian-based miner, a councillor says. (BHP Ravensthorpe)
  
   HOBART - A giant iceberg is drifting towards Western Australia, impressing scientists with its capacity to travel so far north while still largely in tact. (Iceberg. Outseeking more)

urn:contentItem:49M5-J4R0-01S8-D381-00000-00<published>1990-04-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Done on a grand scale as always</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>THOMPSON P</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ALWAYS Directed by Steven Spielberg Produced by Steven Spielberg, Frank Marshall and Kathleen Kennedy</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Screenplay by Jerry Belson and Diane Thomas Leading players: Richard Dreyfuss, Holly Hunter, Brad Johnson, John Goodman, Audrey Hepburn Universal, Rated PG, 121 mins, GUO April 12 THERE used to be a BBC radio program with music supplied live by a bandleader called Wally Stott and his Augmented Orchestra. I loved that word "augmented". It sounded like "tormented orchestra" and it conjured up visions of a vast army of musicians from around the country, a legion of fiddlers, trumpeters and drummers combined to raise the roof of the world.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Steven Spielberg is that sort of director. He marshalls such prodigious resources that even the simplest story is given epic proportions. Spielberg's Augmented Orchestra, a congregation of dazzling talent, helps to make Always the loudest, flashiest, fastest movie in town.</p><p>Which is a bit strange because, unlike his generally underrated Empire of the Sun, Always is a little piece, an intimate story about the bonds of love and the pain of separation. But Spielberg chooses to tell it against a vast background of landscapes incinerated by flame and an army of brave firefighters on the ground and in the air.</p><p> Pete Sandich (Richard Dreyfuss) is a fearless flier, a man who lives to get behind the controls of his converted World War II bomber, an A26, which he flies into forest fires dropping chemical retardant.His best mate Al Yackey (John Goodman) flies a Catalina flying boat.</p><p> The complicating factor is Pete's girlfriend Dorinda (Holly Hunter).Pete and Dorinda are madly in love, ideally suited to each other and blissfully happy together. It is the perfect love affair. Except, of course, for Pete's dangerous flying which gives Dorinda the heebie jeebies.Wouldn't you know it? The night he pledges to take a safe job he is called out on an emergency and crashes.</p><p> That's just the beginning. Pete finds himself on the way to heaven, but an angel (the ever-smiling Audrey Hepburn) tells him he has unfinished business on earth. He must hand on his natural, God-given ability to another flier. And he must release Dorinda from the shackles of the love she still bears for him so that she can live her life.</p><p> Nature has already set things in motion. A young, accident-prone pilot called Ted (Brad Johnson) has fallen in love with Dorinda. But Pete finds himself torn with jealousy.</p><p> Able to move freely in and out of the thoughts of Ted and Dorinda, Pete is nevertheless invisible to them (but not to us) and he's tempted to cause mischief rather than do good works.</p><p> Richard Dreyfuss makes a charming, lovesick ghost and Holly Hunter brings her unique, quirky intensity to the tomboyish Dorinda. John Goodman has some star turns as Al, and Brad Johnson makes a sexy Ted.</p><p> The central story broaches some interesting psychological territory.The theme of death, grief and rebirth is cleverly explored. It is certainly a much breezier treatment than the original 1943 film version, A Guy Named Joe, which mixed in notions of patriotism and self-sacrifice.</p><p> REMOVING the deus ex machina of a righteous war casts Spielberg's film somewhat adrift. It becomes a wacky fable, missing the portentousness, the self-importance of its forerunner.</p><p> Not that there isn't plenty of action. The flying and forest fire scenes are brilliantly staged, quite extraordinary, in fact. It's just that fighting a fire doesn't carry the same dramatic weight as saving civilisation from the dreaded Nazi hordes.</p><p> Like all Spielberg's work, Always is full of dazzling cinematic coups and brilliantly executed contributions from masters like composer John Williams.</p><p> It is a charming, slightly goofy film which critics will probably carve up here as they did in the US.A pity, really. It is highly entertaining - a bit like a chocolate with a soft, gooey centre.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>A 'ghostly' Richard Dreyfuss, Holly Hunter and Brad Johnson.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4SJ7-2420-TXN5-S1P6-00000-00BE HAPPY2008-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisWEEKENDERPg. 10BE HAPPYFEATUREJODIE DUFFY

The happiest man in the world, Matthieu Ricard, says anyone can attain joy, peace and good health through meditation. JODIE DUFFY talks to the Dalai Lama's right-hand man.

What lights up your world?

Is it money, power, religion, relationships or maybe even chocolate? In the quest for happiness the mind is wired to gravitate to external sources.

But are we looking for bliss in all the wrong places? Yes, says the happiest man in the world, Matthieu Ricard.

Dr Ricard, a Tibetan monk who has a PHD in cellular genetics, has become something of a guru since the media bestowed on him the optimistic title.

Not that it really means anything to the Frenchman, who lives in a monastery in Nepal. "It's nice to be called that, than the most unhappiest man," he says. "But it doesn't make any sense scientifically, I mean how can you measure that."

Ricard certainly rubs shoulders with the world's most tranquil souls, the elite meditators of the world - sort of like the Olympic champions of the mind.

In recent years science has made inroads into proving that happiness is not just a vague feeling, but a physical state of the brain. Ricard, now 61, was the first volunteer in the initial study by US neuroscientists who hooked his skull up to 256 sensors and monitored him for three hours while he meditated, without moving a muscle, in an MRI machine. Scientists were stunned at the tremendous electrical activity in Ricard's left prefrontal-lobe. It was at a magnitude and intensity never seen before.

When the media began calling him the happiest man alive, Ricard was embarrassed to face his scientist friends. Still he says the fanciful title has allowed him to travel the world and spread the message about what he calls mind training or meditation with purpose. "Everyone has the capacity to be the happiest man in the world," Ricard says. "But they need to look for happiness in the right places."

Ricard is sitting in an auditorium at Darling Harbour looking out at a sea of 750 faces at the Happiness and it's Causes pre-conference workshop. As he unlocks the secrets to happiness three giant screens beam his image across the room.

It's at events like these that he can teach Westeners about the power of meditation and the good it can do for all of mankind.

Happiness according to Ricard is not intense pleasure or a burst of joy. Rather it's a way of being, found in qualities such as altruistic love, compassion, inner freedom, inner peace, contentment and the ability to deal with life as it happens.

Meditation he explains is a learned skill and not an oriental hobby or a relaxation technique. The very meaning of the word meditation in Tibet means to cultivate.

"It's our mind that translates outer conditions to happiness or suffering. But that changes when we train our mind."

The aim he believes is to raise our base line. "The base line is the platform you sit on when you're not experiencing the ups and downs of life. It's where you come back to after moments of joy and sadness."

While we all inherit traits to our personality, Ricard believes genes are just a blueprint which can change depending on our environment, education and childhood.

"The mind is plastic," he says. "We create 5000 new neurons, new connections and new functions in the brain every day and more if we're learning something new."

But it takes time to change the mind. Not that you need to spend years in quiet, reflective retreat, but the more meditation you do, the closer it brings you to fulfillment. Even 30 minutes a day for eight weeks can substantially improve health and well-being.

Meditation decreases stress by 26 per cent, can boost the immune system by 20 per cent and decreases our levels of anger and anxiety. A recent Canadian study also shows that those suffering high blood pressure can reduce it by 15 per cent through mind-training meditation.

Ricard considers the improvement to health a sideline; the real benefit for ourselves and society is in changing our minds. "When you train the mind, you change the quality of every moment of your life," he says.

The mind can be our best friend or our worst enemy. The goal Ricard explains is not to be a slave to our thoughts, but to stop one thought leading to 1000 thoughts. "One small spark of thought can suddenly give way to a forest fire of anger, jealousy or craving," he says. "Let the thought go, it's not that complicated."

He admits that meditation is not the "ultimate entertainment in life". "We don't do it for fun, but to preserve our inner peace and to be of service to others," he says.

Each meditation session should be dedicated to the benefit of all human beings with a final outpouring of loving kindness and compassion. "Don't let the universe be the mail order catalogue for your desires. Every member in society has a responsibility to have compassion in their heart."

While emotions like despair and hopelessness are to be avoided, sadness he says is unavoidable. "If you see a massacre and you're sad, what's wrong with that. It doesn't diminish your happiness. What it does is awake in you compassion and courage and it spurs you on to alleviate the suffering of others."

Ricard is involved in 30 humanitarian projects, including schools and health clinics in Tibet. "The more I wish to serve others, even in the face of a sad event, the more I'm in a state of happiness," he says.

His humanitarian works can be viewed on www.karuna-asia.org. He has also written a book, Happiness: A Guide to Developing Life's Most Important Skills.

When you feel overwhelmed by emotions

EXERCISE: Imagine a stormy sea with breakers as big as houses. Each wave is more monstrous than the last. They are about to engulf your boat, your very life hangs on those few extra yards in the rushing wall of water.

Then imagine observing the same scene from a high flying plane. From that perspective, the waves seem to form a delicate blue-and-white mosaic, barely trembling on the surface of the water. From that height in the silence of space, your eye sees these almost motionless patterns, and your mind immerses itself in clear and luminous sky.

The waves of anger or obsession seem real enough, but remind yourself that they are merely fabrications of your mind; that they will rise and also again disappear. Why stay on the boat of mental anxiety? Make your mind as vast as the sky and you will find that the waves of afflictive emotions have lost all the strength you had attributed to them.

From: Happiness - A Guide to Developing Life's Most Important Skill, By Matthieu Ricard

Three photos: Dr Ricard with apprentice monks at an elementary school in Nepal. Some will become monks at the age of 20, while others may have the chance to further their education. Dr Matthieu Ricard (above and right) says you can train your mind through meditation.

urn:contentItem:5564-5BY1-JD34-V274-00000-00THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC DUSTS OFF ITS OWN VERSION OF LIVES OF THE SAINTS1990-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 3THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC DUSTS OFF ITS OWN VERSION OF LIVES OF THE SAINTSSource: Associated Press

Saints, martyrs and spirits have been brought to life in China's campaign to teach its people to be good communists amid world communism's bad times.

The role model - selfless, hard-working, plain-living and loyal unto death- is a time-honoured educational tool in Communist China.

Now, as China's hard-line leaders seek absolute allegiance to a system where absolutes no longer exist, the party has again called on its paragons to lead the way.

Some, like perfect soldier Lei Feng, perennially return at times of ideological strife. Others, such as young martyr Lai Ning, are newcomers to the party pantheon.

Here are a few of the legends now in vogue:

* The peasant soldier Lei Feng. Nearly two decades after his death, Chinese today offer blood, sweep streets and give free haircuts in the name of Lei, who according to one song "walks 1,000 miles and does 1,000 good deeds".

According to legend, the fervent patriot secretly washed the clothes of his comrades, donated his savings to help peasants hit by floods and once gave his coat to a woman and her child during a freezing rainstorm.

Lei was killed in 1962 at the age of 22 when he backed his truck into a utility pole. A year later Mao Zedong proclaimed him a communist saint in the first of many Learn from Lei Feng campaigns.

* Fourteen-year-old Lai Ning. Described by the party's official People's Daily as "a flaming torch" of revolutionary spirit, young Lai died in 1988 while trying to put out a forest fire near his home in northern China.

Last October he headed a list of the nation's 10 best Young Pioneers, a party-led youth organisation. Among the revelations about Lai are that he hoped to be a geologist so he could excavate precious metals from mountains around his home and "contribute to our motherland."

"Study the hero Lai Ning" meetings are being held across the country. Beijing city has issued the book The Heroic Youth Lai Ning and organised Study Lai Ning detachments in schools.

* Model workers. Late last year 2,000 model workers were assembled at the Great Hall of the People for the first national ceremony in three decades to honour such exemplars of labour.

Others are hailed regularly in the official press, such as:

* "Sweeper Uncle" Jiang Daoping, a war hero who shot down seven enemy planes in the Korean War, took a job as a janitor after retiring from the military. His daughter was worried she wouldn't get a boyfriend with her father in such a lowly position. But Jiang reportedly replied: "It is no shame to do whatever I can for society. It will benefit both my body and soul."

* Policewoman "Flying Li" Songzhi, the 52-year-old chief of a task force that battles pickpockets, is quoted as saying: "Riding the bicycle at full speed, I can keep up with a bus when a thief is riding on it. In so doing, I feel that I have regained my youth."

* "Learn from Daqing." This common call during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution refers to the perseverance of those who built the nation's largest oilfield in the wastelands of north-east China.

Wang Tao, head of the China National Petroleum Corporation, pledged last year during ceremonies marking the 30th anniversary of the Daqing fields that he would initiate a massive campaign to revive the Daqing spirit.

* "The Spirit of Yanan." Yanan, in the dusty hills of northwest China, was Mao Zedong's base for 13 years during the 1930s and 1940s when the Red Army was fighting the Japanese and Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists.

Young Chinese are now told to emulate the spirit of those days, when Mao and the other communist leaders lived in caves and worked among the Yanan peasants.
