urn:contentItem:50W8-NFF1-JB17-5246-00000-00Carbon conundrum2006-04-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisCarbon conundrumLucy Andrew

Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas contributing to global warming — and the major source of carbon dioxide is fossil fuels, burnt by humans to meet our energy and transport needs. Each year about 27 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide are belched out into the atmosphere.

Lucky for us, not all the carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere stays there and contributes to global warming (if it did it would be known as global sweltering). Of our annual 27 billion tonnes carbon dioxide output;- 7 billion tonnes are absorbed by oceans; - 7 billion tonnes are taken up by forests, and; - 13 billion tonnes accumulate in the atmosphere each year.

However, there's a complication to this neat little equation — in the last two years, the accumulation of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has risen much faster than expected, from an average of 13 to 18 billion tonnes. Scientists attribute this increase to humans producing more carbon dioxide and, ironically, to global warming itself — as the Earth's temperature rises it decreases the ability of oceans and forests to take up carbon dioxide.

How big is a tonne of CO2 gas?

Tasmania is 68,401 km². If we spread Australia's yearly production of CO2 over the surface of Tasmania it would form a 3 metre high blanket across the island.

1 gram of CO2 = 556 ml (a bit less than the volume of a bottle of water)

1 tonne CO2 = 556,000 litres or 556 m3 (about the volume of a 3 bedroom house)

Each year Australia produces 542,600,000 tonnes of greenhouse gases, of which 70% (379,820,000 tonnes) is CO2.

The oceans ain't sinking like they used to!

Global warming could raise the sea levels by as much as six metres (20 feet) in the next generation and the earth could be heading for a mini ice-age. Image: Reuters As the planet warms, the ability of our oceans to dissolve atmospheric carbon dioxide will decrease because of three key factors — the increase in water temperature, slowing of the thermohaline current and the role of phytoplankton.

The increase in water temperature will affect the solubility capacity of the oceans because colder water absorbs more carbon dioxide. This is why most carbon dioxide absorption occurs in the icy waters of the poles in the North Atlantic and Southern Oceans. As ocean temperatures rise due to global warming there will simply be less room within our oceans to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

Global warming is also expected to apply the breaks to the thermohaline current (THC), a crucial global current that moves surface water to the ocean depths. The THC is created by cold and salty water sinking at the poles. This current drags carbon dioxide rich water deep into the ocean and brings carbon dioxide poor water to the surface where it can in turn, absorb more carbon dioxide. A slowing of this current will again result in less atmospheric carbon dioxide being removed by the oceans.

Figuring out phytoplankton

A crucial and uncertain piece in the puzzle is the role of phytoplankton. Phytoplankton are microscopic ocean plants that convert carbon dioxide to organic carbon. Fish eat the phytoplankton and the carbon is locked away from the atmosphere in the bodies of animals.

The effects of climate change on phytoplankton are not clear. On one hand more carbon dioxide may stimulate photosynthesis and encourage more phytoplankton to grow. On the other, a warmer ocean surface is thought to prevent the mixing of nutrients in the upper layer and prevent phytoplankton from flourishing.

On the whole, it's not good news. Climate models that take into account changes in water temperature, the THC and phytoplankton activity predict 14% less carbon dioxide will be absorbed by oceans by 2100.

Forest — our lungs and our sink!

Forests are often referred to as the lungs of the Earth, providing oxygen for the rest of the planet — but they are also a massive carbon sink. Plants consume carbon dioxide during photosynthesis and produce oxygen as a by-product. Plants also produce carbon dioxide during respiration, but on the whole growing plants perform more photosynthesis than respiration, leading to an overall consumption of carbon dioxide.

Carbon tied up in forests is released back into the atmosphere as carbon dioxide when soil bacteria and fungi decompose plant matter on the forest floor or when plants burn in forest fire. The highest recorded level of carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere was over 23 billion tonnes in 1998, attributed to widespread forest fires in Indonesia.

A story of many factors

Elevated carbon dioxide levels and rising temperatures have complicated effects on forests. Plants use carbon dioxide to photosynthesise and grow so it's not surprising that greater concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide stimulates plant growth. However, not all plants respond to higher carbon dioxide in the same way, with some plants growing faster than others. Research in the Amazon rainforest has shown that the forest composition changed when trees were exposed to more carbon dioxide.

Until recently, it was assumed that forests would acts as carbon sinks; absorbing carbon dioxide pumped into the atmosphere by human activity. But a recent study showed that forests in northeast Queensland became so stressed during two dry years that they changed the way they cycled carbon. In the first dry year, they produced as much carbon dioxide as absorbed or remained carbon neutral. In the second dry year they produced a surplus of carbon dioxide. It seems that climate change may stress some forests and turn them into carbon dioxide producers.

This unexpected turnaround from carbon sink to carbon producer is because lower rainfall and increased evaporation cause photosynthesis to slow down, resulting in nett carbon dioxide production - from plant decomposition and respiration.

The effect is thought to be short-term and the forest is expected to once again become a carbon sink with a return to wetter conditions. But Australia's long-term weather forecast is for drier conditions and the role of forests as carbon absorbers may not be as reliable as the planet continues to warm.

Tangled loops

The effect of atmospheric carbon dioxide on carbon dioxide uptake systems is just one of the many feedback loops in the tangled mess of climate change. It seems the more we learn about global warming and climate change, the worse the prognosis.

urn:contentItem:4DK8-XMT0-015H-01NP-00000-00<published>2004-10-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Footbridge still on track across creek</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Mary Vernon</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IT'S hard to get a straight answer about exactly when, but everyone seems to agree that it's going to happen -- that is the footbridge across Ross Creek between Flinders St East and Palmer St. When it was first proposed by the CBD Task Force some years ago, it was to run to the Motor Boat Club site, and the club was to vacate to other premises. Well that's not going to happen now as the club is to stay and is redeveloping the site, but the footbridge is still expected to proceed. A major effect is, of course, to shut down the ferry terminal at Flinders St East which is a shame. The city is greatly improved by the ferries buzzing up and down. But it's all a question of when, not if, so we're unlikely to get any say in it.</p><p nitf:lede="true">ACCORDING to Sunferries manager Mick Reilly there's a possibility that the city terminal might be shut down even before the footbridge makes it necessary in order to keep costs down -- it's just one-cost saving measure he's considering.</p><p>AN institution in the twin cities, Chris, the Town Cobbler in the Cat & Fiddle arcade, is reeling under the rumours that he has retired, which he definitely has not. Apparently another shoe mender in Charters Towers Rd has packed up his last and tacked off into the sunset, but Chris is still going strong and plans to be doing so for some time to come.</p><p>IN response to the picture (About Town 12/10) of the turf shoes, Beryl Kelly of Garbutt writes: "Going back to the Second World War picking pineapples in Redland Bay for the Hargreaves fruit factory, shoes were scarce and we tried to save the ones we had. I remember one woman who had long feet was finding it difficult to find shoes and she had very sore feet. Lo and behold she got two large herrings-in-tomato-sauce tins. She padded them and tied them on her feet. She was comfortable after she got used to them and no more sore feet. I can't remember the brand of the herrings, but I thank the manufacturers on her behalf."</p><p>ON the matter of the mall re-opening to traffic, one reader asks why there has been no survey done among shoppers -- those who shop there now, and those who shop in other shopping centres. She believes that this would be the quickest and most effective way of finding out what should be done and she has a point. It is, after all, the shoppers who will determine the mall's success or otherwise.</p><p>GLOBETROTTING PR whiz Marcia Marseney, who's working in Manila at the moment, reports that journalists in the Philippines are being murdered at the drop of a hat and authorities are doing nothing about it. In the two weeks between July 31 and August 12, four journalists were murdered, bringing to 55 the number killed since 1986. But police say it's the journalists' own fault and that's why they can't manage to arrest anyone.</p><p>COUNCILLOR Jack Wilson has always been well known as an entertainer, but we seldom see him in the role of clown -- but that's what he was doing, hamming it up for the babies at the baby welcoming ceremony. Don't think that's a legitimate use for a traffic cone, however.</p><p>Win a deluxe Cup lunch at Winston's on the Water</p><p>ALL you have to do is write a sentence, or a story in which the words begin with consecutive letters of the alphabet in the A to Z direction. You don't have to use all the letters of the alphabet, and you can start anywhere you like but you can only use each letter once and in the right order.</p><p>So if, for instance, you start with K, you can carry on through Z and back through A until you get to J.</p><p>We've got two double tickets to give away to the fabulous lunch on Melbourne Cup day at Winston's on the Water in Ogden St and the competition is hotting up. Consider this one, from Michelle Woodward:</p><p>Cup Day Expectations: Fun-loving Girls Happily Intoxicated, Jovial Karaoke, Laughing Merrily, Nervous Over Premium Quality Race, Surprisingly Triumphant, Unexpected Victory, Waiters X-posing Y-fronts, Zealous And Bold.</p><p>Or, how about this little gem from Lorraine Philippo:</p><p>Xavier Youngblood Zoomed Around Buses, Cars, Dawdling Elderly Females -- Grinning Hoonishly, Insolently Jumping Kerbs, Looking Mean. Numerous Other Pensioners Querulously Responded, Sabotaging The Unique V-8 Wheelchair.</p><p>And here's a beauty from Nararsha Rehder:</p><p>Another Brilliant Celebratory Day Embraces Flemington. Grand Horses, Intense Jockeys, Keen Ladies, Manic Nerves, Optimistic Punters Queue Restlessly -- So Tuesday Unfolds Verily With X-citement, Yearning, Zeal . . .</p><p> So give it a go, and you could be dining in style at Winston's on Cup day, watching the race on the big screen and vying for the prizes.</p><p>Send send your entries to Winston's, PO Box 2030, Townsville, by e-mail to the above address, or enter on our website at <url normalizedValue="http://www.townsville">www.townsville</url> bulletin.com.au.</p><p>A PHOTOGRAPHER for a national magazine was assigned to take pictures of a great forest fire. He was advised that a small plane would be waiting to fly him over the fire. The photographer arrived at the airport just an hour before sundown. Sure enough, a small Cessna was waiting. He jumped in with his equipment and shouted, "Let's go!" The tense man sitting in the pilot's seat swung the plane into the wind and soon they were in the air, though flying erratically. "Fly over the north side of the fire," said the photographer, "And make several low-level passes." "Why?" asked the nervous pilot. "Because I'm going to take pictures," yelled the photographer. "I'm a photographer, and photographers take pictures." The pilot replied, "You mean you're not the flight instructor?"</p><p>Properly organised, even crime pays</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4J62-4510-TX5J-8252-00000-00Noble view of Man in Black2006-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 23

MATP

Noble view of Man in BlackEvan Williams

Walk the Line (M)

* * * 1/2

National release

North Country (MA15+)

* * *

National release

ONCE it was normal for actors playing singers and pop stars in films to have their voices dubbed for the singing bits. But today no self-respecting Hollywood star would dream of using a dubbed voice. It would suggest there were limits to their brilliance and versatility.

The makers of Walk the Line are therefore at pains to point out that Joaquin Phoenix and Reese Witherspoon do their own singing in the concert sequences. And they do it well. Phoenix has a deep, rasping bass that goes well with his impersonation of Johnny Cash, and Witherspoon as his wife June Carter can hold a tune quite nicely. As with Nicole Kidman in Moulin Rouge, one is surprised to discover they can sing at all.

I was never a huge Cash fan. The songs I liked were the obvious ones: Ring of Fire, I Walk the Line, both duly performed in James Mangold's big, moody biopic, along with a dozen or so others. The difficulty with musical biopics is that they can quickly become an excuse for a string of concert numbers. This is especially true if the subjects aren't already familiar from their movies as, say, Bing Crosby, Elvis Presley or Dean Martin were. Cash recorded five songs for the soundtrack of I Walk the Line, a romantic drama from 1970, but I can't remember a film in which he appeared as himself. I Walk the Line wasn't the Johnny Cash story. That story -- about a boy from a sharecropping family who grew up in the Depression and became the first superstar of country music -- is told in Mangold's film.

Well, actually, it's not. Many a lurid and discreditable episode in Cash's drug-fuelled career has been omitted from the film. Mangold and co-writer Gill Dennis based their screenplay on two books -- Man in Black and Cash: The Autobiography -- that may well give a franker picture of the man. There's nothing in the film about Cash starting a forest fire when high on amphetamines. He was also famous for smashing up hotel rooms and fabricating a story that he was one-quarter Cherokee. In the 1950s, while serving in the US Army in Germany, his hearing was damaged when a German girl playfully stuck a pencil in his left ear, and the scar on his cheek, far from being a knife wound, was the result of a cyst being removed by a drunken doctor.

Such trivia has no place in a film largely concerned with an overblown account of Cash's marital affairs. This is a film about a great show-biz romance, or so we are meant to regard it, and all stops are out. Cash married Vivian Liberto after his discharge from the army. But his great love was Carter, from seminal country music group the Carter Family, who had been married to one of Cash's drinking buddies, country singer Carl Smith.

After a long and turbulent affair with Cash, she married and divorced a stock-car driver before accepting an onstage proposal from Cash during a concert in 1968. In the film this charming episode gives their bumpy relationship a wholesome and sentimental climax, and only a sourpuss would fail to be touched. (It wasn't the last time Cash went public with his private life. In 1997, during a late renaissance in his career, he announced during a concert that he had Parkinson's disease, and was hospitalised soon after with double pneumonia. None of this is in Mangold's film, either.)

The performances are fine. Phoenix has a muscular, craggy sexiness that goes well with the impression left by Cash's music. He can convey a sense of honest bewilderment and inner soulfulness, and he and Witherspoon make a splendid team. I don't think I've seen Witherspoon in a part that demands so much down-to-earth acting, as distinct from the ironic roles and quirky comic personalities she has specialised in. The trademark bounciness and exuberance are there, but she's good enough to give the corniest lines a ring of conviction: ''You're not nothin'. God has given you a second chance to make things right.''

Country music is largely about that sort of thing: second chances, misunderstandings, emotional dilemmas, the outpourings of troubled souls. When Vivian (Ginnifer Goodwin) tells June to ''stay clear of my children'', it's exactly the sort of fraught relationship the country singer dealt with. One reason the film rings true is that it seems like a dramatisation of Cash's lyrics. There is much raw, authentic emotion in Walk the Line, and it ensures that what might have been a maudlin and phony film becomes, in its best moments, one of genuine power and truthfulness.

GGG

I WISH I could say as much for North Country, a worthy and well-intentioned drama from New Zealand director Niki Caro, who had a well-deserved success with Whale Rider. Her new film is another story about woman's invincibility in the face of traditional prejudice, inspired (dread word) by a landmark US court case in the 1980s. The events depicted, though passed off as real, are fictional. And with the film-makers enjoying unlimited scope for exaggeration, the result is a film more notable for righteous hysteria than social realism.

Charlize Theron plays Josey Aimes, a working-class single mother who walks out on her abusive husband and takes a job as a coalminer to support her two children. Her presence at the mine is bitterly resented by the men, who see women as a threat to their jobs and subject Josey and her few female workmates to a vicious campaign of intimidation: slogans daubed on lavatory walls, Portaloos upended with their female occupants in them, obscene objects planted in lunch boxes. Josey is finally persuaded to sue the mining company with the aid of a sympathetic lawyer (Woody Harrelson), who is drawn to the prospect of fighting the nation's first class action for sexual harassment.

It is hard to fault Theron's performance: she brings a measured dignity and restraint missing from the film as a whole. There is fine support from Frances McDormand (who really does look like a working-class battler), and Sissy Spacek (this time playing the coalminer's mum). Best of all is Richard Jenkins as Josey's father, a miner who begins by disapproving of her behaviour before rallying to her side.

The courtroom sequences that punctuate the story bear comparison with The Verdict. But the film feels strident and overdone.

urn:contentItem:5D2P-9DR1-JD3N-54V8-00000-00OUT OF THE CAGE2014-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 12OUT OF THE CAGEMICHAEL DUNAWAY

David Gordon Green's film Joe extracts excellent value from the thespian depths of Nicolas Cage, writes Michael Dunaway

'IT'S great," muses David Gordon Green, the director of the Joe, starring Tye Sheridan and an impressively bearded Nicolas Cage, "when you can have actors who can find within them depths of reality, and things that can really trigger something in audiences. I mean, that's why we go to movies, to see people like these guys that really invite us into their lives, to experience characters through their eyes. That's the most rewarding part of a movie like this, getting in the ring with actors like Nic and Tye, and taking a story that I have a great history with and bringing it to life." Cage, of course, has had one of the most fascinating, and at times beguiling, careers of any actor of his time. Growing up Hollywood royalty as part of the Coppola family, he dazzled early in films such as Rumble Fish and Birdy, then had a truly stunning three-year run in 1986-87 with romantic leads in Peggy Sue Got Married, Raising Arizona and Moonstruck. All that was before he turned 24. Eight years later, he won the Academy Award for best actor for 1995's Leaving Las Vegas.

And that's when things got a little weird. The past nearly two decades of Cage's career have been wildly polarising. He's became one of the biggest action stars in the world, much to the chagrin of many fans who think he has sold out and abandoned his thespian roots. He's also appeared in some real stinkers. Big-budget stinkers, which are the hardest to forgive, it seems.

It was always a somewhat false duality. Cage turned in excellent performances in films such as John Woo's 1997 Face/Off, Martin Scorsese's 1999 Bringing Out the Dead, Spike Jonze's 2002 Adaptation and Werner Herzog's 2009 The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans. But for many moviegoers Cage had become the hack who cashed a big cheque for a National Treasure or Ghost Rider film once or twice a year.

For a while there, Green had been accused of turning his back on sensitive indie drama himself. Still, he can be forgiven for not immediately thinking of Cage when he imagined the title part in Joe. "Whenever I'm reading a book," the director says, "I'm thinking about the movie. I've been that way since I was a little kid. My first thought, reading the Larry Brown book long ago, was: "This is Robert Mitchum." Somebody who really has this sense of wit but masculinity, and dramatic ability. But when I started thinking about the reality of putting this project together, Nic is the only guy who carries those with gusto. Who has the Oscars to prove it, has the bad-assed action movies to prove it and has the hilarious comedies that I can quote to you all day to prove it. So I really wanted that kind of complicated texture.

"And I really wanted to bring Larry out," he continues. "There is a resemblance. If you look at images of Larry, when Nic grows the beard out, there's definitely a very vivid resemblance. And when I started imagining that, I couldn't get it out of my mind." As for Cage, he gives a "Who, me?" kind of shrug and passes the credit. "The great news was," he says, "when I read the script, I knew right away that this was something where I wouldn't have to act too much. That I could bring whatever my life experiences were from the last couple of years into the role. And it's interesting, when the movie premiered and my wife saw it, she said, 'Well, that's you.' " Cage could be accused of being just a bit disingenuous here. It's never quite as simple as "just being yourself" on camera. First of all, it's damned hard to be yourself in such an artificial environment - in a situation that's not your real life, speaking words not your own, with cameras and bright lights and cameras trained on you and dozens of people watching. (And knowing that millions will be watching later.) And second, what feels "just being yourself" to an actor doesn't always translate to audiences as character information onscreen.

Still, there's certainly a truth at the heart of his point about the script, adapted from a novel by Brown, possibly the great American southern novelist. When he wants to be, Green is a truly brilliant director, and he can be brilliant at extracting very naturalistic performances from his actors. Despite his reputation for over-the-top performances in recent years, Cage treasures that sort of role. "One of the things about working with David," he says, "is that he will interview his actors. He'll invite little stories you may recall from your own life. And he'll put those in the film, so that you get that feeling of spontaneity, that feeling of real life, of that actually happening, instead of something being acted out. Little memories, little bits and pieces of dialogue, little thoughts or experiences that actors can put into their performances so that you don't have to act so much." The project has deep, longstanding roots in Green's life. In college his film professor, Gary Hawkins, turned him on to Brown's novels, mostly set in Mississippi and all tough, gritty, gripping stories with unforgettable characters, many of them men struggling with images of masculinity. Green was transfixed. He went on to begin his career with critically lauded indie classics like George Washington and All the Real Girls before returning to work on Hawkins' 2002 award-winning documentary about the author, The Rough South of Larry Brown.

When Brown died suddenly in 2004 from an apparent heart attack, Hawkins decided to adapt his novel Joe as a screenplay, thinking it was at once Brown's most personal work, the work that Hawkins himself most responded to, and the most cinematic of the novels. He couldn't get any interest from the industry. Nine years later, he was having an idle conversation with Green, who had since parlayed his critical acclaim into big-budget Hollywood films (Pineapple Express, The Sitter) and legendary television comedy status (Eastbound & Down). Green asked his old professor if he had anything he should read and received, in return, the script for Joe.

"When I read the script," Green remembers, "it struck me as a great contemporary western, a genre I've always been drawn to and that I love. It's a story very distant from me, but it's something that really resonated with me. I felt really familiar with this world, even though I can't quite say I grew up in the squalor of Tye's character, and I can't quite say I'm as bad-assed and masculine as Nic's character. But they're people I look up to, and I wonder about. Even the horrific characters, or some of the quirkier characters, are people I feel like, in my strange life, I've met along the way. And I love to explore, and take a few steps in their shoes." Green had a few tricks up his sleeve to ground the film in the world in which it's set. "I remember when Nic came to town," he recalls. "We were talking about how to flesh out the cast. I really wanted it to have a raw authenticity and not a Hollywood polish. We were going to make sure these characters felt like they were of a real world, and that we were dropping in on guys who knew how to do this labour, and how to do these voices of either poetry or horror, depending on who we were looking at. We cast it, outside of Nic, with all Texans. It was all shot in and around Austin, and we'd go downtown in the morning and there'd be a construction foreman looking for guys for the job, and some people with landscaping needs looking for someone for their job, and then there we were looking for some people for our job." But filling one specific part was a nagging challenge, says Green: "I wanted somebody who felt sad, in a way, and had a depth and darkness behind his eyes rather than a guy who was going to just roll up his sleeves and chew up a "bad guy" role. I auditioned some incredible actors â€¦ for the part "[Casting directors] John Williams and Karmen Leech met Gary Poulter at a bus stop downtown â€¦ He had actually just come back from his father's funeral. He'd been living on the streets downtown for quite a while and had had some hardships. But he had some amazing stories to tell, and a wonderful charisma, and a positive ambition to bring to the table â€¦ It was amazing to work with him and introduce him to Cage. I introduced them at breakfast one morning, and they hit it off. Then I introduced him to Tye, and they hit it off, and we just had a wonderful time working with this guy.'

A LOT of A-list stars might have baulked at sharing significant screen time with a homeless man with no previous film experience. Not Cage. "The thing is, Gary Poulter had a work ethic," he raves. "He had the Vincent Price monologue from [Alice Cooper's TheBlack Widow] down. He would perform it. All the time. At the drop of a hat. It was outstanding. I mean he was a real, trained street performer. So when I was ready to work, he was ready to work. And vice versa. It didn't feel that much different from working with someone out of Julliard." Cage did his best to give Poulter a vision of the change he was in the process of making in his life. "I said to Gary, 'Just keep it together for one year'," he says, emotionally. "One year, and your life is going to change dramatically. You're going to be getting all kinds of phone calls and you're going to be making all kinds of movies." About two months after the end of filming, Poulter's lifeless body was found in 1m of water in Lady Bird Lake in Austin. It's a loss that no one in the production can speak of without obviously raw emotion. "It's sad," Cage says, shaking his head helplessly.

DURING the time Joe was being filmed, Green kept the set loose, as is his wont. "I like working with David," says Sheridan, "because he incorporates a sense of realness and honesty into his films. He's very spontaneous." "Regardless of the darkness or dramatic nature of the film," Green explains, "I always cast people with a sense of humour. It's about inviting a little bit of absurdity and humanness into the process. It's about remembering that no matter who we are, or what sort of pedestal or what glamorous lighting we're under, we're all eating boogers, man." Green was glad to have secured Sheridan at this moment in his career. He dazzled audiences in two of the best films of the past two years, 2012's The Tree of Life and 2013's Mud, directed by fellow Texans Terrence Malick and Jeff Nichols. But he hasn't quite reached that Di-Caprio level of teen celebrity. "You sometimes get a little self-consciousness in actors," Green says, "especially young actors that are starting to see themselves in ads and interviews and thinking, 'Oh man, I'm cool as shit!' " "I like to work with young people," Cage says, "because young people haven't had their dreams kicked out of them yet. They're full of confidence and imagination and vision. And when they score, that all gets empowered. And Tye was a great example of that."

JOE seems much more of a piece with Green's Prince Avalanche than with any of his other recent work. The connection isn't lost on him. "I think there is a spiritual connection between the two, in a way," he says. "There's something about Mother Nature's efforts and the catastrophic nature of a forest fire, and then there's something very intimately peculiar about a man who takes a hatchet with poison and takes out a tree. As much as a lot of my films have been about strange conflicts of masculinity, I think there's also always been a template of backdrop. I'm always interested in where we are. Who are these people, in this place, in this time?" The concern with images of masculinity in Brown's writing and Green's filmmaking is an element that resounds strongly with Cage. He even contributed one of the film's most memorable conversations to the script. "About 2000 years ago," he explains, "I had put a script together called Heartbreaker, Incorporated, which never got made. In that script, I put a line in there, but I never found a place for it to work. And I thought that maybe with Joe it could work. I don't know how it came to me. I think I was looking at old commercials of the Marlboro Man. It was always this guy who was kind of squinting and kind of smiling. And I was like, 'You look like you're in pain, but you're smiling. Is that the icon of cool? Is that what it means to be cool?' I did the math - OK, make a face of pain, now smile, yeah, that's cool. So I thought I'd put that concept into this movie." Still, if there's a good many pieces of Joe in Cage, the actor is keenly aware of the differ-ences. Asked in a press conference whether he's ever had to do backbreaking work like Joe does in the film, he says, "I used to sell popcorn at the Fairfax Movie Theatre in Los Angeles; that was my first job. And I took the tickets, too. I was also the usher. And I was trying to figure how I could get from there to being on the screen. One day a guy was smoking during the movie, and my boss told me I had to go tell him to put it out. And I went up to the guy and said, 'I'm sorry, sir, you're going to have to put your cigarette out.' And he looked at me, and took one big puff, and he just blew all the smoke in my face. And I quit.

"That was the most backbreaking work I've ever done," he adds. The room erupts in loud laughter. Nic Cage, A-lister, action star and thespian, can still bring the house down.

Paste, April 2014Joe is screening at Melbourne's Australian Centre for the Moving Image until September 16.

urn:contentItem:4RNJ-NS30-TXN5-S05R-00000-00Somewhere over the Rainbow2008-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisMETROPg. 4Somewhere over the RainbowcoverBernard Zuel

Rufus Wainwright has moved beyond the ruby-slippered legend and is turning to opera. Bernard Zuel reports.

AMERICAN singer-songwriter Rufus Wainwright spent a lot of last year being Judy Garland. As you do. Or at least replicating her famous Carnegie Hall concert from 1961, song by song, emotion by emotion - though not exactly costume by costume, even if oneÂ or two outfits came close.

We didn't get to see the show here - only London and New York did - and when Wainwright plays in Sydney it will be with a band but without Garland. Still, the shows left their mark on him.

"Honestly, the next big thing for me is the opera, because that's been my lifelong ambition and fascination," Wainwright says. "That is taking up all the mental space. And there's a large mental space there now that Judy's gone. She really carved out a cathedral that you have to replace with something."

Wainwright's ability to be both arch and romantic, to build songs with an emotional landscape as complex and challenging as his dramatic pop melodies, has had him singled out as a rare, if inconsistent, talent since his 1998 eponymous debut album. Sometimes even he believes his songs could get on the radio and sell a lot, though the jury is still out. Possibly because even when there's only his languid voice and piano, his songs feel like mini-operas and Broadway musicals channelled through pop.

Still, when he plays with a band he both rocks out and camps up, a highly entertaining combination - something that Sydney audiences can expect. Was the Rufus-does-Judy show another of his life's goalsÂ ticked off?

"I wouldn't even say it was a life goal, it was almost like ... I don't mean to say this and be disrespectful but it was almost like her life's goal. Meaning that I had this funny little idea, in the car listening to the album ... Somehow that spark ignited this forest fire and, next thing you know, it's happening and I really do feel like there was a sort of cosmic bubble that I punctured and all of this seething need to live - whether it was her, all the songs or the songwriters I don't know - but it happened and I went along with it. I loved every moment of it. I love Judy and I love the songs but there was a sort of nether force guiding that whole project."

Gee, after his most recent album, his fifth, Release The Stars - which started as an intimate album for not much more than voice and piano and ended up with orchestra, massed voices and big, big songs - who would have thought that a small idea of his would blow up into something almost excessive?

Wainwright chuckles in recognition. "Yes, that's never happened before."

The opera, commissioned by the New York Metropolitan Opera, has been on the horizon for several years now for the passionate operatic fan. The first act is mostly written, next he has "the meat" - the orchestration - which he estimates will take him a year and test him like nothing he has done before.

"And you know, honestly, with the amount of respect I have for composers who have gone before me, I'm not going to even scratch the surface of what's possible, or of what's been done, with my first opera. It's a tall, tall mountain."

Is there a libretto yet? "I'm working on it [at] the moment with a friend. We're doing it in French. English is lovely in so many ways, except opera," he deadpans.

Can we look forward to a death in the first act? A suicide in the third? "There's no death. It's more of a Strauss-ian, late Strauss-ian situation within the drama. It's a very drawing-room sensibility."

Intense but contained? "Yes, intense but contained and the harrowing drama, the harrowing situations of real life."

Speaking of harrowing situations of real life, the end of each year usually means a McGarrigle/Wainwright family show, bringing together the offspring of the McGarrigle sisters Anna and Kate (mother to Rufus and Martha, his febrile and talented sister), Loudon Wainwright III (father to Rufus, Martha and a few more from a second marriage) and sundry relatives.

Given the family's propensity for writing about each other in their songs, up to and including Martha's song about her father, Bloody Motherf---ing Asshole, yet still remaining amazingly close, it's always a psychosocial treat to witness it. But there wasn't one in December. And it wasn't just because of Kate McGarrigle's health battle, which at one stage had looked life-threatening.

"Frankly, the problem [last] year was that I had this two-month monster tour of Europe that I only got off of a few days before [the Christmas show would have been held] and I absolutely refused to go into another production, especially Christmas. I love Christmas but I also love to enjoy it," he laughs.

Is his mother better? "She's doing great. She is fierce - a warrior woman, as we all know. She's got that sort of potato famine without the potato face."

Does he see that in himself? "I was on my website the other day ... and in there was this picture where she and I were facing the same direction, the angles of our faces were in a similar spot and we both have the same eyes. I am blessed for it because they are very, very strong. And I don't mean beautiful, they are beautiful but there is a kind of resilience there."

It must give him some confidence that whatever other adversities come up, beyond a crystal meth addiction and a generally indulgent life, he probably has the strength to fight back.

"Yes, I'm eternally indebted to both of my parents for really being so strong that perhaps it ruined their relationship but in time created Martha and I, who are pretty tough cookies," he says, jokingly adding, "If anything it's an argument for procreation and then divorce."

Would he consider the procreation part? "Ah, well, my boyfriend loves children and we've been together for almost three years, so I'm sure the question will pop up at some point. I personally don't, only because I think children are faking it [he laughs]. I think they're as intelligent and as literate and as aware as adults are and when they're acting like children, they are pretending."

That may have been true of the young Wainwright but I don't think we can all claim such precociousness.

"I know, I'm a bit hard. My bark is much bigger than my bite; I'd make a great father."

It's not something he would rule out? "It's not something that has ever really attracted me but I don't know, I think that that can turn on a dime. Everyone thinks only women go through this but I think men go through it as well; you suddenly start to feel the need to continue your line. To be around youth and to impart your wisdom becomes quite primordial. We'll see."

RUFUS WAINWRIGHT

Tuesday and Wednesday, 7pm,

State Theatre, 136 100, $79.90.

TWO PHOTOS: The Ruf, the Ruf, the Ruf is on fire ... Rufus Wainwright is bringing his powerful show to Sydney. Martina Wainwright

urn:contentItem:55SR-SRT1-JD3N-52B5-00000-00Quick bites - Free to air -2012-06-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 28Quick bites - Free to air -IAN CUTHBERTSON

Dino Gangs

Sunday, 7.30pm, SBS One

Yet another excursion into natural history, Dino Gangs is a low flame compared with the forest fire of our pick of the week, above. In this outing, Canadian palaeontologist Phil Currie is out to prove his radical theory based on evidence discovered in a remote corner of Mongolia. Would that be outer Outer Mongolia then? There the remains of 90 Tarbosaurus dinosaurs -- the Chinese T. rex -- lie together, a great herd of dead beasties. Currie believes many of them were part of a single social group and that they may have hunted in packs. Of course, as various scientific nay-sayers quoted are quick to point out, the tiny reptilian brains possessed by these mammoth creatures were unlikely to have possessed the wherewithal to manage pack hunting, thought to have developed first among mammals. And they may have been heading for the hills in terror when that asteroid struck. Currie's case is not well supported by hokey CGI footage from other sources, such as old films and documentaries, which at times is completely at odds with the narration. Certain to be popular with kids staging plasticine dinosaur battles of their own in front of the television.

We Were Here

Sunday, 8.30pm, ABC2

Though this documentary was made last year, its focus is the AIDS crisis in San Francisco in the 1980s. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden declared it one of the top 10 films of that year. ``Of all the cinematic explorations of the AIDS crisis, not one is more heartbreaking and inspiring than this,'' he wrote. The focus is on five individuals who were all living in San Francisco when the crisis hit. From vantage points such as those of caregiver, researcher and activist, as well as friends and lovers of the afflicted, each has an illuminating tale that is deeply personal but also speaks of the unified reaction of a community under siege. Perhaps most moving is the relatively unknown role that lesbians, not a group gay men generally made much space for, played in the hands-on care of their gay brothers. Because of the peculiarities of transmission, lesbians apparently were the safest possible group available for blood donations. They gave in buckets. Some of the social horrors, such as ostracisation, and the bleak condemnation of sufferers by the religious Right -- particularly from Southern Baptist pastor Jerry Falwell and political adviser Pat Buchanan -- are dealt with, but the focus is on the way a community, from the local florist to the nurses and doctors in AIDS wards, came together to support each other in an unprecedented way.

2 One Another

Sunday, 10.05pm, ABC2

Review editor and dance critic Deborah Jones recently wrote of this production, created and directed by Rafael Bonachela for the Sydney Dance Company, that it was all packaging and no pay-off. ``It is like a gorgeous gift box, big, shiny and promising great delights. Take off the lid and search through the artfully crumpled tissue paper, however, and one comes up empty-handed,'' Jones wrote. Here is your chance to see the whole thing for yourself and perhaps disagree. There is a quite lengthy introduction from Bonachela in which the choreographer explains what the work means to him and what he wanted it to represent. Then it's over to the Sydney Theatre to watch the whole show, filmed live during a single performance. Viewers need not fear that a camera has been turned on at the back of the theatre and left to run. Overhead angles and constantly shifting close and wide shots from left, right and centre compensate for the absence of the third dimension seen only in the theatre. Sound and lighting effects are also beautifully presented.

Revenge

Monday, 8.30pm, Seven

So now we know it was Tyler who was murdered on that beach. Unfortunately we still don't know who pulled the trigger. That makes Daniel, Jack and Amanda possible suspects. To cloud things further, Daniel, found nearby with a nasty head wound and no reliable memory of what occurred, is suspicious of Emily, who was canny enough to remove evidence from beneath her floorboards. Further flashbacks reveal how it was that patriarch Conrad Grayson got mixed up in terrorist activity in the first place. No matter how hard Conrad and Victoria try to escape their past they seem destined to repeat it. Poor things. And what of Charlotte? She has to deal with the fact David Clarke, the man who carried the can for Conrad and Victoria, is her father; she is reeling from the murder and the brutal investigation, and her weaselly little boyfriend, Jack's brother Declan, is up to his neck in it. Just wait until she finds out that show protagonist Emily Thorne is her half-sister.

Bikie Wars: Brothers in Arms

Tuesday, 8.30pm, Ten

If you haven't yet caught up with Bikie Wars, brought to you on Ten by the same people who made the various series of Underbelly for Nine, the program concerns itself with the notorious Milperra Massacre, which occurred in a quiet suburban Sydney on Father's Day, September 2, 1984. In tonight's fourth episode of six, Jock Ross (Matthew Nable), supreme leader of the Comancheros, has a spot of road trouble: he is wilfully knocked off his bike by a flatbed truck in a spectacular sequence that will have you on the edge of your seat. It may be to do with his recent splitting of the club and the formation of a separate branch. Susie Porter, so fine as Jock's wife Vanessa, is a master of the, shall we say, bogan Australian female accent. Jock's Scottish accent, however, is on the level of those gentlemen we all know from the pub who think they can do a Scottish accent but actually can't. A small quibble, though, about an otherwise fine performance. As in Underbelly, gritty action sequences alternate with earthy dialogue, sex and violence are authentically and graphically depicted, and the characters are deeply flawed criminal types yet with considerable charisma. A handy catch-up montage at the beginning means willing newcomers should not find Bikie Wars: Brothers in Arms too difficult to wade into at this stage.

Indian Ocean with Simon Reeve

Wednesday, 8.30pm, SBS One

Now what, you may wonder, is Seven presenter Simon Reeve doing messing about the Indian Ocean for SBS? Aha, fooled again. This Simon Reeve is very British indeed. But now we've got that straightened out, this program is absolutely gorgeous. Reeve is travelling through 16 countries on the edge of the Indian Ocean, a water mass that stretches 10,000km from Africa to Australia. Steeped in history, the Indian Ocean is vital to world trade. But it's not all pretty stuff for the cameras. Reeve investigates pirate-infested seas and war-torn lands along the way. The journey begins at the tip of Africa and then travels up the coast through Mozambique and Tanzania to the island of Zanzibar. On the first leg in Africa tonight, Reeve travels by land, sea and air through countries ravaged by war. Then, there is great peace as he explores the coral beaches of Zanzibar. As he sets off from the Cape of Good Hope, the sea churns with life and the coastline is dramatic. A delicious portent for all that lies ahead.

Offspring

Wednesday, 8.30pm, Ten

The first rule of television is never to resolve the sexual tension between characters. Domestic bliss apparently puts everyone to sleep. Another way to resolve it is to move the characters past it and on to someone else, which seems to have occurred since the last time I poked my nose into this particular doorway. As always, Asher Keddie is sensational as luckless obstetrician and lead character Nina Proudman. Her performance tonight, as a woman waking up with the hangover from hell after a night on the tiles with the girls, is beautifully played. Did she sleep with someone new? A great point of entry for latecomers.

The Story of Wales

Friday, 8.30pm, SBS One

I would wager that the extent of the knowledge of Wales possessed by most Australians is through their lovely friends Gwynedd and Dalwyn, and possibly through Daffyd, the only gay in the village, brought to these shores by Matt Lucas in the broad comedy of Little Britain. But Wales, it turns out, has a fascinating history, and a culture and identity all its own. Who better to take your hand and lead you through the streets of Cardiff than Welsh historian Huw Edwards? Tonight, pop in on episode two, Power Struggles, as Edwards recounts the building of a great frontier and Owain Glyndwr's struggle for independence. The Welsh ruler was the last native Welshman to hold the title prince of Wales. He instigated a fierce and long-running revolt against English rule.

----- PICK OF THE WEEK -----

How to Grow a Planet

Sunday, 7.30pm, ABC1

It seems that the stars of the greatest show on earth really are the plants. In this natural history program, presenter Iain Stewart demonstrates how plants changed our planet from a toxic uninhabitable mass to a blue ball in space teeming with life. In fact, if you'd been around a few billion years ago there was one supercontinent, Pangaea, surrounded by princely purple oceans. In a straightforward narrative, Stewart explains how plants first harnessed light from the sun and created the atmosphere. He uncovers an epic battle between the dinosaurs and the tallest trees. And, in controlled experiments, Stewart shows plants breathing and indisputably communicating with each other. It seems jungles may be alive with plant chatter that so far has eluded most of us. Next week, the planet-transforming power of flowers. Filled with useful knowledge and clear explanations of very complex historical events, this is the kind of series you'll be glad to have seen before you die.

Our TV Pick of the Day appears in The Australian's A Plus section Monday to Friday.

Review makes every effort to ensure programs and times are correct. However, it is not always possible to reflect late schedule changes.

Video previews and more television at theaustralian.com.au/arts/television

urn:contentItem:517X-3D81-F0JP-W1CR-00000-00The language of Italy2010-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisWEEKEND EXTRAPg. 66The language of ItalyAndy Toulson

Looking for a laugh but don't have time to open up the spam cluttering up your email? Let us do it for you. Spam junkie ANDY TOULSON is a serial

emailer and we've put her talents for recognising the ridiculous to good use. Each week she filters out the rubbish and presents the best of spam. Enjoy

The life of an Italian child

1. You have at least one relative who wore a black dress every day for an entire year after a funeral.

2. You spent your entire childhood thinking what you ate for lunch was pronounced `sangwich'.

3. Your family dog understood Italian.

4. Every Sunday afternoon of your childhood was spent visiting your grandparents and extended family.

5. You've experienced the phenomena of 150 people fitting into 50 square feet of yard during a family barbecue.

6. You were surprised to discover the FDA recommends you eat three meals a day, not seven.

7. You thought killing the pig each year and having salami, capacollo, pancetta and prosciutto hanging out to dry from your shed ceiling was absolutely normal.

8. You ate pasta for dinner at least three times a week, and every Sunday.

9. You grew up thinking no fruit or vegetable had a fixed price and that the price of everything was negotiable through haggling.

10. You were as tall as your grandmother by the age of seven.

11. You thought everyone's last name ended in a vowel.

12. You thought nylons were supposed to be worn rolled to the ankles.

13. Your mum's main hobby is cleaning.

14. You were surprised to find out that wine was actually sold in stores.

15. You thought that everyone made their own tomato sauce.

16. You never ate meat on Christmas Eve or any Friday.

17. You ate your salad after the main course.

18. You thought Catholic was the only religion in the world.

19. You were beaten at least once with a wooden spoon or broom.

20. You thought every meal had to be eaten with a hunk of bread in your hand.

21. You can understand Italian but you can't speak it.

22. You have at least one relative who came over on the boat.

23. All of your uncles fought in a World War.

24. You have at least six male relatives named Tony, Frank, Joe, Vince or Salvatore.

25. You have relatives who aren't really your relatives.

26. You have relatives you don't speak to.

27. You drank wine before you were a teenager.

28. You relate on some level to The Godfather and The Sopranos.

29. You grew up in a house with a yard where every patch of dirt had a flower or a vegetable growing out of it.

30. Your grandparents' furniture was as comfortable as sitting on plastic. Wait!!!! You were sitting on plastic.

31. You thought that talking loud was normal.

32. You thought sugared almonds and the Tarantella were common at all weddings.

33. You thought everyone got pinched on the cheeks and had money stuffed in their pockets by their relatives.

34. Your mother is overly protective of the males in the family no matter what their age.

35. Every condition, ailment, misfortune, memory loss and accident was attributed to the fact that you didn't eat something.

Sick leave

I urgently needed a few days off work, but I knew the boss would not allow me to take leave.

I thought that maybe if I acted a little crazy then he would tell me to take a few days off.

So I hung upside down on the ceiling and made funny noises.

My co-worker (who's blonde) asked me what I was doing.

I told her that I was pretending to be a light bulb, so that the boss would think I was crazy and give me a few days off.

A few minutes later the boss came into the office and asked ``What are you doing?''

I told him I was a light bulb.

He said: ``You are clearly stressed out.

``Go home and recuperate for a couple of days.''

I jumped down and walked out of the office.

When my co-worker (the blonde) followed me, the boss asked her: ``And where do you think you're going?''

She said: ``I'm going home too. I can't work in the dark!''

Paraprosdokian sentences

* I asked God for a bike, but I know God doesn't work that way. So I stole a bike and asked for forgiveness.

* Do not argue with an idiot. He will drag you down to his level and beat you with experience.

* I want to die peacefully in my sleep, like my grandfather. Not screaming and yelling like the passengers in his car.

* Going to church doesn't make you a Christian any more than standing in a garage makes you a car.

* The last thing I want to do is hurt you. But it's still on the list.

* Light travels faster than sound. This is why some people appear bright until you hear them speak.

* If I agreed with you we'd both be wrong.

* We never really grow up, we only learn how to act in public.

* War does not determine who is right -- only who is left.

* Knowledge is knowing a tomato is a fruit. Wisdom is not putting it in a fruit salad.

* The early bird might get the worm, but the second mouse gets the cheese.

* Evening news is where they begin with ``Good evening'', and then proceed to tell you why it isn't.

* To steal ideas from one person is plagiarism. To steal from many is research.

* A bus station is where a bus stops. A train station is where a train stops. On my desk, I have a work station.

* How is it one careless match can start a forest fire, but it takes a whole box to start a campfire?

* Some people are like Slinkies . . . not really good for anything, but you can't help smiling when you see one tumble down the stairs.

* Dolphins are so smart that within a few weeks of captivity, they can train people to stand on the very edge of the pool and throw them fish.

* I thought I wanted a career. Turns out I just wanted pay cheques.

* A bank is a place that will lend you money, if you can prove that you don't need it.

* A clear conscience is usually the sign of a bad memory.

* You do not need a parachute to skydive. You only need a parachute to skydive twice.

* The voices in my head may not be real, but they have some good ideas!

* Always borrow money from a pessimist. He won't expect it back.

* A diplomat is someone who can tell you to go to hell in such a way that you will look forward to the trip.

* I discovered I scream the same way whether I'm about to be devoured by a great white shark or if a piece of seaweed touches my foot.

Your last coin.................

A FATHER walks into a restaurant with his young son.

He gives the young boy three 10c coins to play with to keep him occupied.

Suddenly, the boy starts choking, going blue in the face.

The father realises the boy has swallowed the coins and starts slapping him on the back.

The boy coughs up two of the 10c coins, but keeps choking.

Looking at his son, the father is panicking, shouting for help.

A well-dressed, attractive and serious-looking woman in a blue business suit is sitting at a coffee bar reading a newspaper and sipping a cup of coffee.

At the sound of the commotion, she looks up, puts her coffee cup down, neatly folds the newspaper and places it on the counter, gets up from her seat and makes her way, unhurried, across the restaurant.

Reaching the boy, the woman carefully drops his pants, takes hold of the boy's testicles and starts to squeeze and twist, gently at first and then ever so firmly.

After a few seconds, the boy convulses violently and coughs up the last 10c coin, which the woman deftly catches in her free hand.

Releasing the boy's testicles, the woman hands the coin to the father and walks back to her seat at the coffee bar without saying a word.

As soon as he is sure that his son has suffered no ill effects, the father rushes over to the woman and starts thanking her saying, ``I've never seen anybody do anything like that before -- it was fantastic. Are you a doctor?"

``No,'' the woman replies . . . ``I'm with Australian Taxation Office.''

urn:contentItem:457Y-MH30-0197-51JC-00000-00<published>1997-09-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 14</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Voters will have the final word </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>NIALL DORAN, PAUL RUTHERFORD, BARRY THOMSON, JOHN HAYWARD, G.D. BOLTON, SARA HOUREZ, D. ANDERSON, HAROLD HUNT, LES WEBBER. MUSTAFA EREM, JACK MOTT, CHRIS PIKE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JOHN Howard might find it worthwhile faxing all his government members and senators an additional copy of his Parliamentary Code of Conduct.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> This follows a recordbreaking week for his embattled party with two ministerial "resignations" in just one day, which brings the disgraceful tally to six forced ministerial "resignations" in his first 18 months of government.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mr Howard, travel rorting and blatant cases of conflict of interest will never be accepted by the Australian electorate.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Your newly adopted "battler friends" are not impressed and will confirm this at the ballot box in 1998.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>CHRIS PIKE Ryde, NSW</p><p>THE "holier than thou" or hypocritical attitude adopted by the Federal Opposition during the shouting match over travelling allowances was laughable.</p><p> It is most likely that Mr Jull and Mr Sharp will be cleared of any suggestion that they deliberately claimed allowances for which they were not entitled and which were repaid promptly when the discrepancies were ascertained.</p><p> I suppose when the chips are down and the party is staring into a long period in the political wilderness, the ALP, in desperation, can be expected to resort to tactics which Machiavelli would applaud.</p><p> JACK MOTT Rockhampton, Qld</p><p>DESPITE its growing membership, I doubt that the Free Travel Club will become a Free Travel Party. There is no doubt, however, that a centuries-old adage is still relevant today: he who holds the honey pot will sometimes sample its content.</p><p> MUSTAFA EREM Gosford, NSW</p><p> DAVID Kemp could possibly be correct with his claims of levels of illiteracy in the community when not even his colleagues in the Federal Ministry seem able to keep personal diaries.</p><p> LES WEBBER Evelyn Central, Qld</p><p>THE fact that Parliament House in Canberra is often referred to as "the big top, Canberra circus", could be funny if it didn't cost so much to maintain the clowns who inhabit the place.</p><p> Now we have the "travel rort" business clogging up the air waves and newspaper columns.</p><p> Do politicians consider us electors to be just a bunch of idiots? I guess they can't be blamed for thinking that we are, when one considers some of the clowns we have put into parliament.</p><p> HAROLD HUNT Bigga, NSW</p><p> DEPUTY Prime Minister Tim Fischer, interviewed by Matt Peacock for the ABC's PM program on Wednesday, having answered a series of apparently spikey questions on the recent Sharp/Jull ministerial resignations, concluded by advising Mr Peacock to " . . .</p><p>take care Matt". Mr Fischer's delicate emphasis on the word "care" wasn't delicate enough for this Australian. Mr Fischer was discomfited by Mr Peacock's persistence. The concluding remark is of greater than usual interest.</p><p> D. ANDERSON Rockhampton, Qld</p><p>DEAR remnant ministers, beware when the Prime Minister says publicly that he has full confidence in you as your head will be served up on a platter.</p><p> SARA HOUREZ Malabar, NSW</p><p>MEMO Mr Howard: why not move Amanda Vanstone to Transport?</p><p> She has shown firmness which will be more constructive there than John Sharp's abrasive kind of playground-bully approach to both unions and employers which so far yielded you so little.</p><p> And yet this style of Amanda's might be timely to remove from her current areas, where your perhaps unavoidable need to deliver bad news to many people might be better served with a more (outwardly) compassionate minister to deliver it.</p><p> G.D. BOLTON Sydney, NSW</p><p>ANYONE feeling that John Sharp has been hard done by should try telling the DSS that his/her 47 bogus claims for nearly $9000 were the result of honest memory slips.</p><p> Wait for the solicitude of the department. Listen for the expressions of sympathy from the Deputy PM. And take your toothbrush.</p><p> JOHN HAYWARD Weegena, Tas</p><p> MOST of us have unreliable memories. Most of us forget things that did happen. Funny that John Sharp remembered 47 things that didn't happen.</p><p> BARRY THOMSON Coominya, Qld</p><p>NEVER before has there been so much sleaze, so much disregard for the rule of law and civil rights, in such as short a time, by so few!</p><p>  Canberra, Brisbane, Melbourne, Perth -the stench of conservative government pervades the very air we breath like the smoke of an Indonesian forest fire.</p><p> And no doubt this rabble will continue to do all they can to make our political system just like Indonesia's.</p><p> PAUL RUTHERFORD Darlington, NSW</p><p> HOW stupid do the pollies think we are? Travel rorts by politicians are nothing new, it's just that over the last 12 months they've been made more public.</p><p> NIALL DORAN South Hobart, Tas</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7W1G-J0F0-YBDY-R087-00000-00Odd date with the groom2009-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisOPED2Pg. 82Odd date with the groomGLENN A. BAKER

IT is an odd claim to make, I know, but I went to the movies with Michael Jackson on his wedding day.

A Sydney cinema preview had been arranged for the short film Ghosts when Michael was here on his second solo tour, in November 1996.

In the wee hours of that morning he had married the former nurse Debbie Rowe in an impromptu ceremony in a suite of the Hyatt on the Park Hotel on Elizabeth St in Sydney.

News of his nuptials had broken during the day and none of us there at the Hoyts complex really expected him to make an appearance, even though there were three rows of seats bearing reserved signs.

But as 6pm approached, a melee in the foyer reached our ears and the King of Pop duly swept in, followed by a string of children related to a charity, and claimed those seats.

He was directly in front of me, two rows ahead and as he made himself comfortable a battalion of instamatic cameras created a forest fire of light.

He averted his gaze from the conflagration, bestowed a shy smile upon me and waved an arm as if to say, ``Let this begin''. And it did.

There was no sign of his wife of but a few hours; a portent of thing to come, or perhaps not to come.

A few weeks earlier I had travelled to Zaragoza, Spain, to witness a performance on the European leg of the HIStory Tour, which had begun in Prague and, by the time it was over, would see him visit five continents and play 82 shows in 58 cities of 35 countries to almost five million fans.

The fans in that small Spanish city were as fevered as those at every other stop, dancing and prancing in the streets on the way to the stadium, waving banners and singing songs.

It was 17 years on from his No.1 hit Don't Stop Till You Get Enough from the Off the Wall album that heralded the commencement of an astonishingly productive and profitable collaboration with producer Quincy Jones and, quite plainly, the world had not had enough of the enigmatic child-man.

His shows, like his albums, were deftly crafted and constructed extravaganzas, powered along by his irresistible hybrid music.

For that was at the heart of the Jacko phenomenon. He had done in the early '80s what Elvis Presley had done in the mid '50s.

The truck driver from Memphis redrew the face of popular music by fusing black rhythm and white country music and, while becoming a template for a new attitude and behaviour, unleashed a firestorm of uncontrollable force.

Jackson's inspired inter-weaving was black soul and funk -- his music, with white guitar rock, still the pre-eminent sound of the day.

Barriers tumbled when, as one observer put it, disco met pop.

MTV effectively had a colour bar in place as did many radio formats, but when guitar god Eddie Van Halen was called in to unleash a blistering solo on Beat It, from the Thriller album, the colours bled into each other, then and for evermore.

Black acts found a white rock audience that had eluded them. More than can be counted, who have arisen and ridden high in the mainstream since, owe him a considerable debt.

It falls to very few creative forces in a generation or an era to crystalise elements, to be the first to hear what everyone else soon will hear.

The obituary and tribute headlines are now using the world genius liberally and it is not misplaced.

His instincts and intuitions were stunning, as was his ability to integrate sound with vision in order to mould a powerful package than enabled his persona to reach into hitherto unpenetrated areas.

I remember being in another European city, Brussels I think it was, early in 1993 when Thriller -- the album that would spend 37 weeks atop the American charts and sell an unmatched 50 million copies -- was blitzing everything in its path.

I walked into a newsstand where rows upon rows of magazines, from motor mechanics to farm machinery to arts and crafts journals, seemed to have him on the front cover.

The fascination was total fascination for the single glove, for the moonwalking and other svelte moves, even for the then-endearing eccentricities like a pet chimp and an identification with Peter Pan.

He was, as all good stars should be, not just a spellbinder who could seemingly transform lives but also a slightly ethereal figure existing beyond the everyday world.

He had come out of his Jackson 5/Jacksons years with a new sophistication and sensuality eons on from the lad who sang the chirpy Rockin Robin.

The evolution had been inexorable. Performing from the age of four, recording from the age of nine, having hits from the age of 11. Indelible was the mark he left in 1969 when he appeared on our television screens as a tiny, afro-topped whirling dervish whipping through I Want You Back and ABC, his elder brothers plainly taking their lead from him, compelling and commanding with a cocky cheekiness.

You couldn't take your eyes off him. For decades to come you still wouldn't be able to.

Michael Jackson went where no performer had gone before by understanding and drawing upon where a great many had already been, particularly black performers.

His dance moves echoed those of Billy Bojangles Robinson and Cab Calloway, his voice at its smoothest drew a line from Nat King Cole, his stage confidence and style from Sammy Davis Jr, his cool sleekness from his Motown stablemate Marvin Gaye, perhaps even his stage drama from James Brown.

In short, he knew and respected who had gone before.

In many ways it was things we'd seen before but in so many ways it was things we'd never seen.

He knew who to surround himself with to bring out his own talents and abilities.

The jazz bandleader Quincy Jones, who'd worked so effectively with Ray Charles, brought a mature, steady hand to proceedings and, like George Martin with Lennon and McCartney, was able to turn musical ideas into something more tangible.

He amplified the impact of his recordings by bringing directors such as John Landis and Martin Scorsese in the picture.

No simple promotional film clips for Michael -- he outlayed on cinematic extravaganzas to more fully assault the senses.

What he invested in, that which reached the public, was not just towering in financial terms but gruelling and exhausting in human terms -- a sad consequence of which seems to have now presented itself.

It was a sad fact that Jackson's bizarre personal life -- which led to the unflattering nickname Wacko Jacko -- overshadowed his performance prowess in later years.

He was criticised for dangling his baby over a balcony, sleeping in an oxygen chamber, his personal zoo and amusement park he built at his Neverland ranch and befriending a chimpanzee.

Then there was his bizarre transformation from a black man with a big nose, strong features and giant afro haircut, to a white man with straight hair and thin, pale features -- which he usually hid behind a face-mask.

He insisted his transformation to a pale complexion was due to a rare skin disease known as vitiligo, but admitted he had had several surgical procedures to change the shape of his face.

But nothing was as damaging to him as being accused in 1993 of molesting a 13-year-old boy -- a claim he denied and which was dropped after he paid the boy $27.36 million.

He was back in court a decade later accused -- and later cleared -- of sexually abusing another boy.

But through it all Jacko's contribution to music remains a monumental one.

urn:contentItem:4H57-RDD0-015G-Y33G-00000-00<published>2005-09-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Space invaders eye off Mars</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Brian Bergstein</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Real estate on the Red Planet? It could be a lot closer than you think. Brian Bergstein reports</p><p nitf:lede="true">ALL companies set goals, but newly formed 4Frontiers Corp is eyeing some expansive horizons. The company's mission: to open a small human settlement on Mars within 20 years or so.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Sure, it may sound far-fetched. And the company's initial plans are a lot more terrestrial than ethereal -- for example, developing a 2250sq m replica of a Mars settlement here on Earth, then charging tourists admission.</p><p>But the people behind the venture are serious -- as serious as the $US25 million ($32.85 million) they are seeking to raise from investors.</p><p>CEO Mark Homnick, former manager for Intel Corp, who has registered the name 4Frontiers in Florida, says he has already raised "a couple of million" from people he won't name. He hopes for an initial public offering within five years.</p><p>That still leaves a lot of questions: Why should people live on Mars? And if it's going to be done, should a private enterprise engage in what would be one of humanity's defining moments?</p><p>Besides, what's in it for investors?</p><p>Homnick and his co-founders -- a longtime Mars aficionado named Bruce Mackenzie and a 25-year-old Massachusetts Institute of Technology master's student, Joseph Palaia -- are ready with several answers.</p><p>First, they contend, humankind needs a new frontier to explore, with all the intellectual and engineering challenges that settling on Mars would present.</p><p>Also, who knows the fate of our humble Earth? Will we meet an early end at the hands of an asteroid, warfare, disease or some other catastrophe?</p><p>In that case, we'd be glad civilisation had been preserved by some colonists on Mars -- and perhaps elsewhere in the galaxy, if all goes well on the Red Planet. That broader vision of space settlement is what gives 4Frontiers its name: the frontiers being the Earth, the moon, Mars and the asteroids.</p><p>"It's the nature of life -- life tries to expand and tries to adapt," Mackenzie says. "If there's a forest fire in one valley, then all of the organisms in the next valley will slowly creep over the ridge and repopulate that valley. Any species that don't do it eventually die out."</p><p>Going to space, he believes, is as if "all of Earth's life, acting together, is trying to get into the next valley. And the only way we can do it is by building rockets."</p><p>Mackenzie, a software developer, has devoted much of his energy to a nonprofit group called the Mars Foundation, which aims to advance knowledge about how to colonise the planet. But he also believes that a private venture such as 4Frontiers will be necessary to drive things forward.</p><p>Although US President George W. Bush has called for a manned mission to Mars, Mackenzie believes big bureaucracies might never get the job done right.</p><p>"It's better to have lots of groups out there, all trying things," Mackenzie says.</p><p>Indeed, space is no longer solely the province of earnest astronauts with crew cuts and government-issued uniforms.</p><p>Space tourism is now on the verge of becoming big business. Space Adventures Ltd of Arlington, Virginia, has brokered $26.28 million trips for the wealthy on Russian rockets and is taking deposits for fly-bys of the far side of the moon. For a lot less money than that, you can sign up for a quick blast into zero gravity.</p><p>In comparison, 4Frontiers' ultimate goal of an extended stay on Mars would be an off-the-charts extreme.</p><p>It would take months to get there. Once there, you couldn't kick off your shoes and dig your toes into the sand. Life would transpire in an enclosed space with pumped-in air (unless Martian settlers could pull off the even more speculative feat of "terraforming" the planet by changing its toxic atmosphere). Venturing outside would require sealed suits.</p><p>To begin, 4Frontiers plans to gather patents and engineering ideas that would enable a small crew to land on Mars with home-building materials and the manufacturing capability to keep adding on.</p><p>The hot topics would include ways to miniaturise key industrial processes -- such as making plastic or steel -- and methods for exploiting resources on Mars, such as the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, iron in the ground or the water bound up in Martian ice.</p><p>As the company gains expertise, it expects to sell consulting services to aerospace companies or NASA.</p><p>It also envisions getting work designing Mars sets for movies and Mars rides for amusement parks.</p><p>Meanwhile, it plans to construct a mock-up of its Mars home and begin selling tickets to it by 2007. Potential sites in Colorado, Florida and New Mexico are being considered.</p><p>The company's business plan estimates these varied projects would bring in $44.67 million in revenue in 2010, including $9.2 million in gate receipts at the tourist site.</p><p>Profits before taxes, depreciation and amortisation are forecast at $1.84 million as early as next year, and $39.02 million in 2010.</p><p>Even if that flies, then what? A company worth $44.67 million probably isn't in a great position to begin launching rockets into space.</p><p>Homnick says 4Frontiers would probably "stay incremental" through the early 2010s, perhaps getting involved in robotic surveys of the surface of Mars or asteroid mining.</p><p>HOWEVER, projects like that -- and perhaps even settling Mars -- might require some clarity in space law.</p><p>The 1967 Outer Space Treaty declared that the "exploration and use" of outer space and celestial bodies "shall be carried out for the benefit and in the interest of all countries".</p><p>While that's not exactly the traditional language of private enterprise, some space scholars say it leaves room for commercial projects.</p><p>(A 1979 Moon Treaty was more explicit, holding that bodies in the solar system should not become the property of any nation, organisation or person. But most countries, including the United States, China and Russia, never ratified it.)</p><p>Considering all the possible complications, Mackenzie says 4Frontiers' real success might come simply from getting the public pumped about living on Mars. In turn, that could make Washington eager to fund a settlement.</p><p>Even if that doesn't happen, he says he is sure that eventually people will live on Mars -- and perhaps scores of other places in space.</p><p>"It's a question of when," he says. "I really hope we get started before we have an economic decline that delays it. I'd really hate to have something like the Great Depression, or the Dark Ages that lasted several hundred years, delay our getting into space."</p><p>Information: <url normalizedValue="http://www.4frontiers.com">www.4frontiers.com</url></p><p><url normalizedValue="http://www.marshome.org">www.marshome.org</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
