urn:contentItem:4B44-4PY0-01S8-84V5-00000-00<published>1993-09-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WHY THE UNIVERSE IS ALIVE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DAVID HARRIS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>IN THE BEGINNING The Birth of the Living Universe by John Gribbin VIKING/PENGUIN, MELBOURNE, $39.95 FAR back in the history of astronomy, in the year 1970, Jim Lovelock, a designer of the Mars Viking lander, worked out a simple test by which a visitor to our solar system, while far out in space, would establish that the planet Earth must have life. Futhermore, the planet itself would seem as if it was a living creature. Lovelock mentioned this to his neighbor and friend, William Golding, who suggested the name Gaia, the Greek goddess of Earth, for the dynamic, self-regulating system of our planet.</p><p>At the time, the Gaia hypothesis seemed outrageous. How could micro-organisms in the sea be connected to the rhythm of the ice ages? There may be faint analogies between the properties of living creatures and the feedback mechanisms of a planet, but that is all.</p><p>But recently, the language of biology has infiltrated astronomy. Stars and planets are born and die. Galaxies evolve. Gigantic cannibal galaxies devour and digest spiral galaxies such as our Milky Way, that is whirling towards its doom. Gaia on a galactic scale.</p><p>In this exciting, at times thrilling book, astrophysicist John Gribbin uses biological terms, not merely as interesting metaphors but as expressions of facts about the universe. Elegantly, methodically, like a Hercule Poirot, he reveals, piece by piece, the evidence that leads to a mind-boggling conclusion. Our cosmos was born, grows, reproduces the seeds of galaxies and, in a vast, almost infinitely slow struggle, jostles for survival among a host of alternative universes.</p><p>Gribbin writes with authority, as physics consultant for the journal New Scientist and author of some significant books, including The Matter Myth, with Adelaide University physicist Paul Davies; and Stephen Hawking: A Life in Science, with Michael White.</p><p>In The Beginning opens with the dramatic news that, in 1992, a COBE satellite discovered ripples in the structure of the universe dating back almost 15,000 million years, confirming that our universe was born out of a tiny, hot fireball and continues to expand in spacetime.</p><p>Then Gribbin takes us into the heart of the atom, the bizarre world of neutrinos, the nuclear inferno of suns where, by incredibly narrow margins, at odds of millions to one, the atoms are forged that one day will be blown out into space to become planets and living creatures.</p><p>In the Orion Nebula, a site of star birth near to us, are 60 different kinds of molecule. The debris of dead stars, re-cycled into new stars, contains organic compounds such as formic acid, formaldehyde and ethanol.</p><p>Gribbin's argument is that stars are like cells in a human body. The human body loses more than 1kg of cells each day but does not wear out, because the cells are constantly being replaced. So it is with galaxies. A dazzling, blue-white fire burns along the leading edges of the great spirals. That brilliant light is the forest fire of exploding stars swept up in the enormous shock wave of the turning spiral. Each star burst hurls far out into space the stuff of life for the next generation of stars. Each galaxy constantly renews itself, in the process creating the conditions of, as Gribbin puts it, the Goldilocks Effect. Things are "just right" for the emergence of life. The laws of our universe make life not a rare accident but an inevitability on a multitudinous scale. We look out upon a living universe. Moreover, the same laws that describe supernovae account for the creation of black holes, the seeds of new galaxies. But this vast system is bounded by space-time. Our universe is finite, a tiny bubble of light, from which escape is impossible. In effect, we are trapped within a black hole; only one of countless such universes.</p><p>All the grand images and surprises of this book are more than another popularising of science, although Gribbin is an expert at that. He is involved in the efforts to find a coherent understanding of our universe. By linking evolution and cosmology, he anticipates ways of knowing what happened before the Big Bang that produced our particular universe. As he playfully puts it, "You cannot really ask for much more of any scientific idea" than it explains how and why everything exists.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:803V-DKH0-YBDY-R2N7-00000-00Buyback lost behind political smokescreen2010-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisREVIEWPg. 8Buyback lost behind political smokescreenCAMERON STEWART, MILANDA ROUT

VICTORIA

A key bushfire royal commission recommendation is being undermined

IT took only a few days before the sober and considered findings of Bernard Teague's Victorian bushfire royal commission were being undermined by politics and spin.

The 900-page report, based on 15 months of hearings, had barely been digested by John Brumby's government this week before it quietly set out to kill one of the commission's most challenging recommendations: that the state volunteer to buy back the properties of people living in areas of ``unacceptably high'' bushfire risk.

It was the recommendation the Brumby government had feared most, because it would be costly, complex and, above all, politically risky to implement only months before an election.

The government fears voters will see the idea as a kick in the guts for those country towns that have struggled back to their feet after the Black Saturday fires that claimed 173 lives across the state.

But the commission disagreed, arguing instead that governments in a bushfire-prone nation such as Australia have a duty of care to encourage people not to live in places that are only one blistering heat wave from becoming a death trap.

``The commission proposes that action be taken to help people move away from those areas and where other bushfire risk-mitigation measures are not viable . . . the state should develop and implement a voluntary retreat and resettlement strategy --including non-compulsory land acquisition -- for existing developments at unacceptably high bushfire risk,'' the report says.

If adopted, it would require the Victorian government to identify streets and individual properties around the state it deems to be of extreme risk from bushfire, and offer to buy back those properties, thereby giving people the voluntary option of an economic escape from the danger zone

Such a move would also have national implications, forcing other states to consider whether they also owe a greater duty of care to people living in places of extreme bushfire risk.

It is a proposal that raises basic questions about the balance between big government and civil liberties.

It places limits on Australia's cherished embrace of life in the bush and concedes that people cannot be trusted to consider their own safety when choosing where they live.

But is such a plan possible or practical on a statewide basis?

Brumby's official position is that his government will not make a final decision on the retreat and resettlement recommendation for several weeks, until it consults with communities in bushfire zones.

But behind the scenes, the government is trying to scuttle the idea. Government advisers have been on the phones to media warning the commissioners' plan would include vast numbers of homes and billions of dollars.

A report in the Herald Sun that was attributed to government sources warned that up to 49,000 houses would potentially have to be bought out at a cost of $15 billion to the taxpayer.

No explanation was given as to how these government figures were calculated.

Brumby also claims he has already received negative community feedback about the buyback proposal.

``There are certainly some people who would support this policy,'' Brumby tells Inquirer. ``But the overwhelming majority views that I have had is that this would be very complex, very difficult, very expensive and would have implications that would lead to tens of thousands of homes and would lead to a lack of confidence in small towns right across country Victoria.''

Brumby's comments sound less like those of the community than those of his own government lawyers, who told the commission in April that such a proposal would be ``complex to deliver, extremely expensive, may increase bushfire risk and be potentially damaging to the communities affected''.

The government's scare campaign on the issue has raised eyebrows among the commissioners, who used a press conference to point out that the proposed policy only applied to ``micro-sites'' rather than whole towns.

``They would be sites that are on ridge-lines, often surrounded by gullies . . . particularly if they are within 100m of bush,'' Susan Pascoe, one of the three commissioners, said.

In other words, the number of houses affected by the recommendation, and therefore the cost, would be substantially less than the government was claiming.

``I have been appalled by the government's reaction, which amounts to a gross exaggeration of the scale and the cost of what the commission was proposing,' says Michael Buxton, associate professor of environment and planning at RMIT, who was a member of the expert panel advising the commission.

``It would cost millions, rather than billions, and would only focus on very high-risk areas. It was never meant to be widely applied or to close whole towns down,'' Buxton says.

Because the government does not want the proposal to win wide public support, it is interpreting the commissioners' proposal in the widest possible manner to highlight the costs and complexities.

While the government refuses to disclose how it has costed the idea, it appears to have used as its basis a 2009 Country Fire Authority assessment that there are 52 ``high risk zones'' across the state, including highly populated areas such as the Dandenong Ranges and popular holiday towns such as Lorne.

Buxton says he believes the commission intended for the criteria to be much narrower, aiming at selected individual homes and streets rather than entire towns.

The example given in the final report was Pine Ridge Road, which runs along a mountain top in Kinglake West, where 21 people died on Black Saturday.

Buxton says such specific sites for buybacks would have only a minimal impact on country towns and that it was a scare tactic for the government to claim entire towns would die.

``Country towns have been dying in Victoria for all sorts of reasons, such as changes in manufacturing policy or agriculture,'' he says.

``Having a responsible bushfire policy would have only a minimal impact on these towns compared with those other factors.''

But the commission did not provide a formula to determine what constitutes unacceptable bushfire risk and it did not give any examples of locations beyond Pine Ridge Road and parts of the town of Marysville.

According to the government, the devil lies in this detail.

The government would have the difficult task of determining the criteria for which homes qualify for a buyback and then it would have to apply it across the state.

But assessing bushfire risk is an imperfect science and the subjective nature of such a ruling on someone's home may open the door to numerous legal challenges.

Former forest fire chief Athol Hodgson says he is not surprised by the political posturing around the issue, saying this it has all happened before.

He says buybacks of land had been suggested in Victoria after bushfires in the 1960s and then after Ash Wednesday in the 80s.

The Liberal government did successfully implement a buyback of land in the Dandenong Ranges in the 70s but the Labor government had rejected similar ideas in other parts of the state in the 80s.

``It involves freedom of choice of where to live and that is opposed by some people. So it only works if you can make it work politically,'' Hodgson says.

``It's a very tricky issue to resolve. If people live in these areas and don't take some pretty drastic management to reduce their fire risk, there is no way authorities can ensure their safety.''

Buxton believes that any decision to reject the commissioners' buyback proposal would represent a failure of leadership.

``The [Liberal Rupert] Hamer government in the 70s succeeded in limiting houses in the Dandenongs by building community support for the idea.

``What Brumby is doing is trying to scare people -- there is a stark contrast in leadership styles.''

Opposition Leader Ted Baillieu, who has committed to implement the retreat and resettlement proposal if elected, says Brumby is grossly exaggerating the impact of the planned buyback.

``I see this as a modest recommendation rather than the sky is going to fall in and everyone [who lives in the bush] will have to leave their properties,'' he tells Inquirer.

The commissioners' report advocates a dual path of offering to buy back property while also placing restrictions on developing new properties deemed to be in extreme bushfire risk zones.

Planning expert Roslynne Hansen told the royal commission that tree change and sea change trends would see more people moving to small rural properties on the outskirts of Melbourne and that ``more detailed consideration needs to be given to the strategic aspects of planning for bushfire attack''.

Buxton agrees.

``Tens of thousands of people will move into these rural areas in the future and the government has to look at this issue carefully,'' he says.

``If it does not, then it will enormously increase risks for many thousands of people.''

At its heart, the statewide retreat and resettlement proposal challenges the government to open a historic new chapter in Australian bushfire policy, ending the random nature of bush settlements.

Yet it appears to be doomed by politics even before it is properly considered.

urn:contentItem:465D-1TD0-015G-P3DC-00000-00<published>2002-06-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>REVIEW-COLUMN- WINE LINESFOOD & WINE; Pg. R20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Big guy rises from the ashes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>James Halliday</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE 188cm  tall, 120kg, generously bearded Pat Kuleto immediately fills every space he is in -- even a 450m ridge at the top of the 323ha Kuleto Estate in California, the Napa Valley floor and Lake Hennessey far below.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> At 56, he has lived a number of lives, lost the tips of two fingers in a radial saw, and emerged from bankruptcy in 1980 and a raging forest fire in 1992 that destroyed his large ranch house in Calaveras County and all his and his wife Shannon's possessions.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Undeterred, he is nearing the end of his most ambitious project: the house, winery and 40.4ha vineyard project that are the conventional pieces of Kuleto Estate. Less conventional are a 11m French river boat sitting at the bottom of a series of fully functional locks running up a near-vertical mountainside gully, built (in part) because his six-year-old son had been entranced by a canal trip through France.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Seldom do you find a site that has consumed 3000 tonnes of rocks, brought down from Lake County before coming up 450m to the winery and building site, or that is home to a grove of 90-year-old olive trees saved when Stags' Leap Winery wished to expand its vineyards. (The trees only cost $200 each but $2000 each to box up and transport.) Or one that accommodates many dams that were meant to cost $180,000, but ended up at $400,000 -- dams that are variously stocked with golden trout, bass and sturgeon, the latter well over 1m in length and approaching child-bearing age (that is, caviar).</p><p> Earlier this year, Forbes Magazine put the project cost at $40million, and it is hardly surprising that Kuleto doesn't even pretend that it will provide a return of any kind. Indeed, he off-handedly says the winery has a 35,000-case permit, but he doubts whether he will take production past 10,000 cases, selling the excess grapes from the plantings -- 40ha but still expanding.</p><p> It is fair to say that even in the first six years since planting began, Kuleto has changed his mind several times about the main emphasis and direction of the estate. First it was to be sangiovese, now cabernet sauvignon, but an additional half-dozen varieties give plenty of scope for future changes and expansion.</p><p> This self-taught former carpenter and building contractor more or less stumbled into restaurant design and building in the 1970s, having had a brief stint as a waiter. He built more than 20 Refectory Steakhouses. It was then he made his ill-timed move into real estate investment, initially making millions before being caught in a 1980-81 credit squeeze.</p><p> He went back into restaurant design and in 1984 created San Francisco's Fog City Diner. His 110th restaurant, it was a breakthrough in design and established his reputation nationwide. He has now designed more than 150 restaurants across the US and has ventured as far afield as Indonesia and Japan.</p><p> Heading the list are three of San Francisco's most famous restaurants, and Kuleto is a partner in these: Jardiniere, Farallon and Boulevard. More recently, he opened Martini House at St Helena in the Napa Valley. A superb wine list with more than 600 wines and equally wonderful food (I chose crispy sweetbreads, then lobster on roasted asparagus, then squab with wild mushrooms) makes it a powerful challenger to Napa icon restaurants such as Tra Vigne.</p><p> His skill in designing restaurants comes from his innate ability to immediately envision three-dimensional design, and as he strode through the vast upper storey of the winery -- still at gyprock stage and as big as a football field -- glass walls, huge tables, leather couches, fireplaces and dozens of other ideas came pouring from his mind. And he never does things by half-measure.</p><p> The winery won't be open to the public in the normal sense (the planning permit won't allow it, for one thing) but by arrangement. Visitors will be able to spend a whole day at the estate, which is inevitably described as a vinous Disneyland.</p><p> Kuleto is still actively scheming "add-on" experiences for future visitors;  my disbelief grew  through my visit.</p><p> Finally, consider this in the land of the free: until recent changes in the law, he couldn't sell his wine to or through any of the restaurants in which he had a proprietary interest. Now he can sell to two -- but only two -- of them. Alice in Wonderland could not have provided a better storyline.</p><p><url normalizedValue="http://www.winepros.com.au">www.winepros.com.au</url></p><p>The Australian's Winter Reds 2002</p><p>Now that the cooler months have arrived, be quick to take advantage of The Australian's Winter Reds 2002 offer. The selection of top quality wines includes reds from Australia, New Zealand and Italy. The full dozen is great value at $169 plus delivery; a half-dozen is $89 plus delivery. To order, phone 1300 368 851 or visit <url normalizedValue="http://www.theaustralian.com.au/wine">www.theaustralian.com.au/wine</url>. </p><p>Halliday s choice</p><p>1999 Leeuwin Estate Art Series Chardonnay</p><p>The 1999 Leeuwin Estate Art Series Chardonnay (96 points, $77) is a stunner. It s brilliant, pale straw-green in colour, and the delicate and restrained bouquet is completely at odds with the 14.5 degrees alcohol, as is the youthful, vibrant grapefruit, nectarine and melon fruit of the palate. Finer and with less obvious complexity than some of the previous releases, it could develop into something quite special, even by the standards of Leeuwin Estate.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4PVX-K1R0-TX53-20DM-00000-00LETTERS TO THE EDITOR2007-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisPg. 27LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

How to lose support

HOT TOPIC

PROTESTS

SITTING in gridlocked traffic at 3.40pm on Friday, costing me and my family our income as I was late for work, I felt angry and very annoyed with the pathetic display of irresponsibility towards the public's safety by green extremists holding thousands to ransom over the Gunns pulp mill.

Before Friday, the Greens and pulp mill protesters had my full support but after seeing extremists display their true colours and antics and thumb their nose at the laws made to keep the public safe, I am now seriously considering not supporting either group as they have lost my support, vote and respect.

It is a sad day for the pulp mill protesters. Hundreds if not thousands of good, decent, honest, hard-working Hobartians who were inconvenienced, had plans disrupted, income lost and lives put at risk due to emergency vehicles not being able to respond in sufficient time through gridlocked traffic may now react as I have.

Good on you extremists, you have just had a 100 per cent negative effect for green support in the public arena.

Ray Carter

Kingston

Activists unpaid

I MUST take issue with Brian Bresnahan's claim that there is a group of paid protesters who travel the country disrupting forestry operations (Letters, October 8).

I have been involved with forest defence for seven years in my birthplace of the Hunter Valley in New South Wales, in my adopted home in the Huon and several other areas at the request of local communities and I am yet to come across these mythical paid protesters. The truth that is unpalatable to those shortsighted enough to support the status quo of the forestry industry is that people are willing to give up their normal lives in order to defend our ancient forests.

The commitment of volunteer forest activists is in sharp contrast to those timber industry front groups who claim they represent timber communities.

When was the last time someone from Timber Communities Australia could not afford to buy food or had to scrape together a few dollars to afford petrol or stationary?

Warrick Jordan

Huon Valley Environment Centre

Angel stunt

ALLANA Beltran's heart is in the right place but to impersonate an angel is merely a publicity stunt and to religious believers may be distasteful and presumptions. We are all well aware of what is happening to the environment but while we subscribe to an acquisitive capitalist society the destruction will continue unabated.

Norman Dunbar

Sandy Bay

Precious rights

DEMOCRACY is hard to win and easy to lose. Those who tut tut the Burmese military junta for clamping down on basic democratic rights should be careful before agreeing that it is OK for Tasmanian police to sue forest protesters for causing them inconvenience.

Civil liberties are most felt when they are lost. We should value the democracy we have got, even if at times when we disagree with the points of view of people who want to exercise those democratic rights. You never know, next time it may be you that is muzzled.

Chris Harries

Dynnyrne

Legal victory

THERE will only be one winner in the Forestry versus activists legal action: the lawyers. They will be laughing all the way to the bank.

Mark Taylor

Mt Seymour

This is war

HE states that he wants to ''heal divisions in the community'' but what Paul Lennon has done is fire the first salvo in the pulp mill war.

On one side we have the proponents of ''free market'' capitalism aided by politicians with a warped sense of what democracy is really about. These people appear to care only about power and maximising the rate of return to pulp mill investors. On the other side we have many voters who feel disenfranchised, motivated by the desire to ensure that future generations inherit a planet that has well husbanded resources. The present brand of forest-fire capitalism will consume the earth's resources at an ever increasing pace. The pulp mill is a manifestation of a society incapable of putting an adequate environmental cost on production and associated pollution.

Time to get busy people. Protest in any way you can. The ''pulp mill war'' has just started.

Miles Harrison

Blackmans Bay

In the limelight

WITH at least 85 per cent of voters not wanting the Greens, why did all channels on Sunday night TV news lead with what the Greens want? Please think of the 85 per cent who are sick and tired of them. Same goes for the Mercury on Monday.

Brian Jones

West Moonah

QUICK VIEWS

Never-ending twists

WHY is it that despite supermarkets having been around since 1937 it is still impossible for them to provide shopping trolleys that steer properly?

Peter Bond

Seven Mile Beach

Majority dictatorship

ONE thing is obvious, never again let us have full majority governments either federally or state where even conscience votes are not allowed. This leads to nothing but a dictatorship.

Helene Lesage

Bellerive

Minority dictatorship

THE three tiers of our democratically elected governments have given the pulp mill the go-ahead subject to stringent conditions. The Greens have the audacity to scream the process is undemocratic while they themselves are destroying democracy as we have known it by trying to govern from a minority.

J.D. Dillon

Alonnah

Time to go

SUE Neales states that Premier Paul Lennon and Minister Jim Cox are likely to retire early next year (Mercury, September 29). I believe a quote from Macbeth would be appropriate: ''Stand not upon the order of your going, but go at once.''

Brian P. Khan

Newstead

Learn from others

EVEN a cursory glance at the problems now being faced in Britain and Europe should be enough to persuade any government here that African and Moslem immigration into Australia should be stopped.

Rob Sinclair

Sandy Bay

Helping hand

SHIRLEY Els makes an excellent case for increasing aid to countries in the developing world (Letters, October 8) but I'm sure she didn't mean to. She would prefer to criticise conditions rather than do something about it. I have been to developing countries, been robbed, experienced civil wars and seen the benefits that aid programs I was working on have made. We need more aid and support, not more criticism.

Paul Duncombe

Sandy Bay

Life with no doctor

AS a resident of the Orford-Triabunna area I have one question for the Minister of Health. How would she feel if a member of her family were involved in an accident in our area, an ambulance was called but it needed it doctor and clinical nurse to stabilise the patient before being able to be airlifted or driven to hospital? With no doctor or nurse, lives could be put at risk. Would she please help our wonderful and dedicated doctor to stay here?

Margaret Young

Triabunna

STING IN THE TAIL

The way the polls are looking, the Howard Government needs a triple bypass -- not just the Kingston bypass.

urn:contentItem:59NC-82C1-F0JP-W52N-00000-00Letters to the Editor2013-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 11Letters to the Editor

TALKING POINT The IPCC didn't link warming with extreme weather

EVEN the latest report from the

Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change backed away from the link between warming and so-called extreme weather events. Why then is just about every commentary-based ABC program still promoting the

opposite viewpoint? Sometimes they even cite the IPCC as the source for this view when what they say is the opposite of what was reported.

How much longer must the public be forced to sponsor an organisation that appears to be more concerned with a single ideological viewpoint than facts and data or allowing other views to be expressed?

James Hein, Hackney, SA

NOW that former US vice-president Al Gore has bought into the NSW

bushfires, courtesy of the ABC, it is time for a reality check. Planet Earth's climate is not, and never has been,

static. It is in a constant state of flux. There are many examples to demonstrate this.

Perhaps the most dramatic in recent times (on a planetary timescale) began with the end of the last Ice Age 20,000 years ago. In the period from then to about 10,000 years ago, the estimated increase in global median temperatures was 8C and the rise in sea levels was 140m. This cut off Tasmania from the mainland. During this time, human intervention and carbon emissions were not relevant.

W. D. Kavanagh, Macleay Island, Qld

I AGREE with Geoffrey Luck's letter arguing for water-bombing aircraft (24/10). In Spain recently, I witnessed them bombing a large forest fire in the mountains. What struck me was how quickly these planes returned with another load and how much water they are able to carry.

I presume the official reluctance to purchase them must be related to our comparatively few reservoirs and

accessible rivers.

Richard Zweck, Buderim, Qld

PRIME Minister Tony Abbott insulted the UN and several international studies when he said that those who suggest a link between climate change and an impending increase in the severity and occurrence of natural disasters such as the NSW fires are talking through their hats.

With the greatest respect, I believe that on this issue, the Prime Minister is speaking out of his backside.

Brian Cavanagh, Moorooka, Qld

ELOQUENTLY described by Edmund Capon in the ABC's series on Australian art is the 1851 picture by William Strutt, Black Thursday. The bushfire he brilliantly depicted destroyed a quarter of Victoria, killing 12 people and a million sheep in extreme temperatures. Was this a result of man-made climate change or fire that is an intrinsic part of our landscape going back thousands of years?

D. Mackay, Dungog, NSW

I WAS not surprised when Greens MP Adam Bandt in effect blamed the federal government for the bushfires. Yes, climate change is real, and the statistical likelihood of fires will rise. However, having a carbon tax does not appear to have diminished bushfire occurrence. Deliberate and unintentional lighting of fires is a significant contributor as evidenced by proximity to populated areas.

While the Greens may have an apocalyptic view of the future, the political temperature seems to be disproportionate to actual temperatures.

M. Gordon, Flynn, ACT

IT'S quite simple, really. Yes, we have always had bushfires. That's because of the volatile nature of much of our flora, combined with our climate -- hot, dry summers. Climate change will result in longer, hotter summers. The result? More, fiercer fires.

While we're there, flood-prone areas will experience more frequent flooding. How many once-in-a-100-year events have we experienced over the past few years? It's not rocket science; it's climate science.

Judy Crozier, Preston, Vic

Sea ice at the poles can't be compared

THE fact that record sea ice extent in the Antarctic is far outweighed by the decline in sea ice in the Arctic, while correct, disguises the fact that 90 per cent of Earth's ice is in the Antarctic (``Record ice cover in Antarctica'', 24/10). This is because the North Pole is situated in ocean whereas the South Pole is on a continent covered by up to 3km of ice.

Perhaps the sea ice extent in the Arctic is no longer declining because, according to the US National Snow and Ice Data Centre, its September 2013 sea ice extent is the highest since 2007. The sea ice extent in the Arctic can be moderated by volcanic activity under its relatively shallow ocean and this apparently happened earlier this century.

Brent Walker, Killcare, NSW

THE revelation that there is record ice cover in Antarctica must be devastating news for the Greens whose whole raison d'etre is dependent on the opposite result. Perhaps Adam Bandt would like to credit Tony Abbott for this latest phenomenon too.

Ian Mastin, Woodgate Beach, Qld

Union inquiry needed

KAYE Darveniza makes an important point in light of guilty pleas recently entered by former Labor Party national president Michael Williamson to charges of corrupt conduct as boss of the Health Services Union (``Please Mr Abbott, clean up the unions for sake of members'', 24/10).

The fall from grace of such a senior Labor figure confirms the need for a wide-ranging royal commission of inquiry into the trade union movement.

The terms of inquiry should focus on at least four areas: allegations of corruption; corrupt conduct; corporate governance across the sector; and the extent to which the law and practice (in areas such as union elections) encourage or enable corrupt conduct.

The virtual lock-step relationship between trade unions and politics at the highest level makes such an inquiry imperative. Bill Shorten's elevation to Labor leader, with AWU support, reminds us of the political clout wielded by union bosses.

James Miller, Woolloomooloo, NSW

Correct on clap trap

ALANNAH MacTiernan's commentary is a fitting example of why she is so respected on both sides of the house in Western Australia (``Postmodern clap trap rules in schools'', 24/10). Her claim ``a few hundred academics and mid-ranking bureaucrats who prioritise their own careers over the literacy of our children'' should be believed because the lady knows what she is talking about.

The widening gulf between rich and poor in this country can possibly be linked to literacy (and numeracy) decline among those parents who failed to learn under the clap-trap scheme who are now unable to teach their children any better.

Kudos to the principal of Challis and the teachers who embraced truth rather than bow to the bureaucracy of the local education desk occupiers.

Frank Wright, Cottesloe, WA

Weathering the gas crisis

THE story ``Seeney pours water on LNG compo'' (24/10) illustrates the need to make clear the Australian Industry Group's position on the gas

crisis. Our focus is to lift supply barriers threatening gas availability and to find ways for industry to weather the rise in prices.

We are not advocating handouts but proposing solutions to these critical problems and highlighting the risk that poor policy responses may be responsible for adding costs on industry. This includes a national interest test which would give greater consideration before the export of gas from new or extended facilities is approved.

It is the lack of such consideration by former governments, not business decisions by gas users, that has helped create the risks we now face. If supply is uncertain and the price spike is permanent, the rational response may be to relocate future investment -- and eventually, production -- to the US and the Middle East. The loss of high value-added industries is unlikely to leave Australia better off.

We think there should be a sensible public discussion of the merits of all policy actions and all non-actions in relation to the emerging dynamics in the gas market. We have been pushing for this discussion for some time and are pleased these issues are now getting some attention.

Innes Willox, chief executive, Australian Industry Group, Forrest, ACT

Cut perks for former PMs

THE recent attention on entitlements for sitting parliamentarians emphasises the need for a thorough review of the entire system.

With Tony Abbott urging us to be lifters not leaners, let our elected representatives start by setting a good example. And let's look further than sitting parliamentarians. Why are all former prime ministers afforded the generous entitlements they enjoy? Is this a lifetime free ride on our economy? Former PMs deserve some recognition for their service, but they all have comfortable superannuation. I believe cutting their perks would set a good example.

Lyn Wilson, Southport, Qld

I HAVE rarely read a better solution to a political problem (``Entitlement enlightenment'', 23/10). Tony Abbott should read and implement Janet

Albrechtsen's advice.

Alan Cole, Mt Warren Park, Qld

Sad saga about Carr

THE resignation of Bob Carr as a senator is the end to a sad saga in Australia's political history in which gross abuse of voter trust has taken place.

Originally hatched as a master plan by the Labor Party to boost its standing in government, it has ended in tears for all concerned.

By revelling in the role of foreign minister but being unable to commit as a member of the opposition, Carr has failed the character test. To be elected to parliament is a great honour. Unfortunately, Carr does not seem to appreciate this.

Peter D. Surkitt, Hampton, Vic

LAST POST

How inconvenient that Australia's carbon tax has only improved the sea ice cover in Antarctica and not extinguished the phenomenon of El Nino bushfires after La Nina wet years, that have been occurring for millennia.

Bryan Connor, Cloncurry, Qld

The global warming catastrophists keep trying to find the missing heat in face of temperatures not having risen in lockstep with CO2 emissions. Perhaps the record Antarctic sea ice is actually dry ice (frozen CO2).

Mike Young, Swanbourne, WA

Wouldn't it be a bit more relevant to the national interest for our soldiers to be trained in firefighting rather than using live ordnance to cause destruction in fire-prone areas?

John James, Claremont, WA

While Tony Abbott is fighting bushfires, it would be pleasing to know that Adam Bandt is saving the planet by taking cold showers, riding a bicycle and living in an unheated house.

David Barber, Kew, Vic

Bob Carr says Labor lacked cunning. No such problem for the crafty, sweet-talking smoothie himself, who conned us into believing his intention was to remain in the Senate for the long term.

George Fishman, Vaucluse, NSW

It was always obvious Bob Carr was an opportunist and it has been Labor's worst kept secret that he would resign. Eighteen months on the public teat.

Claire Jolliffe, Buderim, Qld

Only six weeks into the job and Treasurer Joe Hockey is already being accused of failure and creative accounting by D. J. Fraser (Letters, 24/10). It would seem Fraser's insight is inversely proportional to the number of times his thoughts are published.

Peter M. Wargent, Mosman, NSW

The idea of a website showing politicians' expense claims is a good idea from Janet Albrechtsen (``Entitlement enlightenment'', 23/10). It's called common sense, something sadly lacking for the past few years.

Mark Postle, Mundubbera, Qld

Nice pun, Margaret Pritchard (Letters, 24/10), but don't let facts get in the way. In Barrie Cassidy's words, ``It is a bit odd to claim this is a political favour -- or any favour at all -- when I am the one doing the favour. It is a job that carries no fee and no perks of any kind.''

Monty Arnhold, Port Melbourne, Vic

Campbell Newman has the courage to act against bikie gangs but hasn't the gumption to bring in daylight saving which would reduce power bills, saving an hour of electricity every night to help the economy and reduce our carbon footprint.

Brian Doherty, Beenleigh, Qld

urn:contentItem:4580-9W70-0197-5173-00000-00<published>2000-02-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FINANCE; Pg. 24</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Breeding incubators play the 10 per cent game</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MARY HUHN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IT'S been a wild couple of weeks in the US Internet world among some of the high-tech world's biggest players.</p><p nitf:lede="true">AOL has bid for Time Warner, Microsoft's Bill Gates has named himself chief software architect and handed the reins to company president Steve Ballmer and while Exite@Homes chief Tom "TJ" Jarmolek has passed his CEO baton to Excite founder George Bell. </p><p nitf:lede="true"> Elsewhere, Transmeta, a Silicon Valley start-up backed by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, billionaire investor George Soros and Linus Torvalds -- better known as the father of the Linux operating system -- has launched Crusoe, a new chip which could give Intel a run for its money.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> That's what's happened a month into the new millennium with only a fraction of the big players. Y2K is shaping up as the year of the Internet shake-out.</p><p>Already, unprofitable e-tailers are reassessing strategies after holiday marketing spending sprees failed to affect the bottom line.</p><p> E-tailers such as Value America, Beyond.com and Boo.com, have made staff cuts.</p><p> Meanwhile, venture capitalists are using a larger filter before pouring money into a company.</p><p> So while we have all these dire predictions, why are Internet incubators flourishing?</p><p> Even though venture capitalists have taken a heavier hand in directing the strategies of their investments, incubators take a more active role and offer burgeoning companies management, administrative and strategic support, as well as technology expertise.</p><p> The incubators are small enough to properly care for their young, breeding about 12 firms a year. In exchange for these services, the incubators can get a 30 per cent to 60 per cent cut of the company.</p><p> Incubators have been around for a long time, but the number entering the Internet world has grown in the US and in Europe.</p><p> More than 50 have been launched in the US in the past two years. In Europe, incubators have grown from a handful to 100 in six months, the majority in London.</p><p> For the most part, incubators are going ahead as planned, even in the face of change.</p><p> But Paul Alofs, a former MP3.com exec and music marketing whiz, pulled the plug on his Canadian incubator before it even began, blaming the changing economics of the Internet.</p><p> "There will be more pressure on Internet start-ups to not only generate revenue but profits, and I think there will be Internet start-up deals available that will be profitable," Alofs told a Canadian newspaper.</p><p> So why the proliferation in such an unsure market? The model resembles a music label that invests in hundreds of artists, hoping one will catch fire internationally.</p><p> "You just have to figure if they hit with 10 per cent of their investments, they're way ahead of the game," Credit Lyonnais Securities analyst Richard Read said.</p><p> Richard Koffler, the head of incubator Koffler Ventures, said he was placing his bets in niche areas of the Internet and wasn't necessarily looking for a company with a $US5 billion valuation, but one with more modest growth.</p><p> There were 300,000 dotcom business plans floating around in the US, he said.</p><p> Is there room for all? Not even close. Most of them are garbage, but there's still a lot of stuff with good ideas.</p><p> In the end, he sees the plethora of companies being hand- held by incubators as a good thing, thinking of them as all these experiments taking place.</p><p> "No one really knows what the next wave of applications and technology will bring," Internet.com analyst Luke Fronefield said.</p><p> "Portals were the first wave, then e-tailers, and now were seeing a focus on B2B and wireless."</p><p> Interestingly enough, incubators like CMGI cover the majority of sub-sectors.</p><p> Besides allowing incubators to share support, CMGI encourages its incubated companies to work together.</p><p> The heads of all its companies meet regularly to discuss plans and projects which could lead to strategic partnerships.</p><p> Once these companies move out of beta into launching, analysts expect these types of relationships to be the next step in the new generation of incubators.</p><p>New York-based Doublespace has entered the Internet incubator space with three new cyber-projects.</p><p>Doublespace principle Scott Osman said the company had been helping Internet firms build brands for five years, and it seemed natural to become an incubator.</p><p> He remains undaunted by the prospects of a shake-out.</p><p> "There are so many great ideas that are still being developed. We've only scratched the surface," he said.</p><p> Analysts for the most part agreed there were sectors that hadn't been Internet-ised, yet.</p><p> Brian Bedol, who recently co-founded Fusient Media Ventures in Manhattan, will focus on funding content players for this broadband age.</p><p> His incubator will succeed because they're focusing on the next wave of value.</p><p> "Content is somewhere around the bicycle or Model T in the Internet life cycle," he said. But he's not ignoring any shake-out.</p><p> "Everyone is going to be affected," Bedol says, noting such an event wouldn't be a totally bad thing.</p><p> "It's like a forest fire and you'll get fresh growth out of it."</p><p><email normalizedValue="mailto:mhuhn@nypost.com">mhuhn@nypost.com</email>. </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGB0-TXN5-R2CN-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 12REGULAR SHORTS

NEW FIRE ALERT IN CHINA

BEIJING, Sunday: Thick black smoke billowed over the Ergun River dividing the Soviet Union from Chinese Inner Mongolia as Chinese firefighters girded for an advancing Soviet fire while battling persistent forest fires in north-eastern China. The official Xinhua News Agency reported today that a forest fire in the Soviet Baikal area posed a serious threat to virgin forests in Inner Mongolia. A Forestry Ministry dispatch from the area said strong winds could carry the fire over the 150-metre wide river and that top priority had been given to keeping the fire out of China. - Reuter

SOLIDARITY LEADERS ARRESTED

WARSAW, Sunday: Polish police have arrested two Solidarity leaders in the north-west city of Szczecin, bringing to six the number of Solidarity officials detained in the past 24 hours, relatives of the two men said. Marian Jurczyk, a former deputy chairman of the banned trade union, and Stanislaw Wadolowski, a member of the former Solidarity leadership for the Szczecin region, were arrested at their homes and taken to the city's main police station, they said. -

AFP

TEN DIE IN DOMINICAN FLOODS

SANTO DOMINGO, Sunday: Heavy rain in the Dominican Republic swelled rivers and caused flooding that left 10 people dead and forced about 200 others from their homes, according to government officials. - AP

HART ADMITS 'MISJUDGMENT'

WASHINGTON, Sunday: The former presidential candidate Mr Gary Hart has sent a letter to campaign workers and supporters blaming the collapse of his campaign on his own "thoughtlessness and misjudgment", according to a published report. In a one-page letter mailed to thousands of staffers, volunteers and contributors, Mr Hart said it was his mistakes that caused the campaign to fall apart three weeks ago, The Washington Post reported. - AP

AIDS TOP OF SUMMIT AGENDA

NEW YORK, Sunday: The killer disease AIDS will be a top agenda topic for President Reagan and the six Western leaders meeting in Venice next week for the economic summit, The New York Times said. The leaders of the seven leading Western powers are expected to declare AIDS a world health problem and call for more international co-operation against it through the World Health Organisation. - Reuter

GREENLAND'S LEADER TOPPLED

COPENHAGEN, Sunday: Mr Jonathan Motzfeldt has been replaced as head of Greenland's Government after leading the country since it attained semi-independence from Denmark in 1979, Danish radio reported. In a development described by Danish media as a "political coup", a new leader of the ruling social democratic Siumut party was elected while Mr Motzfeldt was on his way back to the capital of Nuuk from a visit to southern Greenland. Mr Lars Emil Johansen was elected new leader. - AP

SLIP LEADS TO DOUBLE MURDER

NEW DELHI, Sunday: A man who slipped and fell on a rain-splattered street in southern India stabbed an amused bystander, but was stabbed back - and both men died, the United News of India (UNI) reported. One of the men was hurrying to his home in Avaniapuram, southern Kerala state, in torrential rain when he slipped and fell, UNI said. A bystander laughed loudly, the news agency said. So the man who fell rushed home, found a knife, ran back to the street and stabbed the bystander. "Not to be outdone," said UNI, "the victim managed to plunge the knife into his assailant." - AFP

MONKS CLASH WITH POLICE

SEOUL, Sunday: Some 500 Buddhist monks shouting "Down with military dictatorship" fought riot police with fists during an anti-government demonstration, witnesses said. One riot policeman was kicked and punched severely before being released by the monks at a Buddhist temple in eastern Seoul, the witnesses said. There were no reports of arrests during the one-hour clash. - AP

RATS PUT FRENCHMAN IN COURT

LONDON, Sunday: A Frenchman who brought two pet rats into Britain in his coat pocket was fined the equivalent of $A1,148 for breaking anti-rabies laws. "We had been together for eight months. They were always with me," Jean Paul Fiorentino of Chambery, south-eastern France, told magistrates in Dover. The rats were found by a customs officer when Fiorentino arrived in England. They were later destroyed. - Reuter

urn:contentItem:7VCT-22P1-2R6N-62HW-00000-00Fire cooks up2009-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisAPg. 4Fire cooks upThe Canberra Times

Walk through bushland after a fire, and there's likely to be a whiff of rotting onions in the air, NSW National Parks ecologist Dr Andrew Claridge says.

It's a pungent smell to the human nose, but signals an irresistibly delicious underground cache of freshly smoked truffles for ground-foraging native animals like bandicoots and potoroos.

"Some of the digging activity to get at these truffles could only be described as frenzied. We don't know if fire enhances the flavour as well as the aroma, but the animals are pretty keen to get at them," Claridge says.

There are around 2400 Australian truffle-like species of fruiting fungi (compared to a few hundred in Europe) but most of these don't exude an alluring fragrance like France's famous gourmet black truffles.

"Imagine you've left an onion sealed in a plastic container for a month and it's gone off. The smell that would assault your nostrils when you whipped off the lid is pretty much the same smell that seems to drive bandicoots and potoroos crazy for truffles."

It seems fire may release or intensify the aroma of these underground fungi as a kind of survival mechanism for the species. The animals sniff out, dig up and eat the intensely aromatic truffles, spreading spores across the landscape in their scats and creating new truffle colonies in their wake. "That's the neat way nature works. The bandicoots and potoroos critters that are basically a truffle-seeking nose on legs get a food reward for turning over the soil after a fire. They're the engineers of the forest ecosystem, they keep it healthy."

Claridge recently played a leading role in one of Australia's biggest temperate forest fire research programs, studying the recovery of native plants and animals after fire in Ben Boyd National Park on the NSW south- east coast. Last winter, parks staff conducted a prescribed burn across 1900ha of the park, after a 12-year research program led by Claridge showed populations of southern brown bandicoots, long- nosed bandicoots and long-nosed potoroos were in decline.

"We'd assumed that if we got rid of foxes in the park with a 1080 baiting program, the native animals would thrive. We got the fox population down to unprecedented low levels, but despite the program's success, the bandicoot and potoroo populations were just idling along.

They weren't bouncing back in the way we'd expected, so there had to be other factors at work."

A survey of park vegetation with CSIRO scientists, measuring litter layers, canopy cover and native shrub species, showed there had also been a decline in habitat complexity with the loss of ground cover and understorey plants like banksias, hakeas and acacias.

"These plants were reaching the end of their cycle. They were dying, and they need fire to regenerate. The understorey wasn't providing the dense habitat the animals needed."

A previous study in the mid- 1990s by CSIRO's former Division of Wildlife and Ecology established very different fire regimes were needed to regenerate the habitat of red-necked wallabies, eastern grey kangaroos, swamp wallabies, ground parrots, eastern bristle- birds and long-nosed potoroos.

The research, undertaken in Nadgee Nature Reserve near Eden in south-east NSW, was the first fire study of its kind in Australia and was headed by the late Dr Alan Newsome and Dr Peter Catling. Their research findings suggested six different species- specific fire management "rules" were needed for prescribed burns.

The CSIRO team warned against a one-size-fits-all approach to prescribed burning. They had developed a system of "decision rules" to guide burning, based on combinations of differing habitat requirements, vegetation and time elapsed since previous fires. The "wrong fire regime" could be counter-productive, degrading forest ecosystems and destroying habitat. Claridge describes this 30-year fire management project as "incredibly valuable, just brilliant". The research prompted his decision to do a prescribed burn in Ben Boyd National Park.

"Their research showed bandicoots and potoroos started popping up around 10 years after their habitat was burned. That's when the regenerating understorey is at its thickest, and the animals thrive because they can escape into the understorey and hide from predators."

Mapping and designing the Ben Boyd prescribed burn took "months and months of careful planning to get it right", he says.

Staff safety and achieving a mosaic burn "with large areas of unburnt habitat" were non-negotiable priorities. "We didn't want to raze the forest to a charred mess, and we had lives to protect. We were literally playing with fire, and the outcome could be good or bad, depending on how well we'd prepared. It could burn too hot and not leave any patches as wildlife refuges, or it could be a complete fizzer if weather conditions weren't right. There was a lot of risk to consider and manage."

Getting it right and making it safe involved a team of more than 20 staff, poring over a bank of information drawn from detailed park topography maps, long-range weather forecasts, computer modelling, vegetation data and details of previous fires in the region. All this data was needed to identify fire control lines, problematic areas and safety zones.

During the fire and in the days after it, Claridge's team set up 30 infra-red digital cameras at fixed points in burned and unburnt areas to film the movements of bandicoots and potoroos.

The cameras are used in conjuction with olfactory bait stations a small steel container scented with (what else?) French truffle oil. Claridge has pioneered this combination of truffle oil and digital technology to monitor wildlife, successfully using it to replace traps and sticky tubes that gather animal hair for analysis.

"It's less stressful for the animals than being hauled out of a trap. We can actually see how they behave in the wild, get a better sense of how they interact with the habitat."

The cameras showed bandicoots and potoroos responding to their "improved" habitat, actively foraging in the burned areas. But a massive high intensity fire, in which a large section of bushland was burned, would be likely to have a less benign impact on plants and animals. In a book co- written with the late John Seebeck and University of Tasmania zoologist Dr Randy Rose, Claridge explains research shows some native animals bettongs and bandicoots can survive low- intensity fire by remaining in their nest sites "until the very last minute". The animals move ahead of the fire until they encounter an unburnt patch of habitat. If no unburnt habitat was found, they "doubled back through the flames to the safety of burnt ground".

Claridge writes that after an experimental fire in Western Australia, animals were observed "sitting on burnt ground, seemingly dazed, near their original nest sites". Survival was low, possibly because the exposed animals became easy prey for foxes.

The impact of the Ben Boyd burn is still being monitored through data collected by the remote cameras. So far, results seem to indicate a well-managed fire regime can be used successfully to regenerate habitat and revive declining populations.

But there are still big information gaps. Studies of how fire and Australia's ecosystems interact and possibly depend on each other are rare, and pitifully under-funded, despite predictions of a dramatically increased bushfire risk as a result of current climate change trends.

"Fire is always a big risk to manage when you're doing research," Claridge says. "There's still so much we don't know about the way we should go about introducing fire into the landscape. Our research results are promising, but indicate timing and planning are critical when you're burning for ecological reasons. We can only understand these things if we're in fire research for the long haul."

urn:contentItem:4P84-VBT0-TXN5-R2H3-00000-00Thai high in Bangkok1999-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisTRAVELPg. 82Thai high in BangkokShop till you drop, with bargains for everyonePaul Gogarty

Bangkok is alive 24 hours a day. Paul Gogarty runs the rule over some of the high spots.

DON'T MISS

Grand Palace: The walled complex, with its extravagant temples, glittering palaces, golden stupas, monkey gods, 6m demons and other mythical statuary and frescoes, deserves several hours of your time, if not two visits. It is particularly beautiful when seen from the river at night. Open daily 8.30am-3.50pm; admission $5.20.

National Museum and Gallery: You won't have time for everything here. Pavilion No 1 tells the country's history from 1238, but Gallery 17 is the big draw, with its exquisite royal palanquins and gaudy carriages five storeys tall. Open 9am-4pm Wednesday-Sunday; admission $1.80. The adjacent National Gallery, which displays traditional and contemporary art, is open the same hours and admission is $1.30.

Chatuchak Weekend Market: One of the world's great markets. Operates Saturday and Sunday; Sunday is better because there is less traffic. Arrive at about 10am when it is still not too busy. Allow yourself two or three hours to trawl the Thai furniture and antiques, bird cages, food, Burmese handicrafts, carpets, second-hand porcelain, sarongs, coolie hats, watches, opium pipes, wall hangings, amulets, clothes and shoes. It is mostly covered so you won't get fried and there are plenty of food and drink stalls to dive into.

Aaron Shrine: The four-headed multi-armed Brahma is believed to be the best source of good luck in the city. A forest fire of incense skirts the railings alongside a mountain of marigold garlands and lotus flowers. The World Trade Centre in the city's best one-stop shopping centre is just across the street where you can cool off by ice skating if the air conditioning's not strong enough for you.

Bailout Sky Hotel observation deck: A see-through external wall lift rockets you 77 floors in one minute, 20 seconds for $1.70. It is 2,060 steps and a one-hour climb if the lifts break down. Good information panels at the top and telescope stations offer close-ups of the 360-degree views across the city.

War Foe: The oldest and biggest temple in Bangkok, with the country's largest reclining buddha and most substantial collection of buddha images. Open 9am-5pm daily; admission 90¢. It is also the national centre for traditional Thai medicine. Massage is available at $3 an hour, using traditional herbs. You can also do one-week and 10-day massage courses.

Wat Arun Pagoda: 82m high, decorated with ceramic tiles and multicoloured porcelain, located on the west bank of the river. Known as the Temple of Dawn but most glorious when seen from the eastern bank of the river at sunset. Open daily 7am-5pm; admission 45¢.

Jim Thompson's House: 6 Soi Kasemsan 2, Rama 1 Road. Traditional Thai house containing Asian artifacts collected by the mysterious American who revitalised Thailand's silk industry, only to disappear in 1967. Open daily 9am-4.30pm; admission $4.

Long-tailed boat ride: Hire one for a couple of hours and tour the houses on stilts and orchid gardens along the side canals. WHERE TO EAT

Thai food stalls are great for grazing you'll get a meal of soup, fish, fried rice and water for under $2.

BEST buys are clothes, traditional crafts, wickerwork, jewellery and pirated goods. With devaluation and endless sales, department stores can be as cheap as markets these days.

Chatuchak Weekend Market: Buy anything from a mongoose to a second-hand kimono.

The MBK Centre: (Mah Boon Krong), Siam Square, is where locals buy clothes, PlayStation games (about $1.30 each but you will need an adaptor), sports and electronic gadgetry. The World Trade Centre on Rajadamri Road is best for all-in-one shopping. Just wander. Discounts abound. Zen is good for general gifts and clothes.

Narayana Phand Pavilion: Opposite WTC, a government-subsidised craft centre (the biggest in Thailand). Thai silk, cotton, silverware, porcelain, Thai dolls, mother-of-pearl inlay, pewterware, wood carving, basketry.

Central Gems International: 232 Praram 5 Road, is the best and safest place to buy gems. An explanatory five-minute video is followed by a brief tour of the workshop floor where gems (mostly sapphire, ruby, garnet and emerald) are cut, polished and set in 18- and 14-carat gold. You can have jewellery made up in 24 hours. Sapphires cost from about $330. Expect to pay $1,300 for one set in a gold ring.IN THE KNOW

DIAL 1155 within Bangkok between 8am and midnight for the English-speaking Tourist Service Centre. The tourist police provide similar assistance on 1699.TIPS

TOUTS get up to 40 per cent commissions from shops, so if you are looking for a bargain, go alone.

Use only yellow and black licensed taxis. Be wary of unqualified tourist guides ask to see their licences.

Use an umbrella as shelter from the heat and the cloudbursts.

Avoid having goods shipped to your home address. It's risky.

Cover shoulders and wear long trousers/skirt to visit the temples, particularly the Grand Palace.

Illus: TOP SPOT: Temple of the Emerald Buddha. LANDMARK: The Peninsula Bangkok Hotel.

urn:contentItem:4B0X-G300-015H-9498-00000-00<published>2003-11-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WEEKEND; Pg. 78</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tiwi artists go modern</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Joerg Andersch</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Tokwapi (everything) Tiwi</p><p nitf:lede="true">Art Mob Gallery, Castray Esplanade, Battery Point</p><p nitf:lede="true">Price range: $300 to $2430</p><p nitf:lede="true">IN the forefront of Aboriginal art, Tiwi artists are slowly shedding the mantle of traditional practices.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It was just a matter of time before Aboriginal artists came right in the thick of the creation of contemporary art practices. This exhibition is a fabulous mixture of paintings, sculpture, and printmaking.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Certainly the imagery is generally based within traditional concepts, but when you see the etchings, you'll know what I mean. Urban Aboriginal artists have now for some time straddled the limits of both western and traditional Aboriginal art, and personalities such as the late Lin Onus or Western Australia's Sally Morgan have cut their niche in Australian art history.</p><p>Now traditional areas, which have a fine record of providing art since the 1960s (and the Tiwi communities of Bathurst and Melville Islands are just some of them) have embraced technology in the best possible way. It is pioneering stuff, riding the crest of a wave, metaphorically speaking, by grasping and joining two cultural practices, and coming up with a superb result.A Storm in a Teacup</p><p>Mr Woobys, Salamanca Square</p><p>Price range: $90 to $140</p><p>WELL-KNOWN ceramist and printmaker Carolyn Canty is currently showing at Mr Woobys restaurant-cum-gallery.</p><p> Mr Woobys has long been a staunch supporter of artists in the Sullivans Cove precinct, and is one of the few places that will give young, as yet untried, art practitioners a chance to show their work.</p><p> But for every "young gun" airing their work, Mr Woobys keeps the standard by also showing the work of Tasmania's premier artists.</p><p> Canty is not only well known as a practitioner, but also a leading teacher of her profession, and indeed practises what she preaches.</p><p> In keeping with the venue, Canty has created a series of artworks featuring food iconographically. Using a combination of techniques, such as embossing, printing, and ceramic detail, Canty has produced a marvellous array of plaques. Her subtle use of lettering as texture also adds to the feel of these items, and if you are looking for art with an unusual edge, don't miss this exhibition.The Spring Exhibition</p><p>Expressions of Interest Gallery, Bothwell</p><p>Price range: $120 to $560</p><p>FEEL like a spring excursion? Well, Bothwell is a comfortable distance for a weekend afternoon trip, and the countryside is absolutely glorious at present.</p><p> When the Hibiscus Gallery in Sandy Bay closed its doors a couple of years ago, and subsequently the Affordable Art group at Walch's, many mid-range painters were disenfranchised.</p><p> By mid-range I mean artists who largely work as hobbyists, don't charge an arm and a leg for their work and simply enjoy showing the results of their vocation.</p><p> The Expressions of Interest Gallery at Bothwell became a real alternative for these artists, and several times each year, the gallery is home to some substantial exhibitions featuring this sort of work. It is pleasant work, featuring botanical themes, land and seascapes, views of the highlands in winter, and in general is soundly produced and well presented.</p><p> Mini highlights are a floral study of Camellias by Margaret Parham, and a highlands snow scene by Jennifer Eaton. Radio personality Bob Cure's misty landscape also makes quite an impact, helping keep a fine level of expertise running throughout the show.Student Exhibition</p><p>Rosny College and Art Space, Clarence City</p><p>Price range: POA</p><p>EVERY now and then this column handles exhibitions from the state or private education system, and Rosny College's final year art results have been too good to miss.</p><p> As the college sets fairly high standards and elicited prize donations from two of Hobart's art-related businesses, the result is great, and the exhibition is well worth the attention of the wider public. The college has agreed to let the exhibition -- usually a short-lived affair -- remain on the walls until next Thursday. If you are interested in what next year's intake at the University's School of Art could possibly foreshadow, feel free to visit the college.</p><p> College art has the tendency to be far less inhibited when compared to the work the same students will perform under the umbrella of art schools. Unfortunately the exertion of often-tighter discipline also somewhat shrinks the exuberance of spirit -- many talented students finding the process extremely limiting.</p><p> Perhaps it's natural selection at work, but it often disguises conformity to institutional pressures, which takes a strong and stubborn character to resist in order to survive the process. Please try to see this exhibition, as the best work represents as yet unfettered vitality.Nyrrippi Art</p><p>Long Gallery, Salamanca Arts Centre</p><p>Price range: $60 to $16,000</p><p>THE Nyrrippi community of Central Australia is making its mark on the wider art market.</p><p> Located 300km northwest of Alice Springs, the Nyrrippi community is adding to the national pool of indigenous art, and it is the first time Tasmania is seeing the work. Art broker and curator Tim Crosby is presenting this body of paintings at the Long Gallery, with the exhibition lasting a week, closing next Saturday.</p><p> Collectors of indigenous art now have a new source to ponder, as the national art market is steadily growing. Indeed, from what I'm told, Aboriginal art represents the largest and most successful art market in Australia, outselling all other forms of art.Forest/Fire</p><p>Devonport Regional Gallery</p><p>Price range: POA</p><p>JUST a short note should readers journey to the north of the state, that Lorraine Biggs and Kay Jensen are showing paintings and ceramics respectively at the Regional Gallery in Devonport.</p><p> Biggs's use of rag paper and pastels to create a series of images from within the old growth forests is breathtaking, and in partnering with ceramist Kay Jensen, makes a superb show. Jensen's elegant vessels are featuring delicate carvings, and her glazes from the natural environment are something to behold.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:44SC-GMC0-015G-S3Y7-00000-00<published>2001-12-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 8</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BLACK CHRISTMAS: YOUR COMMUNITY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Affected areas</p><p nitf:lede="true"> * BLUE MOUNTAINS: 19</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 19 homes destroyed; others damaged by fire and water.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Suburbs worst affected: Warrimoo, Springwood, Grandview Rd, Lawson Rd. Mt Hall fire has burned 7500ha. Property threatened at Wentworth Falls and east to the Nepean River. State of Emergency declared.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>* HAWKESBURY: 14</p><p> 14 homes destroyed; others damaged. Graham Creek fire (8300ha burned) active on southern and eastern flanks. Property threatened. Upper Baulkham Hills region may be threatened if fire jumps the Hawkesbury River. State of Emergency declared.</p><p>  * PENRITH/BLACKTOWN/LIVERPOOL: 4</p><p> Four homes lost; others damaged.</p><p> 11,000ha fire being controlled by RFS and NSWFB officers. State of Emergency declared.</p><p>  * WARRAGAMBA: 30</p><p> "The (looters) just took what they could grab. Lollies, cameras and films, whatever they could carry." Margaret Dobson, Warragamba Kiosk. 30 homes and 10 shops destroyed.</p><p>  * SHOALHAVEN: 40</p><p> Up to 40 homes destroyed. Properties at risk at Falls Creek, St Georges Basin and Wandaidian. Fire consumed up to 1400 ha. State of emergency declared.</p><p>  * SUTHERLAND: 27</p><p> "Today, it's snowing ashes" -- Pat Kennedy, Boronia Crescent, Heathcote. 27 homes, one school, four factories and a conference centre destroyed. Waterfall, Helensbury and Stanwell Tops worst affected. State of Emergency declared.</p><p>  * WOLLONDILLY/CAMPBELLTOWN:</p><p> Appin Rd fire has burned 5000ha and combined with Holsworthy and Darkes Forest fire. Heading towards Wollongong escarpment. State of emergency declared.</p><p>  * WOLLONGONG: 10</p><p> Up to to 10 homes destroyed. Fires covering area of 39,000ha. State of emergency declared. Mining assets threatend by fire at Bourke River.</p><p>  * GOSFORD:</p><p> Several properties destroyed, including two sheds and motor vehicles. Spencer region fire broken containment lines. Potential threat to properties north of Wisemans Ferry Rd, east of Peats Ridge Rd and Iron Bark Rd. State of Emergency declared.</p><p>  * GRAFTON:</p><p> Property losses. Fire at Blackadder Creek still active. State of emergency declared.</p><p>  * NARROMINE</p><p> Claggers Spring fire blacked out 32,680ha. Hotspots still being monitored. State of emergency declared.</p><p>Donation and Help Lines</p><p>RTA road closures hotline: 132 701</p><p> Natural Disaster Hotline for fires and welfare help: 1800 227 228</p><p> Insurance Disaster Response Organisation: 1300 363 683</p><p> State Disaster Recovery Centre: 9683 2388</p><p> To make a credit card donation, call the Salvation Army: 13 32 30</p><p> A and B platoons of the NSW Fire Brigade: 9318 4865</p><p>National Australia Bank customers financially impacted by fires: 132 265</p><p> ANZ customers financially impacted by fires: 131 314</p><p> CBA customers financially impacted by fires: 132 224</p><p>Commonwealth Insurance customers: 132 420</p><p> NRMA Insurance customers: 131 123</p><p>GIO Insurance customers: 131 446</p><p> AAMI Insurance customers: 132 244</p><p> To make a donation to the Wesley Mission appeal for the victims of bushfires: 1800 021 821</p><p>Don't drive here</p><p>WESTERN SYDNEY: Silverdale Rd is closed from Mulgoa Rd to Warragamba Dam. Mulgoa Rd is closed between Glenmore Park and St Thomas Road at Mulgoa.</p><p> ENGADINE: Princes Highway is closed southbound at Old Princes Highway.</p><p> HEATHCOTE: Heathcote Rd is closed between the Princes Highway and New Illawarra Rd.</p><p> NOWRA: Albatross Rd closed.</p><p> BLUE MOUNTAINS: Local road closures in the Warrimoo area. Exercise caution while driving along the Great Western Highway between Penrith and Springwood due to reduced visibility caused by smoke.</p><p> GULGONG: Gulgong Rd closed to Goolma.</p><p> HUNTER: Wisemans Ferry Rd is closed to Spencer (resident access only). Peats Ridge Rd is closed at Somersby.</p><p> SOUTHERN: The F6 Freeway was reopened at 5.30pm, with police imposing a 80 km/h speed limit at all times. However, there is still no public access to the Helensburgh turn-off or the Old Princes Highway. The Princes Highway is closed from Heathcote Rd at Engadine to Bulli Pass. Lawrence Hargrave Drive is closed at Stanwell Tops (access for residents only). Access to Wollongong is now available either via Appin Rd or from the Hume Highway, Picton Rd and Mt Keira Rd.</p><p> KURRAJONG: Blaxland Ridge Rd from Kurrajong to Putty Rd reopened. Putty Rd between Upper Colo Rd and Packer Rd is now closed due to poor visibility. Also, all train services from Sydney to the Illawarra line are terminating at Sutherland.</p><p>Weather forecast</p><p>Today</p><p>Dry. Areas of smoke haze</p><p>SYDNEY: 15 to 26C</p><p>LIVERPOOL: 13 to 29C</p><p>RICHMOND: 12 to 30C</p><p>Tomorrow</p><p>Dry.</p><p>SYDNEY: 19 to 29C</p><p>LIVERPOOL: 18 to 34C</p><p>RICHMOND: 18 to 35C</p><p>Sunday</p><p>Strong NW winds, then late southerly change. Risk of thunderstorm.</p><p>SYDNEY: 22 to 36C</p><p>LIVERPOOL: 21 to 39C</p><p>RICHMOND: 20 to 39C</p><p>A Total Fire Ban is in Force</p><p>The devastating facts</p><p>* More than 150 homes destroyed</p><p>* More than 100 fires burning across NSW</p><p>* Firestorms in at least three or four of the fires</p><p>* Fires burning in a ring from Yamba in the state's north, Eurobodalla in the far south and Narromine in the central west</p><p>* At least 40 fires started by arsonists</p><p>* More than 4000 firefighters on the ground</p><p>* 11,000 homes saved after being directly threatened</p><p>* About 10,000 homes expected to be without power until mid-next week</p><p>* 150,000ha of National Parks land devastated</p><p>* Power cuts have left some homes without running water</p><p>What to do if your house is threatened</p><p>* Wet the roof and garden</p><p>* Turn on sprinkler system (if you have one)</p><p>* Clear fallen leaves and branches from around the house</p><p>* Clear gutters</p><p>* Move flammable items (boxes, garden furniture) away from house</p><p>* Block downpipes and fill gutters with water</p><p>* Place wet towels and blankets against gaps under doors and windows</p><p>* Dress in protective clothing</p><p>* Fill baths, sinks and buckets with water</p><p>* If you intend to evacuate, plan well ahead of time where to stay and how to travel</p><p>* If staying go inside as fire front approaches and remain inside until the fire has passed</p><p>* Close heavy curtains, close shutters if you have them</p><p>* After the fire front has passed, patrol your property for spot fires started by flying embers</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
