urn:contentItem:4FC4-3T90-015G-S1NK-00000-00<published>2005-01-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>MAGAZINE; In my own words; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>In my own words … John Butler</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ROBYN DOREIAN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">At 29, this US-born musical soul is fulfilling his life-long dream to help the Australian arts scene and protect the environment through a combination of music and mind</p><p nitf:lede="true">My memories of growing up in Lomita in California, US, are of milking goats and playing army. We had a lot of animals, and I milked them before school. I wanted to be an army hero and used all the local backyards as military bases.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Moving to Pinjarra in Western Australia at 11 was the best thing that ever happened to me. I joked that my dad should get a place with a river in the backyard, and he did. The bush was my ultimate war scene, but it all stopped when I was 12 and fell in love. She was two years older, and when she saw my clubhouse with toy guns, I felt embarrassed and knew it was time to stop. That, along with my father insisting I wasn't going to die for an oil company.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>If I had to describe my teens in three words, they'd be isolation, rebellion and adventure. In Pinjarra, my American accent got me chased out of parties. I ran from many a fight. There was a lot of small-town racism, and I was determined not to be like them. I had Aboriginal friends and related to how they saw society - I felt just as much of an outcast as them. But we had good times, too. My friend, Michael, my girlfriend and I would go looking for caves, set up camp in tree hollows and swim.</p><p>From my father, who's Australian, I inherited discipline and business sense. He taught me to save and invest money, which helped my business [Butler co-owns Jarrah Records with West Australian folk band The Waifs]. From my mum, who's American, I inherited compassion and a giving nature. I love to share with both strangers and people I know. I also have her spacey humour.</p><p>It's not enough to be popular, have money and be successful. I started The JB Seed [a program awarding five $10,000 arts grants] to give something back. When I started out, West Australian arts grants helped me record Three [2001] and tour, so now I want to do the same for others. Australia has a unique arts scene that needs to be encouraged.</p><p>Money makes people treat you funny. I've had people in interviews mention me being a millionaire. My business has had millions run through it, but it's expensive to run, and we donate a lot [to charities such as The Wilderness Society, Refugee Action Coalition (NSW) and Greenpeace]. People are so geared around money that they see a dollar sign on your forehead and forget who you are.</p><p>Playing guitar never made me attractive to women. When I play, I make so many faces that it looks like I'm trying to poo. When I was busking, kids would never mention my playing, just my grunting.</p><p>I have acrylic nails on my right hand. Because of finger picking, my nails wore down to the quick and hurt when I played. A guitarist friend had fake nails, so I got them, too. It's like having a pick on each finger.</p><p>I live in Byron Bay and have a house in Melbourne but don't actually live anywhere any more. Last year, I toured so much that I spent three months at home, but each year, after I've toured, my wife, Danielle, and I go to Broome. She once lived on an Aboriginal community there and now they're part of our family - we camp with them.</p><p>When I met Danielle, in 1999, I realised I could make babies with her. Apart from being sexy, attractive and funny, she was wise, inspiring and I knew she'd be a good mother.</p><p>I caught my daughter Banjo [now two] in my hands. We were going to have a natural delivery, but after 30 hours, it was getting dangerous, so we decided to drive 45 minutes through the hills to the hospital. After 38 hours, she was born - and I was right there. We called her Banjo as we love the name, the instrument and the poet [Banjo Paterson].</p><p>I am a different person at age 29 to 19. At 19, I was pretty angry, addicted and passionate - I'm still passionate. I was hurt and in pain. I was angry about bad things that happened in my childhood and hung on to that anger. In the past 10 years, I've let go of a lot of it as it's not very productive for my child's life or what I want to achieve.</p><p>Weed made me paranoid. I stopped smoking it six years ago because it wasn't fun and it made me anxious.</p><p>A pivotal life moment occurred while 65 metres up a eucalyptus tree in Tasmania. It was a publicity stunt to stop woodchipping in the Styx Valley [December 2003]. I sat in the world's highest tree, played my grandfather's guitar and sang "Treat Yo Mama", a song about respecting where you live. My grandfather died in Western Australia, in 1952, fighting a forest fire. I thought of him up there.</p><p>I care about the environment, so I'm branded a tree-hugging hippie. The fact that I have dreadlocks only makes it worse. But who doesn't want clean air and water? At home in Byron Bay we probably go through a shopping bag full of trash per week. Our house has a composting toilet and runs off rainwater, but nobody can be environmentally perfect. But when you sing about it and promote it, people expect you to be.</p><p>I would describe myself as a person of good intent. I'm honest, passionate, rough around the edges and a bit of a yobbo, but sensitive.</p><p>My biggest faults are self-doubt and not loving myself enough. I've done a lot of good things and if I honoured myself the way I deserved, I could do a lot of good.</p><p>For more information on The JB Seed, visit <url normalizedValue="http://www.thejbseed.com">www.thejbseed.com</url> (expressions of interest close March 15)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5906-4631-JD34-V05X-00000-00MAN OF FLOWERS2013-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisLIFE & STYLEArts & EntertainmentPg. 14MAN OF FLOWERSCover storyAndrew Purcell

Illusion and movement bring nature to life as a ground-breaking US dance troupe transplants itself to Melbourne next week. Inside a ramshackle house where ideas and spirits collide, Andrew Purcell meets the man behind the Momix magic.

Draped in a white sheet, Moses Pendleton careened down the

hillside, pursued by a herd of cattle. He had rehearsed, so he knew his dancers - pure-bred Holstein-Friesians from the family farm in Vermont - could be relied upon to follow him as he swerved from side to side.

As the shrouded figure hurtled towards them, a few people backed away uneasily. The stampede, 50 cows the size of a minibus, appeared to be out of control. Just before reaching the crowd, Pendleton threw himself into a ditch. The cattle, with nothing more to chase, stopped running and began to graze. A volunteer from Vermont Natural Theatre rang a bell and audience members were led into an adjacent meadow, where they were encouraged to strip naked and swim across a lake to the farmhouse, to discuss the experience over hot cider and soy bread.

This would be Pendleton's first and last attempt at "cow-ography", but his debut as a performance artist contained the germ of a creative method that has served him ever since. It began with a single arresting image - black-and-white shapes on a green background - and confounded expectations. As the director of Momix, one of the world's most successful dance companies, he has produced hundreds of inventive variations on this simple formula.

From August 7-11, Momix returns to Arts Centre Melbourne with a full complement of dancers for the first time since a sell-out run a decade ago. The Sunday Age's dance critic, Neil Jillett, described that show, Opus Cactus, as "a combination of the high points of Disney's Fantasia, Sydney Dance Company at its most inventive and Cirque du Soleil at its slickest". Momix typically has two or three productions on tour at any time, mostly in the US, Italy and Brazil, where the dancers are greeted like rock stars.

The company is run from a ramshackle house in Washington, Connecticut, deep in New York's banker belt. On a gusty spring morning, the doors were open and there was music playing from an unattended computer. As nobody answered, I let myself in and wandered from room to room, taking in the awesome, borderline obsessive-compulsive clutter, peering around corners and calling out, until Pendleton emerged from the basement.

He has lived in Washington since 1978 with his common-law wife and creative foil, Cynthia Quinn, the nearest thing Momix has to a prima ballerina. They intended to buy the barn across the road as a rehearsal space, but the estate agent convinced them to take a look at the house and when he stepped inside, Pendleton was entranced by the late-afternoon sunlight. "The wallpaper was aglow," he recalled. "It was a mystical experience."

He was so enamoured of the wallpaper, in fact, he hasn't changed it in 35 years. On the stairwell, above papier-mache gargoyles of Verdi and Vivaldi, it is peeling off in metre-long strips. On every shelf are sunflower and daffodil blooms, not so much dried as interestingly dead, in shapes Pendleton found too appealing to let go.

As we toured the property, he kept up a relentless stream-of-consciousness monologue. The eight bathrooms all have original fixtures but only one is fully operational, he told me. His daughter, Quinn Pendleton, is getting married to a Turkish prince who dances with her at the Monte Carlo Ballet.

The house is haunted: "If people have that in them to think that it might have some spirits, they're more apt to catch them."

All of this was captured on not one but two digital audio devices. "We'll double-tape," Pendleton told me. By habit, he carries a recorder at all times, on the off chance that his conversations might contain ideas worth keeping. His assistant's main job is to catalogue the thousands of tapes and terabytes of new data. "If the tape's running, you've got to put something on it," he explained. "Say something of importance, confess something that's really heartfelt. Dare you."

Although he stopped dancing professionally long ago, he still has a dancer's sinewy physique, thanks to a daily exercise regime that includes a swim in the lake, an hour cycling and a 13-kilometre walk, listening to himself on headphones. He always takes a camera, to ensure he never misses an image. Last month, he shot some "Rauschenberg-esque crow poop". In March, he spent hours lying flat on country roads, taking extreme close-ups of ice crystals forming and melting. Each spring, he sets fire to last year's Christmas tree and films the flames.

Botanica is the end product of this exploration. The dancing flowers, bees and fireflies, the worms and sprouting plants are imaginative responses to Connecticut's changing seasons. It seems unlikely that Pendleton saw centaurs or a triceratops mating with a daffodil on his walk, but something in the hedgerows or the orchard grass set him off. "You think you're in a Wyeth painting," he told me. "You need the wind to get the grass to show you the dance."

Momix shows often reflect his enthusiasms - sex, baseball and astronomy - but Botanica is born of obsession. Each spring, Pendleton plants thousands of sunflowers. One sad summer, Verticillium wilt and Rhizoctonia laid waste to the monoculture, so he now plants marigolds on the lawn, in beds like a child's drawing of the sun, and rents "terroir" from a farmer for the sunflowers.

"Botanica isn't just the piece you see on stage. It really started with digging the soil, putting in these marigold plants," Pendleton said. "Monet grew his muse. He would say, when he referred to his act of painting, 'je pioche', and that in French means 'I hoe'."

Unlike most dance companies, Momix does not receive funds from the government or charitable foundations. Much of its income is derived from corporate partnerships with BMW, MAC cosmetics, Target stores and Hanes underwear, among others. Botanica is the fruit of three such arrangements, with Mercedes-Benz, Kohler bathroom fittings and a chain of Las Vegas casinos. For the Frankfurt Motor Show, Pendleton conceived the metamorphosis of a giant tree into a Mercedes, the dancers transforming branches into car parts, to emphasise the company's green credentials.

Because Momix needs to sell tickets (its peers can afford to make a loss at the box office), its shows are unashamedly populist, more likely to please crowds than dance critics, who have sometimes been rather sniffy about its blend of acrobatics, physical theatre and surrealism. Writing in The New York Times, Alastair MacAulay described a performance as "sensationalist trash so brightly harmless that I wish I could fall in line with those who enjoy it as sheer sensation".

Pendleton calls his troupe "dancer-illusionists". Half the pleasure of watching a Momix show is in working out how the visual effects are created and enjoying the feeling of being tricked. Although illusion is cheap in the multimedia age, it is amazing what can be achieved with 10 preternaturally lithe bodies, a few props and some ingenious lighting. When fans complain that Pendleton has started using computer-generated imagery, he is tempted to employ "a lightning bolt, a subliminal flash, to show the dancer behind the fabric" and prove he's done no such thing.

Hanging over Pendleton and Quinn's bed is a picture of merino sheep by a river bank in the shade of eucalyptus trees - an image that was printed on every box of blankets made by his family's woollen company. In the late 1930s, his father, Nelson Augustus Pendleton, spent two years working on a sheep station "somewhere near Brisbane" and thought about emigrating to Australia - "I should know more," Pendleton admitted - but on a visit back to the US he was severely injured in an explosion at a hotel in San Francisco.

Badly disfigured, he was "brought back in a box" to convalesce in New York, fell in love with his nurse and proposed marriage before the bandages had been taken off his eyes. Pendleton's grandfather, Moses Pendleton snr, set the newlyweds up with a farm in Vermont and the beginnings of a herd of Holstein-Friesians. Moses, the fourth of six children, grew up believing he would breed the ultimate dairy cow, but in 1962, in haying season, his father committed suicide.

"I was 12 years old. And everything changed. This whole fantasy of creating the perfect Holstein, all of this, shut down."

Pendleton's mother sent him to Dartmouth College, to train with the Olympic ski team. He first took a dance class as a form of physiotherapy after breaking his leg on the slopes. Momix began as an offshoot of Pilobolus Dance Theatre, the company he founded with his teacher, Alison Chase, and a group of fellow students.

When Frank Zappa asked them to open for him, the reception they got from "2000 screaming girls" convinced them there was a market for performance art that fused choreography, gymnastics and the absurd.

It was October 1971, the dog days of the Vietnam era, and students all over the US lived in terror of being drafted. "I got a high number, but two of my close friends burnt their draft cards and went to prison," Pendleton said. "The war was an event that caused potential lawyers and doctors and businessmen to head into the frigging hills and learn how to play drums on hollowed-out spruce logs."

He suggested that dance was most profound without an audience, and that this was something pioneers such as Merce Cunningham and Martha Graham understood: "They did it for themselves, as a kind of spiritual awakening. It wasn't a performance art."

We dropped in on rehearsal, in the barn, where Quinn was teaching a group of six young female dancers their roles in Alchemia, the newest Momix production, in preparation for a run at the Roman amphitheatre in Verona.

As a mix of Ennio Morricone and the hissing, popping noises of a forest fire played over the speakers, the dancers skipped, twisted and twirled, their red stretch dresses trailing like flames. It looked a little bare, without lights, despite the level of technical skill and the unfeasibly flexible bodies on display. "If someone is so highly trained and musical and has the ability to defy gravity, that is still something that fascinates people, because we all identify with the body," Pendleton said.

In a second sketch, referred to by Quinn as "bubble butts", the dancers wore pads beneath their dresses in the shape of half melons, shifting them from buttocks, to hips, to bust as the dance progressed, giving them a grotesque, surgically enhanced look.

Most Momix shows have an element of titillation. The couple's dog, Mojito, wears a collar that gives him an electric shock if he strays too far from the house, and Pendleton joked that "Cynthia's getting me one as well. I can walk the further perimeter but I can't get out."

That this might be prudent became clear over lunch at the country club. As our waitress, to my eyes a fairly nondescript young woman, approached the table, Pendleton deployed the full force of his charm: "Well, speaking of an angel! Where's that accent from? What's your name? Do you say it Zo-ay, or Zo-ee?"

When she left, he turned to me in raptures. "Zoe gave me enough energy right there to almost burn my midnight candle," he said. "When you get to be 64, you don't need much. You don't go anywhere near there, but if you are a good receiver, you can pick up the feminine fire, the all-required celestial heat, in one quick exchange of bread and ... god, life is beautiful. If I were alone, I'd have five glasses of that white wine, stay until five, have two espressos, go out in the garden, talk to one of my flowers and call her Zoe."

This afternoon, he would settle for meditating under the hawthorn tree in full bloom, then join Quinn on the verandah for dinner, to discuss the day's inspirations. "It's always been my problem: whether or not you want to just see a flower grow and feel your art is complete, or do you need to take that experience into a studio, try to translate it into Momix dancers and see if they can somehow, through dance, give you a feeling of a flower growing," he said. "I'm not sure it's possible."

"Botanica is at the State Theatre, Arts Centre Melbourne, August 7-11.

urn:contentItem:3TV7-C420-0048-T0SB-00000-00<published>1998-10-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:05Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ISRAEL FIRE</p><p nitf:lede="true"> HAIFA, Israel, Oct 11 AFP - A major forest fire seriously damaged some 20 homes early today and forced the evacuation of outlying neighbourhoods of Haifa, Israel's third biggest city, officials said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Several thousand people were forced from their homes and three people were hospitalised for smoke inhalation as firefighters battled to contain the blaze on a mountainside on the southern edge of the city, Mayor Amram Mitzna said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A huge cloud of smoke hung over this Mediterranean port from the fire, which destroyed around 500ha of forest and was still raging several hours after it broke out.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> About 30 teams of firefighters from around northern Israel were deployed in the area along with six helicopters and two fixed-wing planes which were dropping water on the flames.</p><p>AFP</p><p>RUSSIACHECHNYA</p><p> MOSCOW, Oct 11 Reuters - The breakaway region of Chechnya today released nine Russian military servicemen, eight of whom flew to Moscow later in the day, officials said.</p><p> The soldiers had been kidnapped in Russian territory neighbouring Chechnya over the past year, Russian military officials said.</p><p> There are about 400 Russian soldiers still held hostage in Chechnya, which won de facto independence from Russia during a brutal two-year war ending in 1996, a defence ministry representative to Chechnya told reporters.</p><p> The young soldiers appeared to be in good health on arriving at a Moscow airport. One of the nine returned to his military unit in south Russia.</p><p> The number of kidnappings has risen in Chechnya since fighting against Russian rule ended, although the seizure of foreigners there has typically overshadowed cases involving Russian soldiers.</p><p> REUTER</p><p>INDIA POWER</p><p> NEW DELHI, Oct 11 AFP - A national power corporation today switched off electricity to one of India's most populous states while a second begged for time to settle bills running into millions of dollars.</p><p> The National Thermal Power Corp (NTPC) switched off its largest powerhouse generating 1,600 megawatts daily, disrupting supplies to West Bengal state, saying it did not have the funds to generate electricity.</p><p> The blackout followed an 1830 GMT (0430 AEST) deadline yesterday for West Bengal and its adjoining state of Bihar to pay up arrears totalling $ US613 million ($ A996 million), the company said in a statement.</p><p>NTPC said it blacked out the coastal state because West Bengal's Marxist government did not respond to its string of reminders on growing electricity bills.</p><p>AFP</p><p>TURKEY ISLAMISTS</p><p> ANKARA, Oct 11 AFP - Turkish police today arrested over 200 Islamist demonstrators during rallies held throughout the country to protest against a ban on the Islamic headscarf in universities, the Anatolia news agency said.</p><p> several pro-Islamic organisations in Ankara, Istanbul and nearly 20 other major Turkish cities and towns, the agency said.</p><p> In the southern city of Gaziantep, the police arrested more than 100 protesters after they failed to obey an order to disperse peacefully.</p><p> Another 100 people were arrested in rallies in other cities in which several parliamentary deputies from the pro-Islamic Virtue Party also took part.</p><p> The protests were prompted by a recent decision by the rectors of Turkey's 50 universities to bar female students from wearing Islamic head scarves on university premises.</p><p>AFP</p><p> UK AWARDS</p><p> LONDON, Oct 11 PA - An "empty chair" tribute will be made to Linda McCartney at the 43rd Women of the Year Lunch in London tomorrow.</p><p> The vegetarian campaigner and wife of Sir Paul McCartney, who died of cancer in April, will be honoured by 500 leading women at the lunch at the Savoy Hotel.</p><p> Guests will be offered a vegetarian meal so that they can do want Linda asked and "Go Veggie".</p><p> Sir Paul, who is releasing a CD of Linda's music later this month, sent a message to the organisers which said his wife would have been "chuffed" to be involved with the Women of the Year Lunch and added: "It's a pity us blokes can't go."</p><p> Janet Hull, Vice Chair of the Women of the Year, said Linda's life summed up what the assembly represents.</p><p> "She could have been a lady of leisure, she did not need to work but she pursued her own career and ideals. She was very much in the spirit of what we are celebrating."</p><p> Last year Linda was invited to the lunch but was unable to attend because she was too ill.</p><p> PA</p><p>GERMANY BOOK</p><p> FRANKFURT, Germany AP - Martin Walser, whose novels explore the conscience of Germans rebuilding the nation after the Nazi era and World War II, was awarded the prestigious Peace Prize at the Frankfurt International Book Fair today.</p><p> In a ceremony at St Paul's Church that included President Roman Herzog, the 71-year-old German author was praised as one of the country's most important literary figures.</p><p> Walser's novels and essays "explained to the world and to Germans their own country and brought them closer together," said the German Book Trade Association awards committee, which awarded the 25,000-mark ($ A25,000) prize.</p><p> Walser was an early critic of the Cold War division of Germany. One of his best known works, the spy novel Dorle and Wolf, decries the nation's east-west barrier and the political scare campaigns on both sides of the border.</p><p> Walser, who has also written for the stage, tries to reconcile German guilt over the Holocaust with a young postwar generation's desire to look to the future.</p><p>AP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3TV7-C420-0048-T0SB-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="915"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4T8S-SDP0-TX5N-01GS-00000-00CHILDS REBORN2008-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisEVENTPg. 6CHILDS REBORNSally Browne

Singer-songwriter Toni Childs had the world at her feet two decades ago, when ill health forced her to give it all up. Sally Browne reports on a remarkable journey of self-discovery heading back to the top

'It wipes everything out for a while, and then you have to kind of regrow, heal, rebuild. You've been dismantled and dismembered. And then all your bits start coming back together and it's wonderful'

SHE looks exactly the same, but Toni Childs has been on quite a journey to get to where she is today.

In the early 1990s, the US singer had the world at her feet. Her debut album Union (1988) was an international hit, spawning such memorable songs as Stop Your Fussin', Don't Walk Away and Zimbabwe.

I've Got To Go Now from her second album House of Hope (1991), was a No.5 hit in Australia.

Her powerful voice and soulful tunes cut to the heart of the listening public and in 1988 she was nominated for two Grammy awards. Although she didn't win, she delivered a memorable performance, with Stevie Wonder, Paul McCartney and Mick Jagger in the audience.

While working on a fourth album, Childs plunged herself into charity work, starting the Dream a Dolphin charity for sick kids. It was then she discovered that she, too, was sick. She had a disease she had never heard of. It was Graves Disease, a thyroid condition brought on by stress.

``My right eye was popping out of my head and I was waking up with my hands and feet cramping,'' she recalls. ``These are classic symptoms. I didn't know what it was. I thought, `I know I need to go to an eye doctor' but I was so busy and my life was so crazy.

``I remember I was visiting my grandmother and my Aunt Linda said, `You know what? I bet you have Graves Disease'.''

Sure enough, she did. She went to a doctor who told her that her resting pulse rate was 120 beats a minute, and immediately put her on heart inhibitors.

``It was a shock because each one of the doctors said I had to dismantle my life.''

She put the brakes on her projects and recording career and spent the next eight years focusing on getting well. She describes the experience as like a forest fire.

``It takes everything down,'' she says. ``It wipes everything out for a while, and then you have to kind of regrow, heal, rebuild. You've been dismantled and dismembered. And then all your bits start coming back together and it's wonderful. It gives you this amazing appreciation for life and the privilege of getting to do what you love.''

What she loves is music, and Childs finally has a new album out. It's titled, aptly, Keep the Faith.

Not only that, her journey to recovery brought with it other rewards. Part of her healing ritual was to treat her body with salt rubs, reminding herself that each part of her body was beautiful.

Gradually, she was able to wean herself off her medication. The process inspired her to create a line of organic bodycare products, with names such as I Love My Body and I Love My Hair, which will be released in Australia next month.

Childs worked on the products from the ingredients to the packaging. She spent time scouting for a manufacturer in Australia who could handle smaller quantities, and found one in Melbourne. She still has her ritual salt rubs by her outdoor shower at her home on the island of Kauai, Hawaii.

It was a serendipitous meeting that led her back to the recording studio.

Childs was performing in a local production of The Vagina Monologues and it just so happened that Eve Ensler, the creator of that play, was in the audience. She sought out Childs after the show.

``When she came we were all nervous. We were in this receiving line waiting for her. She didn't really recognise who I was because she thought it was the black gal in the cast, and said, `Oh, so who's Toni Childs?' pointing and looking at this other gal and I said (in a small voice) `No, it's me!'.'' Childs laughs at the memory.

What came next was a deep bonding experience for both women. Ensler told her that her record, Union, had had a profound impact on her life. When Ensler was down in the dumps and living out of her car, she listened to the record over and over again.

She took Childs aside and told her she needed to start singing again.

``She said, `You need to be singing. This is your gift. Why aren't you singing?' She really gave me a hard time and then she asked me the craziest thing: `Okay, I want you to write an anthem that will inspire people to end violence against women and children for all time.'

``And what's really scary was I actually contemplated whether I could do it or not. That's the funny part.''

Childs ended up writing the song Because You're Beautiful for Ensler's documentary Until the Violence Stops. The song won an Emmy Award.

``I wanted to address how women need to know they are beautiful,'' she says. ``I think we as women are really hard on ourselves. I think we have what I call a beauty wound, needing a lot of outside reflection that we're okay and there's these vulnerable parts of ourselves and we give our power away.''

Where does that beauty wound come from?

"You know, Oh, God," she sighs. ``I'm writing a book. It's called Living Beauty: Alchemy of Acceptance, and this is a big piece of this book, because I'm really looking at my own stuff, and my girlfriends'. It's something I've been working on since '94. In fact, writing that song for Eve was the catalyst to start writing the book.

``It's centuries old, this wound, and I think there are certain things that happened in our history which created a situation for women to stay more in the background. I believe right now that a lot of women in the world, not all women in the world, are coming into their own.''

At the age of 50 Childs is finding her voice again, both as a speaker and a singer. She says her new record is more rootsy and home-spun than her earlier work and she has noticed that her voice is more ``open''. The music industry has changed a lot since Childs last released a record, for the better she thinks.

``It's actually becoming more karmically balanced,'' she laughs. ``It also asks the artist to become more business savvy. With computers and the internet and also the ability to really connect with people, it's much better now.''

Her life is much more karmically balanced, too. She lives on a beautiful property with two dogs, a cat, a horse named Sunny, 50 ducks and 100 chickens.

A particularly plucky rooster likes to crow outside her window to let her know it's breakfast time. Then her day begins.

In the morning she'll be working online with people on the US mainland and in the afternoon, when the time is right, she'll be working with people in Australia.

Her new mood on life is summed up on the new single One Life.

``I feel like there's this amazing world,'' she says. ``We've got this life and then we've got this chance to live it to its fullness, and each one of us is an amazing shooting star here for a short period of time. What are we going to do with it?''Keep the Faith is out now. Toni Childs will perform at the Tivoli, Brisbane, on September 25; and Twin Towns, Gold Coast, on September 27.

urn:contentItem:53X9-M2N1-DYG0-91C4-00000-00FED:States face grass fire threat2011-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:States face grass fire threatMegan Neil

  Grass fires are shaping up as the big threat this bushfire season, with heavy rains creating grass fuel loads not experienced in decades in many parts of Australia.
   Following is an analysis of the situation by fire authorities in each state and territory.
  
   ACT
   Bushfire season: October 1 to March 31.


   The ACT has had relatively few bushfires since fires devastated Canberra in 2003.
   But authorities say abundant grass growth and regrowth in the forests since 2003 present a significant risk over the 2011-12 bushfires season, should there be a return to hot and dry weather over summer.
   ACT Rural Fire Service chief officer Andrew Stark said while the territory experienced a dry winter, significant rainfall last summer had reduced the forest fire danger while dramatically increasing the grass fire danger.
   "The ACT has a grass fuel hazard developing which has not been seen for 20 to 25 years," Mr Stark said.
   Last year rain kept the grass from curing and becoming a fire hazard but the summer rainfall wasn't expected to be repeated this year.
   "So we're expecting to have a much higher hazard than we had last year even though conditions are somewhat similar, but the rainfall is the critical lever in this hazard at the moment," Mr Stark said.
   Mr Stark said in the bush capital, the potential for fire to occur over a back fence was a reality every summer.
   "It mightn't be a huge calamitous fire like Victoria or Canberra 2003, but if it's over your back fence it's still terrifying and still has the potential to damage your property or your house and threaten your family."
  
   NORTHERN TERRITORY
   Bushfire season: In the Top End, has run since June and will end some time in October. For central Australia, from August until April.
   Central Australia, which doesn't even have a fire season every year, is experiencing what Bushfires NT director Steve Sutton described as a one-in-30-year event.
   Mr Sutton said fires would continue to burn in the centre for most of the season running through to the end of April and would likely move into both South Australia and Queensland.
   "It will be a very large number for the total area burnt," he said.
   Record rainfall right across the territory has led to enormous amounts of grass growth, while there's also the problem of introduced species of grass which grow denser and burn hotter than native grass species, he said.
   "The fuel loads are, in some areas, potentially higher than they have ever been," Mr Sutton said.
   He said Bushfires NT had a vigorous fire mitigation program but the problem this year was that the record rain continued through the mitigation season, making it difficult to conduct prescribed burning to reduce the fuel load.
   It's been situation normal in the Top End of the NT, where there's lots of fires each year, but the season should end within the next month with the first widespread showers of the wet season.
  
   NSW
   Bushfire season: October 1 to March 31. Bushfire danger period declared in 31 local government areas since September 1.
   Drought-breaking rains have generated significant grass growth with NSW facing a difficult fire season, the NSW Rural Fire Service says.
   Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said that after one of the quietest fire seasons in many years last year, there was every potential for a difficult season in NSW.
   "We are coming into a fire season which is going to prove particularly challenging, I suspect, and particularly so given the grassland conditions the likes of which we haven't seen for 30 or 40 years," he said.
   He said that even over winter there were dozens of grass fires a week, as a lot of vegetation dried and died.
   "Any new growth we get now with any spring rain, as we come into summer you only need a couple of days of hot, dry, windy conditions and you've got a landscape that is very susceptible to ignition, and should ignition start under those conditions fires will spread very quickly."
   Fire authorities and the brigade's 70,000 volunteers had been focusing on hazard reduction work and raising awareness among communities to ensure they were prepared for a difficult fire season.
   While the focus was on grass fires, Mr Fitzsimmons said there was still a lot of bush across NSW that would be prone to bushfire this season.
  
   QUEENSLAND
   Bushfire season: Started August 1. End date not set but generally runs to end October or November. Fire danger period, requiring permits to light fires, runs September 4 to January 1.
   The warm weather has already brought with it bushfires and days of severe fire danger for large parts of Queensland.
   Queensland Fire and Rescue Service acting assistant commissioner Paul Adcock said the fires were moving quickly, due to an abundance of thick grass load, particularly in the west and south-west of the state.
   "In essence we've got a normal fire season but with a very high grass load which makes it difficult to control fires," Mr Adcock said.
   After the state's extensive floods, higher soil moisture meant the fire danger rating was lower in forested areas than in grass areas, but Mr Adcock said warm dry winds over the next month or two would start to dry out the forests as well.
   Mr Adcock said it looked like being a busy season but not one like 2009, when Queensland experienced one of its worst bushfire seasons on record with dry conditions fanning thousands of blazes.
   "I think this year we're going to find that there'll be perhaps less fires but some of the fires may be more difficult to control because of the higher fuel loads," he said.
   Mr Adcock said October was the month of concern for fire activity, before the storm season began.
  
   SOUTH AUSTRALIA
   Bushfire season: Dates not set yet. Some districts could start from mid-October but generally begins from November 1 into early December, and then runs until late March or late April.
   The north-east and north-west pastoral districts and the west coast face above-average fire potential, with SA fire authorities providing resourcing to those areas above what would they would normally be provided.
   The abundance of grass in those areas due to well-above average rainfall had increased the risk of bushfires in those areas above what they would normally see, SA Country Fire Service manager operations services Rob Sandford said.
   "When you talk to a number of people, long-time residents in the pastoral country, particularly on the stations, they're saying they haven't seen growth like that for a long time," he said.
   The risk remains for the rest of the state.
   Mr Sandford said the fuel load was there but the level of fire activity was very much weather dependent.
   He said everyone needed a bushfire action plan, including people travelling through SA's outback.
  
   TASMANIA
   Bushfire season: Dates yet to be set.
   Tasmania Fire Serve district officer Jeff Knight says it's too early to tell what sort of fire season the state faces.
   He said the weather bureau had indicated it would be an average year but it would take until the end of October for there to be a good indication of the season.
   Mr Knight said in some years large areas which had experienced flooding earlier in the year then had fires in early October, while in other years there were no major fires until after Christmas.
   "We had an average season last year and the year before," he said.
   "We'll always get fires, but it just depends on how many and how frequent and how big."
  
   VICTORIA
   Bushfire season: Dates not set yet.
   Victorian fire authorities say this year's rainfall, coming after 10 years of drought, has changed the outlook for the 2011-12 season and the state faces a significantly higher grass fire risk than it has for many years.
   The Mallee and Wimmera region in the north-west, where fires are a normal occurrence each year, has had significant and widespread native grass growth.
   Fire Services Commissioner Craig Lapsley said central Victoria had experienced similar conditions. There the grassland ran into small forest areas and there was a dispersed population of small hamlets, rural agricultural country and regional centres.
   Mr Lapsley said this summer had the potential for large grass fires but also warned there was still a risk of bushland fires.
   "We should never underestimate what fire can do in the bushland and particularly after a dry spell of weather, of what fire can do in any part of Victoria," he said.
   Victoria has experienced a couple of benign fire seasons since the devastating Black Saturday bushfires in February 2009 killed 173 people.
   Work was continuing to implement the Bushfires Royal Commission's recommendations.
   "Have we implemented everything yet? The answer's no. Have we got everything moving? Yes we have, but not everything is in its final state yet," Mr Lapsley said.
   "We're certainly in a far better position."
  
   WESTERN AUSTRALIA
   Bushfire season: Northwest WA June to late October. Rest of the state October to April.
   Most of WA is facing a risk of above-average bushfire activity, because the rains have promoted grassland growth in the outback and pastoral areas.
   "We've got above-average growth and I guess above-average potential across about 80 per cent of our state," said Chris Arnol, assistant chief operations officer (country) at the Fire & Emergency Services Authority of WA.
   The south-west corner of WA is expecting normal bushfire activity this season, but Mr Arnol said it would still be significant fires in those forested areas and a key issue facing fire authorities was urban interface fires.
   "If the rains continue we'll probably have a later onset of the season so January/February could still be quite horrendous for us, because that's our peak (for the south season)," he said.
   The bushfire season in the north is coming to an end but fires have been burning particularly in the Kimberley, including one which trapped ultramarathon runners in early September.
   "As the summer comes down the continent we have fires progressively come down," Mr Arnol said.
   Mr Arnol said WA probably undertook the most hazard reduction burning of any state, including aerial control burning up north and work to protect towns identified as being most at risk.

urn:contentItem:4P7M-CTY0-TXN5-R2F9-00000-00MODERN REALISM1990-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMReviewsPg. 76MODERN REALISMReviewed by DON ANDERSON

RICHARD Ford's first novel, A Piece of My Heart, was runner-up for the 1976 Ernest Hemingway Award. Since then, he has published two novels, The Ultimate Good Luck and The Sportswriter, and a volume of short stories, Rock Springs.

Much of Ford's fiction concerns poor folks, the unemployed, the just plain unlucky, and adulterers - the little betrayals that make us human. Although Ford is college-educated, his father was a travelling salesman. You feel confident that the author knows his unstable, "low-life", small-town milieu.

Richard Ford has been associated with a new generation of American realists, whose fiction has been described as "devoted to the local details, the nuances, the little disturbances in language and gesture ... the belly-side of contemporary life".

Wildlife is set over three days in Great Falls, Montana, a city of 60,000, just one hundred kilometres from the Canadian border. Ford's stories are often located in the rural American north-west, where it gets damned cold in winter. A cold tale's best for winter, as the Bard hath it. Ford is a winter writer -climatically, emotionally, and stylistically. Each of his fictions charts a decisive moment of change - to call it a crisis would be too strong, would sensationalise the restraint of his writing. A moment of change that is always for the worse:

In the Fall of 1960, when I was sixteen and my father was for a time not working, my mother met a man named Warren Miller and fell in love with him. This was in Great Falls, Montana, at the time of the Gypsy Basin oil boom, and my father had brought us there in the spring of that year from Lewiston, Idaho, in the belief that people - small people like him - were making money in Montana or soon would be, and he wanted a piece of that good luck before all of it collapsed and was gone in the wind.

That's a damned fine opening paragraph. Unassertive, limpid, economic. Ford is a master of economy. In a hundred words he gives us the principals, the location, the father's "misfortunate" fate, the mother's infidelity, charted the plot for us - delivered both history and prophecy - and, perhaps most important, exposed us to the 16-year-old narrator's tone, the tone, albeit, of that narrator some years later.

Tone is Ford's characteristic triumph. The American novel, from Huckleberry Finn on, is littered with adolescent (J. D. Salinger, Bret Easton Ellis) or arrested adolescent (Jack Kerouac) first-person male narrators. While the Joe of Wildlife experiences the same traumas as Huck Finn and Holden Caulfield(loneliness, loss, the prospect of death), his essential restraint makes him, appropriately, a singular figure.

Joe's mother tells him: "Your life doesn't mean what you have, sweetheart, or what you get. It's what you're willing to give up ... That's the rule. It's the major rule for everything." Loss is perhaps the Lesson of Literature. Joe reflects: "What I thought about as I fell asleep in my bed late in that morning was loss and how I would get along with it alone and what I had of myself that I was willing to lose." Indeed, his narrative restraint, his mature detachment in telling of his adolescent exposure to the facts of adult life - bad luck, deception, compromise - may just be the index of what he has lost.

Why the title - Wildlife? Well, the principals do lead a "wild life", as one remarks. And they are surrounded by Nature, Tennysonianly red in tooth and claw. Great Falls is threatened by a forest fire, which Joe's father quixotically fights. It is then that he sees the bear, as Jimmy Buffet would say.

Your father said he saw a bear catch on fire. Isn't that something? He said it had climbed a tree to get away and the fire exploded in the branches all around it. The poor bear jumped out completely on fire and ran away. That's a thing to remember, isn't it?

It certainly is. "No symbols where none intended", as Samuel Beckett helpfully remarked. Wildlife, indeed. Papa Hemingway would have saluted the way Ford put that burning bear in a realistic fiction, creating ever-enlarging ripples of signification.

urn:contentItem:4M88-5TX0-TX52-H3BR-00000-00More than just hot air2006-11-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisFEATURESInside Edition TablePg. 68

MATP

More than just hot airPETER TRUTE

Being green isn't that easy in a country which has the world's worst record for greenhouse gas emissions

Aday in the Weston house starts just like a day in most Sydney homes. For the family of four there's breakfast to be had, school lunches to be made and maybe clothes to be ironed before it's into the car, or on to the bus, and off to school or work. Australia bears the unhappy distinction of having the world's highest per capita greenhouse gas emissions.

For the average Sydneysider, this dubious honour might seem unfair -- particularly when most of us wouldn't call our lifestyles extravagant or luxurious.

On the world stage, Australia is responsible for 1.4 per cent of energy-related carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions -- or about 27.2 tonnes of greenhouse gas per person. Inside the country, 50 per cent

of greenhouse gas comes from making stationery energy, such as the electricity which powers our homes and industries, and 13 per cent comes from energy for transport, such as the petrol in our cars.

That's some 387 million tonnes of emissions out of 565 produced each year, using the 2004 figures.

The average Australian home, according to calculations by climate change solutions group Easy Being Green, puts out about 11 tonnes of greenhouse gas per annum. So how does an average Sydney home stack up?

A day with the Westons shows where we run up our greenhouse gas bill -- and also illustrates that the humble home is only part of the problem.

Brad Weston is a finance director with a major property consultant firm.

''[Reducing emissions] isn't at the forefront of our thinking all the time, but as opportunities arise, we are replacing our lightbulbs with energy-efficient ones, for example,'' he says. ''As the opportunity or circumstances change we rethink the way we can do things.''

The 42-year-old starts most days early with a 5am drive from Cherrybrook to the gym, which is 10 minutes away at Pennant Hills. After he gets home, the family has breakfast together, then Brad's wife, Ban, drives Dani, 10, and Talia, 7, to school before getting started on her own work day. Ban, an organisational psychologist, usually works from home but drives her four-cylinder BMW into the city about three times a week to see clients. Brad drives his Ford Fairmont to the bus stop 2km away for a bus into the city where he works.

Using the online Australian Greenhouse Calculator to estimate the greenhouse impact of running their two-storey home and two cars puts the Westons above the average of 11 tonnes of greenhouse gas per annum.

It's a figure that's skewed because Ban has an office at home, pushing up energy use in the day. Ban says she was surprised at the carbon emissions from running their household but running an office from home would contribute to the high figure. "I think that's going to impact on it a lot," she says. "But I also have to use my car a lot."

Neither Brad nor Ban describe themselves as "greenies", although Brad says that he is "becoming more aware", mostly as a result of the growing attention given to the issue in the media.

"It's an issue that I think about a lot in terms of our kids in the future,"Ban says.

"It alarms me a bit. Being on the road brings it home more than anything else - just the pollution you see."

Chief executive of Easy Being Green Paul Gilding says much of Australia's high per-capita emissions are the result of industry. "About 20 per cent of emissions in Australia come out of the home and personal driving - the things under your personal control - though that doesn't mean that's all you are responsible for because you are buying things that require CO2 to be made," he says.

However, Gilding believes that despite our highest-polluter per capita tag, Australians are generally very aware when it comes to the environment.

"I've worked in Europe a lot so I know that Australians are among the most environmental consumers in the world," he says. "What we are missing in Australia has been government and business action to mobilise that belief that people have into action. The most important thing we have to do is put a price on carbon so that people are rewarded for acting."

. Appliance calculations made using Energy Australia's Small Appliance Calculator. All calculations are best estimates only. Household Greenhouse Calculator figures are also best estimates.

How it all adds up

* Electric kettle: 119kg ofCO2/year or 320g/day.

* Toaster: 99kg ofCO2/year or 270g/day.

* Refrigerator: 565kg/year or 1.54kg/day.

* Dishwasher (used every twothree days): 250kgCO2/year or 680g/day.

* Washing machine (used every three days): 250kgCO2/year or 680g/day.

* TV: 119kg/year or 320g/day.

* Electric lighting: 1.2 tonnes CO2/ year or 3.28kg/day.

* Computer and monitor: 198kg/ yearCO2 or 540g/day.

* Ducted airconditioning: 2.5 tonnesCO2/year or 6.8kg/day.

* Hot water (gas): 1.5 tonnes/year or 4.1kg/day.

* Vacuum cleaner (used three times a week): 178kgCO2/year or 490g/day.

* Swimming pool filter: 173kgCO2/ year or 470g/day.

* Two cars: combined output 8.5 tonnes/CO2 per year or 19kg/day.

* Additional activities (including operating gas stove for meals and other household appliances): 2.5 tonnesCO2/year or 6.8kg/day.

What to expect as temperatures rise

1 DEGREE

* 10-40 per cent shrinkage of the snow-covered area in the Australian Alps;

* 60 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef will be bleached regularly;

* A 250-310-litre annual drop in milk production per cow in the Hunter Valley;

* Up to 15 per cent likely decrease in flow to Burrendong Dam and Macquarie Marshes in the Macquarie River Basin;

* 70 per cent increase in droughts in NSW.

2 DEGREES

* Hard coral reef communities are widely replaced by algal communities;

* 91 per cent chance that wheat exports will be below the current level (without adaptation);

* $12.4 million annual cost to manage the spread of the Queensland fruit fly;

* 40 per cent of eucalypts' core habitat lost;

* Murray Darling Basin flow down by 12-25 per cent;

* Southward spread of malaria-receptive zones.

3 DEGREES

* 97 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef is bleached every year;

* Core habitat of butterfl ies shrinks by 92 per cent;

* 80 per cent loss of freshwater wetlands in Kakadu (30cm sea level rise);

* Temperature-related mortality among people 65 years and older in Australian capital cities increases by 89-123 per cent;

* Forest fire danger index increases by more than 10 per cent in many areas.

4 DEGREES

* Temperature-related mortality among people 65 years and over in Australian capital cities increases by 144-200 per cent;

* Dengue fever transmission zone expands south as far as Sydney;

* 20-85 per cent shrinkage of the snow-covered area in the Australian Alps and 38-96 per cent decline in 60-day snow cover;

* Flow in the Murray Darling Basin to decrease by 16-48 per cent.

5 DEGREES

* 60-90 per cent loss of core habitat for Victorian and lower mountain tropical vertebrate species;

* 90-100 per cent of core habitat lost for most Australian vertebrates. Affected species will include golden bowerbird, green ringtail possum, mountain pygmy possum (left) and the alpine skink;

* Peak electricity demand in Adelaide, Brisbane and Melbourne will increase 10-25 per cent.

Source: CSIRO

urn:contentItem:4SG6-MW80-TX5N-00PV-00000-00Moving slowly in the right direction2008-05-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisTALKING POINTPg. 32Moving slowly in the right directionSUE NEALES

IT was a confusing week in Tasmanian politics, as mixed messages emanated from the Government's inner bunker about its trumpeted new way ahead.

On the one hand, there were some welcome signs that, like a slow-moving juggernaut, the State Government may finally be willing to make some concessions on key public health issues such as air and water quality.

After years of concerns about thick forest-smoke clouds from residents and tourists alike, and fears about high levels of chemical use in standard agricultural and forestry practice, the Government is to be congratulated for moving towards tighter controls on both.

The announcement by the Forest Practices Authority that, in certain weather conditions, it will move to ban regeneration burn-offs of logged forestry areas in both public and private forests, is a good start.

It will go some way to addressing the public outcry that has accompanied the almost-continuous smoke haze over parts of Tasmania this autumn, as well as providing the hope of future relief for severe asthmatics and smoke sufferers.

In the past, the decision to burn off -- whether for seed-regeneration purposes after radical logging, or to reduce undergrowth build-up as a bushfire-amelioration tool -- has rested entirely with Forestry Tasmania, individual farmers or private forest and plantation owners such as Gunns, Norske Skog and Timbercorp.

Not surprisingly, on windy days or at times when cold air streams have caused temperature inversion phenomena, smoke has regularly spread across the land or lain thick in valleys and over inland plains for days.

The head of the Forest Practices Authority, Graham Wilkinson, said the smoke problem was an area where he had long felt the forestry industry could perform better.

By next year he hopes to have in place mandatory guidelines for regeneration fires, in particular, to ensure the ash and smoke rise safely into the upper atmosphere, rather than spreading across local houses and communities.

The new rules will cover wind direction, wind speed, temperature inversions and weather changes, regulating when and where fires can be lit. There will be fines of up to $100,000 for any breaches.

The decision by the Forest Practices Authority to crack down on forest burns was welcomed by the Australia Medical Association.

Of particular concern to the AMA has been the issue of new high-intensity forest fires being lit when smoke haze from previous burns is still lingering.

``Patients are much more sophisticated and they know what's what, and I don't think they're prepared to put up with the smoke any more -- and quite rightly so,'' said AMA Tasmanian president Professor Haydn Walters.

``You can't keep lighting these fires day after day; you've just got to back off and let the smoke clear, whereas what we've seen this year is the haze begins, but nobody backs off and it just builds up day after day after day.''

Forestry Tasmania has also reacted to criticism from wine growers about the impact of forest smoke on the grape harvest.

It has agreed to consult with the wine industry about the timing and location of fires, so that smoke taint does not affect picked grape loads.

On Wednesday, further evidence of a weather change in the Government's seemingly unrelenting solidarity with the most red-necked elements of the forestry industry came with the decision by Primary Industries Minister David Llewellyn to impose tougher controls on chemical spraying.

Mr Llewellyn announced that, after years of public outcry by communities where homes and schools border tree plantations, aerial and ground spraying of pesticides within 100m of residential property would now be illegal.

Similar exclusion zones where chemical spraying is prohibited will also be established around schools, water bodies and catchments.

Like the proposed forest-fire weather guidelines, the new chemical spraying rules sound like common sense.

Many would rightly wonder why they had not been introduced earlier if they can so easily be proposed now and immediately win the support of conservative groups such as the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association.

The answer is that community pressure is a powerful force.

It is impossible not to see these welcome, if overdue, moves as anything but clear evidence that community angst and unrest -- not to mention political agitation -- is starting to hit home in the highest levels of the Government.

But, before community and environmental groups who have agitated for such changes become too euphoric, it is worth also looking at the contradictory signals circulating through the political airwaves this week.

The biggest was the release of the strange $15 million ``sovereign risk'' agreement on Monday, signed four months earlier between the State Government and Gunns over wood to be supplied to its planned $2 billion pulp mill and adjacent wood-fired power plant.

Despite what the Tasmanian Greens claim, there is nothing bizarre at all about the existence of such an agreement in the commercial world.

It effectively agrees that the state Treasury will pay compensation of a maximum of $15 million over 20 years to Gunns, if political decisions taken by the State Government to restrict logging prevent Forestry Tasmania from meeting its contract to supply Gunns with a set amount of wood for the pulp mill.

But what is strange is the timing and value of the sovereign risk agreement.

Why release it now, four months after it has been signed? Why is it for $15 million, which appears to bear no relation to the value of the contracted wood to be supplied?

There are some indications that the Government has reverted to type over this sovereign risk deal and tried, as so often has happened in the past, to hide its existence from the public.

Even now, it may only have been forced to release details of the agreement this week because it was about to turn up elsewhere. Exactly how and where it would have been unveiled is not clear.

It could be that the $15 million deal will be referred to as a liability in the upcoming June 12 state Budget. Or it might have been uncovered in a Freedom of Information request or during the June estimates sessions, when departments and their ministers are quizzed by opposition politicians about their budgets and deals.

However, another interesting option is the possibility that, in the current tight global credit market, Gunns may have to announce a capital-raising offer -- either via a rights issue or a share plan -- to partly finance its pulp mill.

Such an offer would need to provide financial security about the guaranteed safety of funds raised and effectively lent to Gunns for its massive project.

It may be that the sovereign risk deal, besides its compensatory effect, also effectively confers on Gunns the ``protection'' of the Tasmanian Government's own current triple-A credit rating from Moodys, allowing it to borrow funds at a cheaper interest rate or capital raised to be offered with more investor confidence.

Not quite a government guarantee, but close to it.

Either way, some better explanation from the Government and Treasurer Michael Aird of the deal's intent would have been welcome and, indeed, should have been provided.

So too would some explanation about why 25 documents -- held within the Department of Economic Development relating to the Government's well-advanced plans to fund the private pulp mill's $65 million water supply pipeline -- could not be made publicly available.

A Freedom of Information request to obtain this information this week received a blanket refusal on the grounds the information was commercial-in-confidence and formed part of protected information provided to the Government's inner Cabinet.

Increasingly around Australia, both arguments are being used as a form of obfuscation by governments seeking to prevent the public using FOI laws to discover what is actually going on behind the thick walls and closed doors of executive government.

The problem is, as Michael McKinnon, Australia's leading FOI media exponent told a packed lecture at the University of Tasmania on Thursday, these excuses are usually used as a cover-up.

``Where you get this sort of government secrecy [in relation to FOI requests], you can almost always guarantee that there is a sweetheart deal going on,'' McKinnon said bluntly this week.

urn:contentItem:4P89-SSR0-TXN5-T3CK-00000-00IN BRIEF1997-10-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisNEWSBriefsPg. 9IN BRIEF

Fire havoc in NZ WELLINGTON. Twenty homes were evacuated as a forest fire burned out of control near Motueka in the north of New Zealand's South Island, Radio New Zealand reported yesterday. It said the fire had engulfed around 20sq km of a forestry block of radiata pine. One hundred firefighters were battling the blaze, backed by four helicopters, 12 fire engines, six water tankers and five bulldozers.

Pornography sentences LOS ANGELES. Three US-based members of an international child pornography ring that used the Internet to transmit pictures of children being sexually molested were sentenced to long jail terms in San Jose yesterday. The ring had members as far afield as Australia, Finland and Canada, investigators said. Ronald Riva, 38, of Greenfield, California, was sentenced to 30 years in prison; David Tank, 35, of Cheney, Washington, to 19 years and seven months; and Christopher Saemisch, 38, of Lawrence, Kansas, to 11 years. Suicide organs donated NEW YORK. A controversial American doctor who assists terminally ill people to commit suicide said yesterday he planned to offer organs harvested from his suicide patients to people who need transplants. Retired pathologist Dr Jack Kevorkian said the first organs, most likely lungs and a heart, would be donated on a first-come, first-serve basis. Algerians vote again ALGIERS. Millions of Algerians, rocked by a recent series of massacres and years of bloodletting, voted yesterday in local elections that the Government says will complete the establishment of a democracy. But for Algerians it was their third election in under two years and they appeared to have abandoned hope that the poll will end the nearly six-year-old civil strife that has killed more than 65,000 people. More executives arrested TOKYO. Police have arrested three Mitsubishi Motors Corp executives on charges of making illegal payments to suspected racketeers, the eighth such case against a major Japanese company so far this year. An assistant managing director of Mitsubishi, Mr Atsushi Ueba, and two other executives are suspected of funnelling more than Y9million ($A106,000) to `sokaiya' racketeers over the past two years. Sexual harassment charges WELLINGTON. Eleven New Zealand Navy staff face disciplinary charges for sexual harassment of a woman sailor on a Navy frigate during patrol duties in the Persian Gulf, in a case seen as a landmark for sexual harassment in the NZ armed forces. Larissa Turner, 21, left the NZ Navy in March, 1996, after alleging she was verbally and physically harassed continually during her six-month tour of sea duty on HMNZS Wellington. She said she was commonly grabbed by her buttocks and breasts and subjected to indecent suggestions. Minister dismissed PORT MORESBY. Papua New Guinea's new government has suffered its first casualty with the dismissal from office for misconduct of the Minister for Education, and former top public servant, Mr Gabriel Dusava. Mr Dusava, elected to Parliament in PNG's June elections, was found guilty by a leadership tribunal recently of 17 counts of misconduct while in his former post as Secretary for Foreign Affairs. The charges related to money he paid himself as advances on salary. Fires worsen haze JAKARTA. New fires are adding to the haze which has covered Indonesia and large parts of South-East Asia for the past three months, the Minister for the Environment, Mr Sarwono Kusumaaatmadja, said yesterday. Farmers who believed mistakenly that sporadic rainfalls in some areas meant the rainy season had started were clearing their fields with slash-and-burn methods to prepare them for planting, Mr Sarwono said. Reports said new blazes had flared up in various provinces of Sumatra and Kalimantan in recent days. Fiji says sorry LONDON. The Fijian Prime Minister, Mr Sitiveni Rabuka, went to Windsor Castle on Wednesday and presented Queen Elizabeth with a whale's tooth by way of apology for a military coup that transformed Fiji into a republic 10 years ago and ousted her as its head of state. Buckingham Palace said the Queen accepted Mr Rabuka's apology, and the whale's tooth, and that the two had 30 minutes of `the most cordial and friendly talks'. UN vote on Iraqi bans UNITED NATIONS. The United States and Britain have given up their demand to impose immediate travel sanctions against Iraq and instead proposed a UN Security Council resolution that prepares for new measures. The new resolution would require another Security Council vote before any sanctions would go into effect, as France and Russia have insisted. The measures would bar travel abroad by certain Iraqi officials except for diplomatic purposes. Jackson's brother jailed NEW YORK. The Reverend Jesse Jackson's half brother has been sentenced to life in prison for laundering drug profits for a street gang and hiring its members to kill former business partners. Noah Robinson was sentenced yesterday. He was convicted by a federal jury last year on racketeering, drug conspiracy and murder-for-hire charges that stemmed from a federal investigation into a gang that controlled drug trafficking on Chicago's South Side in the 1970s and 1980s. Human rights neglected PHNOM PENH. Amnesty International accused yesterday the Cambodian Government of gross neglect in protecting human rights, saying its commitment amounted to nothing more than an empty promise. In its harshest criticism yet, the London-based organisation blasted the Government for its failure to investigate scores of alleged abuses since 1993, especially following July's violent overthrow of co-premier Prince Norodom Ranariddh.

urn:contentItem:5573-8W21-F0J6-J51W-00000-00Indonesia finally hunts the culprits1997-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 12Indonesia finally hunts the culpritsGreg Earl Jakarta

Martin Hardiono operates a computer that is identifying some of the biggest companies in Indonesia for reckless land clearing and has provincial governors sweating by the fax for the latest information on fires in their own backyard.

But the slight young man at the keyboard is a lapsed criminologist who dropped by from the World Wide Fund for Nature to do a volunteer shift at the country's national fire co-ordination centre.

When President Soeharto was forced to make an unusual apology to his neighbours this past week for Indonesia's uncontrolled bush fires, the Government turned to an unlikely collection of volunteers and junior government staff to do something their superiors have failed to do for years - to identify the culprits.

The dozen people running Land and Forest Fire Control on the 6th floor of a nondescript building in central Jakarta are careful not to claim too much credit, but they have provided the first hope that Indonesia may finally be able to do something about a recurring regional crisis.

Not only does Mr Soeharto face the infamy of a threatened evacuation as far away as Kuala Lumpur, but if the fires rage until the end of the year they could inject new heat into the already tough battle over political succession.

While Malaysia's Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir Mohamad, drove home the message to Indonesia by wearing a face mask throughout the week, the South-East Asian countries have made some progress on co-operation by agreeing to share weather information, satellite pictures and cloud-seeding operations.

"We have done them [the neighbours] great harm, but we are doing ourselves even greater harm. This is not a business-as-usual scenario, this is a disaster scenario," the Minister for Environment, Mr Sarwono Kusumaatmadja, said of the way the fires have exposed flaws in land-use policies, the legal system and disaster-response capability.

Mr Sarwono, an advocate of political and bureaucratic reform, has always been seen as the out-gunned good guy when it came to defending the environment against the two-pronged assault of population pressures and politically influential companies. Now, with Indonesia facing intense criticism from its neighbours, the minister may have won just the lever he needs to push through some new monitoring procedures and more serious scrutiny of land use.

But before the Government has to confront the economic and social complexities of slowing down the conversion of up to 300,000 hectares of land a year for new agriculture, it has up to 176 opportunities to demonstrate its new environmental awareness - the number of plantation, timber and construction companies that have been identified as possible users of fire to clear land despite the unusually long dry season. They all have 15 days to defend themselves before various government agencies can scrap licences, levy damages and encourage financiers to turn off the flow of capital.

Close analysis of the fires shows that an unusually large number break out in the morning, when land clearance work begins, and remarkably few have occurred in protected forest areas, despite starting in nearby areas that have been approved for commercial land use.

For more than a decade Indonesia has promised to stop the fires at their source as its neighbours have become perturbed at the trans-border pollution threat that became reality this week.

But no serious attempt was made to link the burning to land ownership until May this year, when satellite images of fires were manually brought together with various land-use maps.

Then last Friday week, just days after Mr Soeharto gave his clear stamp of approval to a new approach, Mr Sarwono called in the country's new generation - well educated young mapping specialists, who cut across the boundaries of the old departmental rivalries which often strangle reform projects in Indonesia.

Over the weekend, volunteers from non-government organisations worked with government officials to create a makeshift control centre, where computer-generated maps can immediately highlight who owns the land where fires have started.

Mr Sarwono says he called company executives to his house to demonstrate how their anonymity as arsonists was finally over. "He had to admit. He couldn't run away any more," he recalls with a grin about one sheepish corporate heavy.

THE FIRES: HOW BAD CAN IT GET?

The Cause

* Long dry season (2 months longer than usual El Nino impact)

* Excessive land clearing by fire

The Impact

* 8 Indonesian airports closed

* 1,000 flights disrupted

* Health threat to 20 million Indonesians

* Evacuation plans in Indonesia and Malaysia

* Diplomatic embarassment for Indonesia

* Severe pollution in Singapore and Malaysia

The Solution

* Better weather forecasting

* Satellite monitoring of spot fires

* Sanctions on companies

* New land clearing methods

The Geography

The fires are in central and southern Kalimantan 1 (affects Singapore) 2 and central Sumatra 3 (affects Malaysia) 4 and have been developing gradually over 3 months. The last week has seen new outbreaks in West Java 5 north Sulawesi 6

and Irian Jaya 7.
