urn:contentItem:4P85-13R0-TXN5-R28S-00000-00STATE ABLAZE: FIRE COUNT NEARS 1501994-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:05ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 2STATE ABLAZE: FIRE COUNT NEARS 150THE BUSHFIRE BATTLEReports by: Karin Bishop, Maria Ceresa, Jenny Cooke, Andrea Dixon, Eamonn Fitzpatrick, Sandra Harvey, Jacquelyn Hole, David Killick, Linda Morris, Andrew Perrin, Sonya Sandham, Helen Signy, Nicole Taylor, Asa Wahlquist, James Walker, James Woodford.

CENTRAL COAST: Fires around the Central Coast had stabilised by early this morning but authorities feared further major flare-ups in the hot, dry conditions predicted for today.

Thousands were evacuated yesterday from in and around Gosford and Wyong as fires raged on a number of fronts.

A spokesman for the Gosford City Bush Fire Brigade, Mr John Costello, said: "The really big fire we thought was going to come right down on us from behind Mangrove Dam has slowed down to spot fires. But it is likely to flare again this morning.

"Fires in the Somersby area continue to cause concern. Fire brigades are working hard to stop the further spread of this front, along Wisemans Ferry Road."

Yesterday afternoon, about 200 firefighters and 18 units moved into the Somersby area near Gosford.

Two houses were burnt in Mt White, along with an NRMA depot which included a service station.

The Central Coast was isolated after rail and road services were cut. Both the highway and the freeway were closed after police described the freeway as a "tunnel of flame". Train services were cut from Hornsby to Gosford as the fires in the Hawkesbury region spread and phone lines to the Central Coast were jammed.

Those evacuated from homes, retirement villages and youth centres flocked to the Central Coast Leagues Club last night to wait out the emergency. A spokeswoman for the club said arrangements were being made to accommodate the evacuees at the club overnight and that many people in the area had offered the use of their homes. Local residents and charities were supplying bedding for the evacuees.

* Firefighters late last night hoped to bring under control a blaze which had destroyed 800 hectares of the Ku-ring-gai Chase National Park.

The fire, which started at Cottage Point at 4.30 yesterday afternoon, was thought to have been deliberately lit.

National Parks and Wildlife spokesman Mr Michael McFadyen said hazard reduction last year had slowed the fire's progress to the north and south and the main campaign would be fought to the east, with backburning near McCarrs Creek Road.

Early this morning, the Ku-ring-gai fire had spotted east across to Bayview where it was burning in the Katandra Bushland Sanctuary, between Cabbage Tree and Mona Vale Roads.

NORTH COAST: The entire north-eastern corner of NSW was declared a fire emergency area yesterday as the number of uncontrolled fires jumped to 68.

A Grafton fire control spokesman, Mr Laurie Orel, said a small amount of overnight rain had done little more than hamper bush firefighters who were backburning through the night.

The Bundjalung National Park fire, which began shortly after Christmas, had joined with another already in the Doubleduke State Forest and destroyed more than 20,000 hectares.

The Banyabba fire was running over 25,000 hectares and Mr Orel said while fire activity was stable, forecast high winds would cause more trouble for firefighters.

By midday the temperature was 35 degrees and Mr Orel said he was expecting similar conditions today. Police were having difficulty finding "alternative dwellers" living in remote areas of bushland, he said.

NEWCASTLE: Half a dozen major fires are surrounding Newcastle, while a fire at Singleton has burnt thousands of hectares. The main fires are at Wollombi, Medowie, Williamtown and Nelson Bay, West Wallsend, Barnsley, Martinsville and Belmont North.

A police spokeswoman said there was concern for Killingworth and Barnsley, where a halfway house with 10 severely disabled persons in Bendigo Street had to be evacuated.

Campers in the Allynbrook and Dungog areas were evacuated, while residents of the Banksia Grove retirement village were evacuated.

SOUTH COAST: The NSW Fire Brigade confirmed last night that three people were trapped in a house in Yates Road, Bangor. Fire authorities said a water tanker had reported the three could not escape the house and required help.

A Fire Brigade spokesman did not know whether they had been successfully freed from the house.

Tents were on fire last night as a blaze swept through a camping site at Dolphin Point, south of Ulladulla. There were no reports of injuries. The Runnyford fire between Mogo and Batemans Bay has spread claiming 15,000 hectares of the Mogo State Forest.

Fire last night continued to threaten the western parts of Batemans Bay through to the south of Surf Beach, where property was damaged.

CENTRAL WEST: About 150 firefighters battled a blaze which has burnt about 1,000 hectares in the Hervey Ranges of the north-west of the Cabone Shire, near Yeoval.

Illus: Photographs by: James Alcock, Patrick Cummings, Elizabeth Dobbie, Sahlan Hayes, Dallas Kilponen, Andrew Meares, Steven Siewert, Andrew Taylor, Greg White. Two Diags: Fires along NSW coast - and across the State
